(History) (Review Exercise, Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise, Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on Ancient Greek civilization)

\begin{enumerate}
\item The earliest Greek civilisation was the \_\_\_ civilisation.
\item Democracy is an idea that started in:  
\item The Ancient Greek market place was called the:  
\item The Ancient Greeks liked to discuss ideas about knowledge, truth and the meaning of life. These ideas are known as:  
\item The rooms in a house that only the men used were called the:  
\item Greek soldiers fought battles in a formation called a:  
\item The largest Ancient Greek fighting ship was called a:  
\item The Ancient Greeks and the \_\_\_ controlled trade on the Mediterranean Sea.
\item Historical literature was invented by ‘the father of history'. His name was:
\item The Mycenaean civilisation began on the island of Crete.  
\item A Greek warship had up to 270 men pulling the oars.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 4 (Activity on imagining life in Ancient Greece)

Imagine you are a child in Ancient Greece. Write to a child in another country. Describe a typical day and what you hope to do in the future.


(History) (Discussion Exercise, Group Activity) D 4 (Exercise on household chores in Ancient Greece)

Discuss in a group how household chores in an Ancient Greek house were different from chores today. Share your ideas with the class.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 4 (Activity on different types of homes in Ancient Greece)

Find out about the different types of homes in a city in Ancient Greece. What size were the houses? How many rooms did they have? What features were there?


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on hoplite's armour and weapons)

Write a brief description of a hoplite's armour and weapons and how the army fought.


(History) (Writing Exercise, Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on Ancient Greeks)

Write your response to this question: ‘Why do we remember the Ancient Greeks?'


(History) (Pair Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on evidence from Skara Brae)

With a partner, discuss what these pieces of evidence from Skara Brae tell us:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item bones of sheep, cattle, red deer and wild boar  
\item grains of barley  
\item bone tools: shovels, pins and knives  
\item small bowls carved from whalebone  
\item fish bones and teeth  
\item seashells  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Group Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on tasks in Skara Brae)

In a group, discuss different tasks that people had to do in Skara Brae.


(History) (Role-Playing Activity, Class Activity) D 4 (Activity on Skara Brae, Exercise with interview questions)

As a class, write questions to ask a person who lived in Skara Brae. Take turns to be the person from Skara Brae. The other students interview that person.


(History) (Research Exercise) D 5 (Activity on Neolithic settlements)

Use books and the Internet to find out about Neolithic settlements in your country or region.


(History) (Research Exercise, Presentation Exercise) D 5 (Activity on Mayan works of art)

Research Mayan works of art made from jade, clay, stone, gold, silver, wood and bone. Create a presentation to show and describe some of the works of art.


(History) (Creative Activity, Pair Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 5 (Activity on designing and interpreting glyphs, Exercise on the use of images in communication)

Design three new glyphs. Swap your glyphs with a friend. Can your friend work out what the glyphs mean? Discuss where we use images instead of words, sounds or objects in today's world.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity, Question Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Mayan clothing)

Carry out some detailed research into Mayan clothing.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How did the different groups in Mayan society dress?
\item How did the Maya make their clothes?
\item What types of jewellery were popular?
\item How else did the Maya decorate their bodies?
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on differences between types of boats)

Explain how the following boats differ from each other: dugouts, coracles and reed boats.


(History) (Research Exercise, Creative Exercise) D 5 (Activity on creating a poster about ships and boats used for trade/exploration/war throughout history)

Use research to create a poster that explains how ships and boats were used for trade, exploration and war throughout history.


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Question Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on changes in ship types over time)

Choose one type of ship (for example, a warship or a cruise liner). How has this type of ship changed since the first one was built? How has its use changed?


(History) (Discussion Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on interpreting quotes)

Neil Armstrong said: ‘That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind.' Explain to a friend what you think this means.

Work with a partner. One of you is a television reporter. One of you is an Apollo 11 astronaut. Make up a television interview about the moon landing.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Draw a timeline and write different events in your life on it.  
\item We are all different. Our timelines are also different. Look at your friend's timeline. How is it different from your timeline? How is it similar?
\item What events do you think will be on your timeline as you get older? Tell a friend your ideas.  
\end{enumerate}

(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on the end of the Bronze Age)

The Bronze Age ended when people began to use:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item copper
\item iron  
\item tin  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Bronze Age settlements)

In some places, during the Bronze Age, people lived together in very large settlements called:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item villages  
\item farms  
\item cities  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on the transition from bronze to iron)

People started to use iron instead of bronze because iron was:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item cheaper and stronger  
\item stronger and more expensive  
\item softer and cheaper
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Iron Age burial site findings)

Archeologists have found a gold bracelet, a decorated sword and a shield in an Iron Age burial site. These objects tell us that the person buried there was:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item a farmer  
\item a warrior chief  
\item a trader  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Iron Age living conditions)

Most people in Europe in the Iron Age lived in:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item small farming settlements  
\item hill forts  
\item castles  
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item wagon
\item cart 
\item chariot  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (True-False Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Iron Age and Bronze Age)

Decide if these statements are true or false. Write ‘True' or ‘False' for each one.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Iron plough blades helped farmers to farm more land.  
\item Bronze Age settlements were built by rivers so the people could be safe.  
\item Iron Age tribes did not fight against other tribes.  
\item Iron Age people used local materials to build their roundhouses.  
\end{enumerate}

Write an explanation of how wall paintings help us understand parts of life in Ancient Egypt.


(History) (Group Activity, Research Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on buildings inspired by Egyptian architecture)

In a group, research three buildings that were inspired by Egyptian architecture. Write about each building, including where it is.

Write a brief explanation of why you think we remember the Ancient Egyptians.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Iron Age hill fort defenses)

Describe three features of an Iron Age hill fort that helped people to defend the fort from an attack.


(History) (Research Exercise, Creative Exercise, Group Activity) D 3 (Activity on Iron Age tools, Activity involving the creation of a class display)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item drawings of the tools  
\item brief descriptions of how the tools worked
\item brief explanations of how the tools changed people's lives
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Writing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on archeological interpretation)

Imagine you are an archeologist. You have found some objects in the remains of an Iron Age house. Write what you think each object tells you about the people who lived in the house:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item a mirror of
\item a large decorated shield  
\item the remains of a loom.
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Writing Exercise, Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Activity on Iron Age musical instruments)

Find out about Iron Age musical instruments. Are there any in a museum near you? What do objects like these tell us about life in the Iron Age?


(History) (Diagram Exercise, Drawing Exercise, Activity) D 5 (Exercise on Mayan society organization)

Create a diagram to show how Mayan society was organised. Remember to show and explain the differences between the various groups.


(History) (Research Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Activity on Mayan society's law and order, Exercise on crime and punishment)

Write a description of the system of law and order in Mayan society. Carry out some extra research on crime and punishment.


(History) (Research Exercise, Writing Exercise, Activity) D 5 (Exercise on Mayan kings)

Research and write a report about one of the Mayan kings. King Pakal of Palenque is one of the most famous kings. He became king when he was 12 years old. The rulers of the city-states were nearly always men, but there were sometimes queens. You could research the Lady of Tikal.


(History) (Creative Exercise, Activity) D 5 (Exercise on creating a poster or presentation, Exercise on the achievements of the Maya)

Create a poster or a presentation called ‘The achievements of the Maya.' Give examples of Mayan mathematics, writing and astronomy.


(History) (Creative Writing Exercise, Research Exercise) D 5 (Activity on theories about the Maya)

Create a newspaper article or television news report that explains different theories about what happened to the Maya. Carry out your own research to find out other theories.


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Short Answer Exercise, Research Activity) D 5 (Exercise on the Spanish invasion of Mayan land)

Find out about the Spanish invasion of Mayan land.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item When did the Spanish explorers arrive on Mayan land?
\item Why did they go there?
\item How did the Maya resist the invaders?
\item How long did it take the Spanish to gain control?
\end{enumerate}

\item Where did they land? Did they settle for long?
\item Did they fight with North American tribes?  
\end{enumerate}

\item Bartolomeu Dias  
\item Christopher Columbus

\item 1488 ce  
\item 1498 ce  
\end{enumerate}

\item Queen Isabella  
\item Queen Victoria  
\item Queen Elizabeth  
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item chicken pox  
\item scurvy  
\item measles  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the meaning of the word 'Renaissance')

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item release  
\item reactivate  
\item rebirth  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (True-False Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on historical facts)

Decide if these statements are true or false. Write 'True' or 'False' for each one.  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Many European traders began to look for new sea routes to India and the Far East because they did not want to pay the high taxes demanded by the Ottomans.  
\item A caravel ship was between 100 and 150 meters long and weighed between 250 and 350 tonnes.  
\item The crow's nest was where a sailor went to look for land.  
\item The invention of the printing press meant that books could be produced slowly.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the Age of Discovery and Exploration)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Recall what the 'Golden Age' means.
\item Explain how trade and ideas spread before the Age of Discovery and Exploration.
\item Analyse why there was an Age of Discovery and Exploration.
\item Recall some of the key voyages at this time.
\item Describe what life was like on a ship at this time.
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Short Answer Exercise, Question) D 5 (Exercise on Roman control in 265 BCE)

Which was the only country controlled by the Romans in 265 BCE?


(History) (Short Answer Exercise, Question) D 5 (Exercise on listing countries added to the Roman Empire by 30 BCE)

List all the countries that the Romans had added to their empire by 30 BCE.


(History) (Short Answer Exercise, Question, Listing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Roman Empire expansion)

List the countries that the Romans added to the Roman Empire between 30 BCE and 117 CE.


(History) (Map Exercise, Activity) D 1 (Exercise on finding countries on a map)

Can you find Italy on the map?


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Scandinavian countries)

The Vikings originally came from Scandinavia. Which are the three countries in Scandinavia?  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Norway, Sweden and Spain  
\item Norway, Denmark and Sweden  
\item Denmark, Sweden and Britain  
\end{enumerate}

The Vikings were also known as:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Norsemen  
\item Eastmen  
\item Westmen  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Viking chiefs)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item jarls  
\item karls  
\item thralls  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Viking meetings)

Groups of Vikings had regular open-air meetings to discuss local problems, vote on new laws and settle arguments. A meeting like this was called a:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Thing  
\item Thrall  
\item King
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Viking traders)

The long, wide boat used by Viking traders was called a:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item knarr  
\item canoe  
\item coracle  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Viking trade)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item gold  
\item iron  
\item silver  
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item one  
\item two  
\item three  
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]

\item Bjarni Herjólfsson  
\item Leif Erikson  
\end{enumerate}

\item 993 CE  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Writing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on report writing)

Write a report on trading between Mayan city-states. Include:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item why trading was important for city-states  
\item what is meant by 'bartering'  
\item how merchants travelled between the city-states.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity, Short Answer Exercise, Challenge Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Mayan feather trade)

Feathers were important and valuable to the Maya. Feathers were one of the most popular items that Mayan merchants traded. Find out the different types of bird that were the source of the feathers. How did the Maya use the feathers?


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on societal organization in a Mayan city-state)

Describe how society in a Mayan city-state was organised, beginning with the king and ending with the slaves.


(History) (Comparison Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on comparing Mayan cities to modern towns or cities)

Compare a Mayan city to the town or city you live in today. What are the main similarities and differences?


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Early Stone Age cave shelters)

Write down three things you might see in an Early Stone Age cave shelter. Explain how people might have used these things and what they tell us about life in those times.


(History) (Comparison Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on differences and similarities between modern life and the Stone Age)

Write down three ways in which your life is different from the lives of people in the Stone Age and three ways in which it is the same.


(History) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on imagining a battle experience)

Imagine you have survived a battle against warriors from an Iron Age tribe. Write a report describing what you saw and heard before the battle began.


(History) (Research Exercise, Creative Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on trading goods during the Iron Age, Exercise on making a class display)

Find out about three goods that people traded during the Iron Age. Draw each item. Make a class display. On a world map, place your drawing of each item in the country it came from.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Activity on researching Iron Age forts in different countries)

Research the locations of three Iron Age forts in different countries.


(History) (Group Activity, Presentation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on convincing a Bronze Age tribe on city building location)

Work in a group. Prepare a presentation to convince a Bronze Age tribe that you know the best place to build a city.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Bronze Age objects)

You have found some Bronze Age objects. These include a scythe, some gold jewellery, glass beads, a clay pot and a model of a cart. Explain what each object tells us about life and work in the Bronze Age.


(History) (Challenge, Research Exercise) D 3 (Activity on trade during the Bronze Age)

Find out about one material or product that was traded between two different countries during the Bronze Age.


(History) (Pair Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on reasons for building pyramids)

Pyramids were very expensive to build. Discuss with a partner why the pharaohs wanted to create these huge buildings.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on building a pyramid, Exercise on making a class display)

Research the different stages of building a pyramid. Make a class display to show your findings.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity, Data Collection Exercise) D 3 (Activity on ancient archeological sites)

Use books and the Internet to research ancient archeological sites in your country. Write a fact sheet describing where the sites are, how old they are and what was found there.


(History) (Creative Activity) D 4 (Exercise on creating a military duty poster for Ancient Greek city)

Make a poster ordering the men in an Ancient Greek city to report for military duty. The poster should describe what weapons, clothing and other items the men must provide.


(History) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 4 (Activity on imagining a hoplite on a trireme, Exercise on writing a report of a sea battle)

Imagine you are a hoplite on a trireme. Write a report of a sea battle. Describe the tactics used in the battle.


(History) (Research Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Activity on the Battle of Marathon, Activity on the Battle of Thermopylae, Activity on the Battle of Salamis)

Use reference books and the Internet to research the Battle of Marathon, Thermopylae or Salamis. Write about 100 words to describe the battle.

\item What tactics did the Greeks use when fighting at sea?
\end{enumerate}

\item as hammers  
\item to make jewellery  
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

(History) (List Exercise, Challenge) D 6 (Exercise on reasons for travel, Exercise on Vikings)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Think carefully about each reason. Make a list of reasons why a farmer might choose to travel. Make another list of reasons why a raider might choose to travel. Sort your two lists into order from the most important reason to the least important reason.
\item When you have prepared your lists, answer the following question: Why did Vikings leave their homeland and travel to other countries?  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 6 (Activity on the impact of the Vikings on a country)

Write a report about the impact of the Vikings on a country that you have not already studied. Find out about:  
\begin{itemize}
\item when the Vikings started raiding or trading with the country  
\item how the Vikings travelled to this country  
\item what items the Vikings traded with this country  
\item how much of the country the Vikings settled in  
\item the positive and negative impacts of the Vikings on this country  
\item how the Vikings have influenced modern-day life in this country
\end{itemize}

\item How have they stayed the same?  
\item Write a caption for your baby photo. Add your caption to the class display.
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Question, Short Answer Exercise, Discussion Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on Columbus's discovery of land)

Draw a picture of Columbus on a ship. Write what you think he said in a speech bubble.


(History) (Discussion Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on Columbus giving gifts)

Why do you think Columbus gave the king and queen a pineapple and a turkey? Explain your ideas to a friend.


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Map Search Activity) D 1 (Exercise on finding locations on a globe)

Look at a globe. Find: Europe, India, America.


(History) (Creative Exercise) D 1 (Activity on drawing a family tree)

Draw your family tree. How many boxes do you need for the people in each generation? Label each person with their name.


(History) (Research Exercise) D 1 (Activity on local water collection methods in the past)

Find out how people in your local area collected water in the past. Did people use a river, a well or a pump? How do you know?


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Research Activity) D 1 (Exercise on historical dental hygiene methods)

Find out how people cleaned their teeth before the invention of toothpaste. Are some of these methods still used today?


(History) (Creative Exercise, Design Exercise) D 6 (Activity on achievements of the Vikings)

Design a poster or write a short report on the achievements of the Vikings. Find images of Viking jewellery, crafts, games and writing to illustrate your poster or report.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Viking achievements)

Why are the Vikings best known for attacking other countries rather than for any of their other achievements? Write down all the reasons you can think of.


(History) (Research Exercise, Short Answer Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Exercise on the Viking alphabet)

Research the Viking alphabet and write a short report. How many letters were there? What were the letters called?


(History) (Presentation Exercise, Group Activity) D 6 (Exercise on European explorers and discoveries)

In a group, create a presentation to explain how European explorers gradually discovered more and more about the world. Include key dates, countries and explorers. Include the reasons for exploring and discovering new lands.


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Research Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Columbus's voyage and transportation comparison)

Columbus set sail from Spain on 3 August 1492. He reached San Salvador, in the Bahamas, on 12 October 1492. Find out the distance he travelled. Work out how many miles he sailed per day. Compare this to the fastest method of transport between Spain and San Salvador today.


(History) (Creative Exercise) D 6 (Activity on designing a poster for a Baghdad merchant)

Imagine you are a Baghdad merchant. Design a poster to advertise the goods you have for sale and to show that the goods have come from all over the world.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Activity on the Golden Age of Islam)

Research the period that historians call the Golden Age of Islam. Find three examples of developments in medicine, art, biology, physics and engineering.


(History) (Question Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Mayan cities)

What were Mayan cities like? How were the cities set out?


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the invention and impact of the wheel)

When was the wheel invented? How did people move heavy objects before the invention of the wheel? How has technology changed the way in which we use the wheel?

Describe some inventions from early civilisations.

Discuss similarities and differences between life in early civilisations.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on evidence of early civilizations)

\end{enumerate}

Research and write about the goods that the Ancient Egyptians traded. Explain what the goods were used for.


(History) (Research Exercise, Presentation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on Ancient Egyptian seasons)

Use books and the Internet to find out about the three seasons of the Ancient Egyptian year: Akhet, Peret and Shemu. Prepare a presentation with illustrations to explain: when the seasons were; what happened during each season; what people did during each season.


(History) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on Roman empire expansion)

Write a brief explanation of why the Romans wanted to expand their empire.


(History) (Group Activity, Research Exercise, Creative Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on the first five emperors of the Roman Empire)

Work in a group. Find out some facts about the first five emperors of the Roman Empire. Include when they ruled and why they are famous. Make a class poster that brings together all the information.


(History) (Research Exercise, Writing Exercise, Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on Roman road network)

Use books and the Internet to find out about the road network built by the Romans. Write a report of between 100 and 200 words.


(History) (Drawing Exercise, Presentation Exercise, Activity) D 5 (Exercise on how people travelled and transported goods before the invention of the wheel)

Create a presentation or diagram to show how people travelled and transported goods before the invention of the wheel.


(History) (Question, Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on the development of roads)

How and why did roads develop? First, explain where the first roads were located and what they were used for. Then explain why a network of roads developed.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on the impact of the invention of the wheel)

Describe the impact of the invention of the wheel. Explain how the wheel changed the ways in which goods and people moved around.


(History) (Research Exercise, Question Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Activity on the invention of the wheel)

Use the Internet and books to research the invention of the wheel. Where do experts think the wheel was invented? How did the wheel develop over time?


(History) (Research Exercise, Creative Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Mayan city-states)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Research one Mayan city-state and find images. Write a fact file about the city-state you have researched.  
\item Create a travel guide for someone visiting the city-state. You can write your guide for someone visiting the city-state today, or for someone visiting long ago.  
\end{enumerate}

\item coracles
\item reed boats
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Survey Exercise, Data Collection Exercise) D 5 (Activity on transport usage, Exercise with charts and graphs)

(History) (Drawing Exercise, Activity) D 5 (Exercise involving the creation of a timeline, Exercise on the developments in transport)

Create a single timeline showing developments in transport. Include developments in road, rail, air and sea transport.


(History) (Group Activity, Writing Exercise, Short Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Bronze Age objects)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]

\item For each object, write one reason why bronze is a better material for this object than stone or wood.  
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]

\item a long network of roads that merchants use to transport goods  
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}


(History) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on energy-efficient cars)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item clever cars
\item sharp cars
\item smart cars
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the impact of agriculture on Mayan civilisation)

Why and how did knowledge of growing crops change Mayan civilisation?


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the invention of the wheel)

Explain why the invention of the wheel was so important.


(History) (Research Exercise) D 5 (Activity on methods of transport before the wheel)

Research what methods of transport were common before the wheel.


(History) (Research Activity) D 5 (Exercise on transport and trade linkage)

Research how transport and trade are linked.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the impact of technology on transport)

Explain the impact of technology on transport.


(History) (Research Exercise) D 5 (Activity on developments in transport)

Research how developments in transport have changed people's lives.


(History) (Discussion Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on explorers using caravels)

Why do you think explorers used caravels?


(History) (Writing Exercise, Creative Exercise) D 5 M

Imagine you are a sailor on board a caravel. Use all the information you have learned so far to write an account of a day at sea. Make sure you include:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item a description of your caravel  
\item conditions on board the ship  
\item the problems with food and water  
\item your reasons for becoming a sailor  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Exercise on the caravel Pinta)

One of the most famous caravels of all was called the Pinta. This was the fastest of the three ships used by Christopher Columbus on his first voyage across the Atlantic Ocean in 1492. Find out as much as you can about this ship. For example, find out the ship's length, its weight, what features made it faster than the others, who sailed on it, and other voyages it made. Find out about a sailor named Rodrigo de Triana who was on board the Pinta.


(History) (Map Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the growth of the Ottoman Empire)

Describe the growth of the Ottoman Empire. Use a map to help you with important dates.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the growth of the Ottoman Empire)

Write a few sentences to explain how the growth of the Ottoman Empire led to:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item a new age of exploration  
\item a new age of discovery.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Drawing Exercise) D 6 (Activity on creating a timeline of Istanbul's history)

Use books and the Internet to research the history of Istanbul. Create a timeline showing the five most important dates in the city's history. Explain why you have chosen these dates.


(History) (Research Exercise, Challenge) D 1 (Activity on photo color differences)

Some photos are black and white. Some photos are colour. Can you use the Internet or ask an adult to find out why?


(History) (Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the first settlers of London)

Explain who first settled in London and why.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the rapid growth of London)

Describe how and why London grew so rapidly.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on plagues/fires/invasions in London)

Recall how plagues, fires and invasions had a major impact on London.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on London's famous buildings)

(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on London's development)

Summarise how London has changed and continues to develop.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Queen Latifa
\item Queen Boudicca  
\item Queen Elizabeth  
\end{enumerate}

\item 65,000  
\end{enumerate}

\item 46  
\item 56

(History) (Discussion Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on comparing historical and modern cars)

How is Karl Benz's car different from the cars people drive today? Tell a friend your ideas.

Make a fact file comparing old toy cars with modern toy cars. Think about:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item what the cars look like  
\item what the cars are made of  
\item how the cars move.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 2 (Exercise on Karl Benz and the first real car)

Work together as a class. Find out three facts about Karl Benz and the first real car. For example, find answers to these questions:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item When was Karl Benz born?  
\item Where was he born?  
\item What was the name of the first car?  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Group Activity, Research Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Anglo-Saxon society and culture)

Work in a group to research items of art and crafts, jewellery, coins and literature that provide information about Anglo-Saxon society and culture.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the Staffordshire hoard)

In 2009, the largest ever collection of Anglo-Saxon gold and silver was found buried in a field in Staffordshire, England. Research the Staffordshire hoard. How many objects were found? How were they found? How much was the collection worth?


(History) (Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on defining an Anglo-Saxon kingdom)

Write one or two sentences to define an Anglo-Saxon kingdom.


(History) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Anglo-Saxon culture)

Imagine you are an Anglo-Saxon king and a foreign king has come to visit you. Write a short speech explaining:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item how Britain is divided  
\item how an Anglo-Saxon king rules and controls his kingdom  
\item which types of people the visitor will see in an Anglo-Saxon kingdom  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Anglo-Saxon graves)

Anglo-Saxons were often buried with their possessions. When archeologists discover Anglo-Saxon graves, they find evidence of the different jobs that men and women did and the skills they had. Read more about what was found buried at Sutton Hoo and find out who may have owned these treasures.


(History) (Partner Activity, Writing Exercise, Discussion Exercise) D 4 M

Work with a friend. Discuss and write down your answers.  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Why do you think most Ancient Egyptian settlements were near the River Nile?  
\item How did a good supply of food help the Egyptian civilisation to develop?  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Group Activity, Timeline Exercise, Creative Task) D 4 (Exercise on important pharaohs of Ancient Egypt)

Work in a group. Make a display showing a timeline of some of the important pharaohs of Ancient Egypt.


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on Ancient Greece and Egypt)

A historian from Ancient Greece who lived in the 5th century BCE said Egypt was 'the gift of the Nile'. What do you think he meant? Do you think this is a good description?


(History) (Role-Playing Exercise) D 3 (Activity on trade between ancient civilizations)

Make up a role play between a Sumerian trader and a trader from the Indus Valley. Discuss the items you have to trade.


(History) (Group Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on map drawing)

In a group, draw a map of a Sumerian city-state. Add labels to show what is valuable and why the city-state might be attacked.


(History) (Research Exercise, Creative Activity) D 3 (Exercise on barges and ships from Sumer or the Indus Valley)

Find out about barges and ships from Sumer or the Indus Valley. Create a poster to show how these boats were made and how they carried goods.


(History) (Group Activity, Presentation Exercise, Research Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on the origins of writing)

Work in a group. Find out how writing began in Ancient Sumer, Ancient Egypt, the Indus Valley, Meso-America and China. Prepare a presentation to present your findings.


(History) (Short Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on writing tools across different eras)

Write a description of a writing tool that was used in:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Ancient Sumer
\item the 12th century  
\item the 1950s.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on how the method for making paper has changed over time)

Carry out some research to find out how the method for making paper has changed over time.


(History) (Comparison Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on similarities and differences between theatres in Ancient Greece and 17th-century Europe)

Describe two similarities and two differences between a theatre in Ancient Greece and a theatre in 17th-century Europe.


(History) (Comparison Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on changes in the history of travelling for pleasure)

Think about how people travel for pleasure today and how they travelled for pleasure in Ancient Roman times. Write about some of the changes in the history of travelling for pleasure.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on effects of cabinets of curiosity and early public museums)

Write about two effects that the cabinets of curiosity and early public museums had.


(History) (Comparison Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on sports and fitness activities)

Choose one modern sport or fitness activity and one from a period of time in the past that you have studied. Write about the similarities and differences between the activities. Why did people take part in the activity from the past? Why do people take part in the modern activity?


(History) (Essay Writing Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on recreation activities over time)

Write a short essay about how recreation activities have changed over time. Think about:  
\begin{itemize}
\item the amount of leisure time that people had  
\item the types of recreation activities  
\item people's reasons for doing these activities
\item how the activities have changed.
\end{itemize}

(History) (True-False Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on historical facts)

Decide if these statements are true or false. Write ‘True' or ‘False' for each one.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Many London streets were named after the main product that was traded there.
\item The Anglo-Saxons were the first to build a bridge across the River Thames.
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise) D 6 (Activity on Samuel Pepys and the Great Plague)

Use books and the Internet to find out what Samuel Pepys wrote about the Great Plague, a deadly disease that hit London in 1665, the year before the Great Fire. What did Pepys think caused the plague? When did he first hear about it? How many Londoners died in the plague?


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on identifying turning points in London's history)

In history, a ‘turning point' is a significant moment when something begins to change. A turning point can be an event, a development or an invention, for example. Identify three turning points in London's history, which changed London forever. Explain why you have chosen them.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise, Question) D 6 (Exercise on significant events in London's history)

Which do you think are the most significant events in London's history? Choose three events and explain why you made these choices.


(History) (Definition Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on defining historical events)

Define the Wars of the Roses.


(History) (Question, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 M

How did the Wars of the Roses come to an end?


(History) (Short Answer Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Exercise on Tudor period chronology and facts)

The following are all important years in the Tudor period:  1547  1509  1485  1516  1533  1603  1558  1553  1537  1536  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Write the years in the correct chronological order.
\item Next to each year, write at least one fact about the Tudor royal family.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Research Exercise, Short Answer Exercise, Challenge) D 6 (Activity on the Scottish ruling family that replaced the Tudors)

Find out about the Scottish ruling family that replaced the Tudors. How was Elizabeth I related to James VI of Scotland? For how long did James VI rule? What was he like as a ruler? Who took over the throne from him?


(History) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on imagining historical scenarios)

Imagine you were a Roman soldier based in London in 70 ce. Write a letter to your family in Rome, telling them:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item why the Romans chose to settle in London  
\item what London looks like (describe the town)  
\item why London is under threat and why a wall has been built.  
\end{enumerate}

\begin{itemize}
\item New York City, USA
\item Tokyo, Japan  
\item Paris, France  
\item Nairobi, Kenya  
\item Rio de Janeiro, Brazil  
\item Cairo, Egypt  
\end{itemize}


(History) (Research Exercise, Presentation Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Exercise on Roman objects found in London)

In London, builders and archeologists have uncovered many Roman objects. Create a presentation about some of the objects that have been found.


(History) (Writing Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Exercise on writing a report, Exercise requiring the description of Tudor society)

Write a brief report of no more than 100 words with the title 'Description of England'. Your report should explain how the population of the country was divided into four groups within Tudor society.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Exercise on Tudor food and society)

Find out about the types of food people ate in Tudor times. For example, what did rich people eat? How was this different from the food that poor people ate? What do the types of food that rich and poor people tell us about Tudor society? What types of food did merchants bring into England from abroad?

(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on early civilisations development)

How and why did the invention of the printing press lead to more learning?


(History) (Group Activity, Writing Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on list writing)

(History) (Research Exercise, Comparison Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on modern and historical printing presses)

Find out how modern printing presses work. Explain the similarities and differences between modern printing presses and printing presses from the past.


(History) (Creative Exercise) D 5 (Activity on designing a brochure or advert in Anglo-Saxon times)

Imagine you are an estate agent in Anglo-Saxon times. Design a brochure or advert to sell your friend's house. Include a picture of the house and a description of the house and the land around it.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on daily life comparison)

Write a description of a day in the life of an Anglo-Saxon boy or girl. Think about the jobs the child does, as well as food, washing and sleeping. What are the main differences between your life today and the life of an Anglo-Saxon boy or girl? Are there any similarities?


(History) (Research Exercise, Challenge Exercise) D 5 (Activity on researching historical towns or villages)

Find out about a very old town or village near you or in a place you have visited. Who lived there long ago? How old is the town or village?

(History) (Group Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the decline of the Roman Empire)

(History) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 5 (Activity on explaining historical events)

Imagine you are a history expert on television. You have one minute to explain the decline of the Roman Empire. Write what you will say.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the Eastern Roman Empire)

Find out about the Eastern Roman Empire. Make a list of the countries in this part of the empire. Find out how it was ruled. Explain when and why this part of the empire declined.

\end{enumerate}

(History) (Grammar Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on sentence correction)

Rewrite these sentences so that they are correct.  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Henry VIII had three children – two daughters named Mary and Eleanor and a son named Edward.  
\item Henry VIII married eight times.  
\item In Tudor times, household waste was collected from homes and taken away for recycling.  
\item There were three universities in Tudor England: Oxford, Cambridge and York.  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Short Answer Exercise, Question Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Henry VIII)

Answer the following questions about Henry VIII.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Who was Henry VIII's father?
\item What was the name of Henry VIII's mother?
\item Write the names of Henry VIII's three children. Next to each name, write the name of that child's mother.
\item Write the names of Henry VIII's three wives who did not have children.
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Short Answer Exercise, Question) D 6 (Exercise on entertainment in Tudor times)

What entertainment was popular in Tudor times?


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on historical games)

What was the game that poorer people played, and how was it described by a spectator in 1602?


(History) (Discussion Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on the Wright brothers' airplane testing methods)

Why do you think the Wright brothers made kites to test their ideas for an airplane? Explain your ideas to a friend.


(History) (Partner Activity, Role-Playing Activity) D 2 (Activity on the Wright brothers' first flight)

Work with a partner. Imagine you are the Wright brothers. Make up a role play about what happened on 17 December 1903.


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Research Exercise, Class Activity) D 2 (Exercise on first women pilots)

Work together as a class to find out more about Lotfia El Nadi or another of the first women pilots.


(History) (Activity) D 2 (Exercise on describing a modern teddy bear)

Look at a modern teddy bear.  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Describe what you can see.  
\item What is the teddy bear made of?  
\item How does it feel?  
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Comparison Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 2 (Activity on comparing modern and historical teddy bears)

Write three ways in which a modern teddy bear is different from the first teddy bears. Write three ways in which it is the same.


(History) (Discussion Exercise, Partner Activity, Challenge) D 2 (Exercise on comparing modern and old bears)

Which bear is best to give to a baby: a modern bear or an old bear? Explain your ideas to a friend.


(History) (Map Activity, Writing Exercise, List Writing Activity) D 5 (Exercise on the Roman Empire's growth and decline)

Use the map to write a detailed description of when the Roman Empire grew and declined. Write a list of reasons why the Roman Empire declined and write a sentence to explain each reason.


(History) (Discussion Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the Roman invasions of other countries)

Think about all the work you have done on the Romans and the Roman Empire. Do you think that the Roman invasions of other countries were always negative for the invaded countries? Or do you think that some countries may have welcomed the Romans?


(History) (Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Viking longboats)

Write a brief description of a Viking longboat.


(History) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Viking raids and settlement in Britain)

Write a short paragraph explaining why the Vikings raided, and then settled, in Britain.


(History) (Group Activity, Research Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Viking raids and settlements)

The Vikings raided and settled in many European countries. In a group, find out about these other raids and settlements. Where were they? Where did the Vikings go? Why did they go to these places?


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Fact File Creation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the events of 1066 and the Normans)

The Anglo-Saxon age in Britain finally came to an end in 1066 ce when an army from Normandy in France invaded. Prepare a fact file about the events of the year 1066 and the new military force – the Normans – who came to rule England.


(History) (Presentation Exercise, Group Activity) D 3 (Exercise on the history of telephones in your country)

Work in a group. Prepare a presentation that shows when telephones were first used in your country and explains how the telephone system has changed.


(History) (Drawing Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on creating a timeline of major events in telecommunications)

Make a timeline that shows five major events in the history of telecommunications.


(History) (Research Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on first messages sent by telephone and email)

Find out what was said in the first messages sent by telephone and email.


(History) (Activity) D 3 (Exercise with partner activity on creating and interpreting pictographs)

Make up some pictographs. Use them to write a simple message. Swap your message with a partner. Can you understand each other's messages?


(History) (Partner Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 3 M

Work with a partner. Write three things that people in an early civilisation needed to:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item measure to find the length
\item weigh
\item count
\end{enumerate}


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Creative Activity) D 3 (Exercise on the impact of numbers and writing in early civilizations)

Numbers and writing changed life in early civilisations. People could now measure and record things. Create a poster that explains some of the things that changed because of numbers and writing.


(History) (Question, Short Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sending messages)

How can we send a message without a letter?

(History) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Tudor England conversation)

Write a conversation between two people in Tudor England. One person has never been to a theatre, but the other person has. The person who has never been to the theatre should ask questions and the other person should answer them.


(History) (Comparison Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on modern and Tudor times football differences and similarities)

In what ways is the modern game of football different from football played in Tudor times? Are there any similarities?


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Research Activity) D 6 (Exercise on the life and works of William Shakespeare)

Theatres were very popular in Tudor times. William Shakespeare became famous for writing plays. Find out about the life of William Shakespeare and the plays he wrote. Which other people are famous for writing plays in Tudor times?


(History) (Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on Henry VIII's wives)

Write the names of Henry VIII's wives in the correct order of marriage, beginning with the wife he married first and ending with the one he married last.


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Partner Activity) D 1 (Exercise on finding similarities and differences)

Talk to a friend. Find out all the ways you are similar to and different from each other.


(History) (Writing Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on writing a letter about Tudor towns)

Imagine that you live in a town in Tudor times. Write a letter to a friend who lives in the countryside. Your letter should describe the Tudor town. For example, describe your house, the street you live on and the jobs people do in your town. Try to be as descriptive as possible – think about the sights, sounds and smells of a Tudor town as you write.


(History) (Comparison Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on comparing Tudor towns with modern towns or cities)

What are the main differences between a Tudor town and the town or city you live in today? Are there any similarities?


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Research Exercise) D 6 (Activity on Tudor London)

Use books or the Internet to help you make a display or poster about Tudor London. For example, how big was Tudor London? How many people lived there? Find a map of Tudor London. Include some images of Tudor buildings that still survive today. Can you suggest reasons why some buildings have survived but other buildings have not survived?


(History) (Research Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 6 (Activity on creating a fact file about a ruler)

Use the Internet or books to find a portrait of a ruler in a different part of the world. Write a fact file about this ruler and explain how the painter has attempted to portray the ruler. Here are some ideas of portraits you could look for:
\begin{itemize}
\item Suleiman the Magnificent, who ruled the Ottoman Empire from 1520 to his death in 1566  
\item Emperor Longqing or Emperor Jiajing of the Chinese Ming dynasty  
\item Emperor Akbar or Emperor Humayun of the Mughal Empire in India.  
\end{itemize}


(History) (Challenge Exercise, Research Activity) D 6 (Exercise on comparing written descriptions and portraits of Queen Elizabeth I)

Use books and the Internet to find some written descriptions of Queen Elizabeth I. How do the written descriptions compare with the portraits of Elizabeth?

\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\item a colony  
\item a region  
\item an island  
\end{enumerate}

(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the effects of the Suez Canal opening)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The population of Cairo increased  
\item Goods could be transported to the Mediterranean Sea without being carried over land  
\item The price of fish decreased  
\item Ibn Saud became King of Saudi Arabia  
\end{enumerate}

(Social Studies) (Writing Exercise) D 2 (Activity on self-reflection)

Make a list of good things you can say about yourself. Think about:  
\begin{itemize}
\item how you behave with your family and friends – are you kind, considerate, helpful, loyal?  
\item your work in school – are you hard-working, determined?  
\item other things you like to do – are you confident, co-operative, enthusiastic?  
\end{itemize}


(Social Studies) (Creative Exercise, Class Activity) D 2 (Activity on personal qualities)

Make a decorated shape with your name on. Add a positive personal quality you think you have. Let other people in the class add positive personal qualities to your name shape.


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on writing about a special person)

Think about a person who is special to you and write about what makes them special.


(Social Studies) (Drawing Exercise, Interview Exercise, Research Exercise) D 2 (Activity on creating a timeline)

Work with a partner to think of some questions you could ask family members to find out the information you need for your timeline. These are some of the things that you need to find out:
\begin{itemize}
\item when your parents were born  
\item where they lived when they were children  
\item when they married  
\item how long they have lived in the home they live in now  
\item when your grandparents were born  
\item where your grandparents lived.  
\end{itemize}


(Social Studies) (Writing Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Activity on self-assessment)

Write a self-assessment that describes some of your strengths and areas for development. Think about:
\begin{itemize}
\item subjects in school where you feel more and less confident  
\item how well you cope when facing new challenges  
\item situations when you react well and situations when your reactions are not so helpful  
\item whether you are able to persevere with something difficult  
\item whether you use effective methods to find information  
\item how well-organised you think you are  
\item whether you can think creatively and come up with new ideas or solutions to problems.
\end{itemize}

\item Design some clothing that shows some of the things and ideas that are important to you.  
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Creative Activity, Labelling Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on comparing generations)

Make a labelled drawing of all the things in your living room at home and all the things in your bedroom. Mark off the ones you think would not have been in your parents' living room and bedroom when they were children.


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on big changes in the environment/transport/communication/homes)

Write about some big changes that have happened in the environment, transport, communication and homes.


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on values in society)

Write a brief explanation of why you think values such as hospitality, generosity, respect, and tolerance would help to create a strong society.


(Social Studies) (Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on ways pupils can contribute to the life of a school)

(Social Studies) (Creative Exercise) D 4 (Activity on uses of land)

Draw and write about four different uses of land in your country.


(Social Studies) (Creative Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on cultural similarities and differences)

Make a labelled drawing. In the centre show some of the ideas and values that people have in common. Around this show some of the differences, such as clothing or food, which are special to some of the cultures represented in your school or community.


(Social Studies) (Creative Exercise) D 3 (Activity on different types of transport in local area)

Draw and write about the different types of transport you can see in your local area.


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on places for walking and cycling)

(Social Studies) (Group Activity, Research Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on recent public information campaigns)

Work in a group to find out about some recent public information campaigns in your country.


(Social Studies) (Group Activity) D 4 (Activity on designing a public information campaign)

Work in a group to design a public information campaign on a subject of your choice.


(Social Studies) (Group Activity) D 4 (Exercise on jobs in economic sectors)

Work in a group and choose a particular area of activity in either the primary, secondary or tertiary sector. Think of all the different jobs that could be done in this area.


(Social Studies) (Writing Exercise, Discussion Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on countries and capital cities in the Arabian Gulf region)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Make a list of the countries and capital cities in the Arabian Gulf region.  
\item What do you notice about the location of all the capital cities apart from Riyadh?  
\item Write why you think most people in these countries live in cities.  
\item What might you find at cities located inland?  
\item Write about the transport links you think these places have to other countries around the world.  
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on expected behaviors in Arabian Gulf societies)

Identify ways in which people are expected to behave in Arabian Gulf societies.


(Social Studies) (Creative Exercise) D 1 (Activity on natural and built environments)

Draw and label two natural physical features and two parts of the built environment in your country.


(Social Studies) (Partner Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on identifying natural and built environment elements in school)

Work in pairs to discuss three things from the natural environment and three things from the built environment you can find in your school.


(Social Studies) (Presentation Exercise, Research Exercise) D 1 (Activity on waste in school)

Find out what waste is created in your school. Tell the class.

Make a poster showing how some everyday waste can be recycled.


(Social Studies) (Lesson Planning Exercise) D 6 (Activity on sustainable development)

Prepare a lesson you would deliver to younger students that explains the idea of sustainable development simply. Include examples of how they could consume fewer resources.


(Social Studies) (Creative Writing Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 6 (Activity with article writing, Exercise on writing a brief history of the student's country's development since independence)

Write an article for a travel guide that gives a brief history of the development of your country since independence.


(Social Studies) (Research Exercise) D 6 (Activity on colonization in the Middle East or North Africa)

Carry out research into a country in the Middle East or North Africa that was colonised by a European power. Find out what form of colonisation took place, what goods were traded between the two countries and the cultural influence of the colonial power.

(Social Studies) (Writing Exercise, Activity) D 6 (Exercise on writing an article about urbanisation)

Write an article for a magazine that describes the process of urbanisation and explains some of its causes and effects.

\begin{itemize}
\item How many pupils are in the class altogether?
\item How many pupils are boys and how many are girls?  
\item If every person in the class uses three pencils and two pens in a year, how many pens and pencils must the school provide?  
\end{itemize}

(Social Studies) (Partner Activity, Listening Exercise) D 4 M

Work with a partner. Tell your partner about the different members in your family, your favourite food, favourite colour and something you really like to do. Your partner should listen carefully. Then swap and you listen to your partner. Both of you must be ready to feed back to the class what your partner has said.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Draw and label a picture of you as a baby and the things you may have worn, slept in or played with. Then draw and label a picture of yourself and the things you wear, sleep in and play with today.  
\item Write about three things that have changed about you and the things you can do.  
\item Draw a simple timeline. Write and draw things that have happened in your life. Make sure you put them in the correct order.
\end{enumerate}

\end{itemize}

\end{enumerate}

(Social Studies) (True-False Exercise) D 5 (Exercise about population)

Which of the following statements is true for the country you live in?
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The age group with the smallest number of people is 60–64 year olds.
\item There are more males aged 20–24 than females.
\item There are more women aged 50–54 than men of the same age.
\item People under the age of 20 make up the largest part of the population.
\end{enumerate}

The population pyramid shows that there are more males than females in a country. What might be the cause of this situation?

\item Which continent is between the South Atlantic Ocean and the Indian Ocean?  
\end{enumerate}

When a person is a citizen of a particular country this is known as their:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item culture  
\item nationality  
\item custom  
\item heritage  
\end{enumerate}

The process by which people are taught the customs, values, ideas and beliefs of the society in which they grow up, is called:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item socialisation  
\item indoctrination  
\item preparation  
\item immunisation  
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item accepted language  
\item original language  
\item official language  
\item indigenous language  
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item discrimination  
\item stereotyping  
\item prejudice  
\item inequality  
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\item Somalia and Libya  
\end{enumerate}

\item practise their sewing skills  
\item engage in sporting events  
\end{enumerate}

(Social Studies) (Group Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on personal identity)

Answer these questions for yourself. Then, discuss them in a group to decide why these things are important.
\begin{itemize}
\item How well do you cope when something is not easy – can you keep going?  
\item How good are you at telling other people what you think and feel?  
\item How often do you see what other people need, and do something to help?  
\item Do you make decisions based on what you know to be right or wrong?  
\item How easy is it for you to work with other people?  
\item Are you curious about life? What are the things you want to know and find out about?  
\item Are you able to respect other people's views in different situations?
\end{itemize}

(Social Studies) (Group Exercise, Design Exercise, Activity) D 2 (Exercise on student responsibilities, Activity on poster design)

(Social Studies) (Creative Writing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on agriculture, Activity on writing a letter to a government minister)

Write a letter to a government minister asking for funds for a hydroponics farm you hope to set up. Your letter should explain briefly how the system works and the advantages you think it has to offer. Also explain how it will help with your country's food security.

\item protein to build muscles
\item energy quickly and for a short period
\end{enumerate}

(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on the importance of rest and relaxation)

Explain why it is important for people to have rest and relaxation and describe two ways in which you get these things for yourself.


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on internet safety)

Write some brief guidelines for people who are new users of the internet about how they can protect themselves.


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise, Discussion Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the development of mass media in the Arabian Gulf)

Talk about the development of mass media in the Arabian Gulf.


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the use of mass media)

Describe and evaluate the use of mass media.


(Social Studies) (Drawing Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on weather symbols, Exercise with chart drawing)

Make a chart of symbols that show the different parts of weather.


(Social Studies) (Data Collection Exercise, Question) D 2 (Activity on comparing weather patterns)

Keep a record for a week of the weather in your country and in another, distant country. How is it the same and how is it different?


(Social Studies) (Drawing Exercise, Writing Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on responsibilities within a home)

Draw and write about the responsibilities of two different people within a home.


(Social Studies) (Group Activity, Writing Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on keeping safe in the home)

Work in a group and write some rules you would have about keeping safe in the home.


(Social Studies) (Writing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on shared values and goals)

Write a list of the shared values and goals that you think would help people in a country live and work well together.


(Social Studies) (Group Activity, Writing Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on cooperation for national improvement)

Work in a group to make a list of ways in which people can work together to make your country a better place to live.


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 2 (With Answer, Exercise on the importance of exercise)

Why does your body need exercise?

\subsection*{Answer}
\begin{itemize}
\item Exercising helps our heart and muscles to stay strong.
\end{itemize}


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise, Question) D 2 (Exercise on the importance of rest)

Why does your body need rest?


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on map scales)

Explain how scale is used to draw accurate maps.

(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the effects of climate and weather, Exercise on human activity)

Explain how climate and weather affect human activity in the Arabian Gulf countries.


(Social Studies) (Role-Playing Exercise) D 5 (Activity on a public meeting about a hotel development proposal)

Act out a public meeting where a developer is proposing a new hotel development in a coastal area of mangrove, which will attract tourists, bring jobs and create wealth.


(Social Studies) (Group Activity, Research Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on advertising, Activity on analyzing advertisements)

Work in a group to research and analyse some current advertisements.


(Social Studies) (Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on school life, Activity on improving school life)

Work with a friend to discuss how happy you are with life in school. Suggest one idea that you think will improve school life.


(Social Studies) (Group Task, Research Exercise) D 4 (Exercise about charities)

Work in a group to research some charities working to help people in difficult circumstances in your country or elsewhere in the world.


(Social Studies) (Drawing Exercise, Creative Exercise, Writing Exercise) D 6 (Exercise about the three early Muslim empires, Activity on creating timelines)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Create a timeline for each of the three early Muslim empires.
\item Write about two significant events or achievements during the time of these empires. Illustrate your work with a drawing.
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Creative Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on school life, Activity with drawing and labeling)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Draw a picture of yourself in school uniform.
\item Draw and label your school uniform.
\item Does your school have any other signs or symbols?
\item Write about two things that you do in school.
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Question Exercise) D 1 (Exercise about the need to take care of the natural world)

Why should we take care of the natural world?


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on the benefits of family)

Identify the benefits of being in a family.


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on independence, Exercise on ways children become independent)

Identify ways in which children become independent.


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on family, Exercise on family members' interdependence)

Describe how family members depend on each other.


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (With Answer, Exercise on finding about the past)

How do we find out about the past?

\subsection*{Answer}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Evidence for the recent past.
\item People who are older can remember life in their past.
\item Many different kinds of writing are useful. The documents kept by important people and the letters ordinary people wrote to each other can all give us clues about life in their time.
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on monarchy)

Which statement defines a monarchy?
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The ruler is elected by the people.
\item The ruler inherits power from his family.
\item The ruler is a military leader who takes power.
\item The ruler is elected by a national parliament.
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on government)

A group that tries to influence government and public opinion is:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item a community group
\item an interest group
\item a pressure group
\item a charity
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on local and foreign goods)

Copy out the true statement.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item People buying local goods leads to more exports.
\item People buying foreign goods will help local businesses.
\item People buying local food brings about food security.
\item People buying local goods will reduce imports.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item watch a film once a week
\item drink clean water
\item go to university
\item drive a car
\end{enumerate}

\item Mangrove swamps
\item Rainforests
\item Public parks
\item Date palm plantations
\end{enumerate}

\item judiciary
\end{enumerate}

(Social Studies) (Discussion Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the WHO, Exercise with group discussion)

The constitution of the World Health Organisation (WHO) states that ‘the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health is one of the fundamental rights of every human being'.

Work in a group to discuss this statement and what it means for governments and individuals.


(Social Studies) (Activity) D 6 (Exercise on being an active citizen)

Make a checklist of the knowledge, skills and attitudes needed by an active citizen. Fill in the checklist for yourself to see how active a citizen you are.


(Social Studies) (Creative Exercise, Group Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on culture)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Make a design for an object such as a pot or rug that shows an important part of your culture.
\item Imagine: A box containing eight items (or photographs) that show different parts of your culture today is to be buried in the ground, in the hope that people will find it in a hundred years. Work in a group to choose the items that you think should go in the box.
\item Draw each object that will go into your box and write down why it was chosen.
\end{enumerate}

How do you find out about how to stay healthy?

\item food products made from milk
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item eat too many vegetables
\item read too many books
\item do not get much physical exercise
\item do lots of physical work
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item fruit, fibre and nuts
\item sugars, salt and fats
\item cereals, grains and peas
\item fish, cheese and salads
\end{enumerate}

\item during a rainstorm
\item in bed
\item when outside in the sunshine
\end{enumerate}

\item helps you exercise for longer
\item allows you to bend and stretch
\item helps you run faster
\end{enumerate}

\item a child doing a simple chore
\item a child being paid pocket money
\item and the child doing something with that pocket money.
\end{itemize}

(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on oral evidence about the past)

Oral evidence about the past is:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item written documents that people wrote a long time ago
\item drawings and paintings people made a long time ago
\item the things that people who are still alive can tell us about their past experiences
\item objects people made a long time ago
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on ancient pottery)

Finding an ancient piece of pottery would prove that the people of that time:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item grew wheat and stored it in jars
\item liked to have flowers in their homes
\item carried water in jars on their heads
\item had the resources, knowledge and skills to make pottery
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on historical artifacts)

Objects we find in the ground can tell us about the past. Older objects are usually found:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item near the surface
\item deeper underground
\item near water
\item near trees
\end{enumerate}

People who herd animals from place to place in search of food and water are known as:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item nomads
\item wanderers
\item settlers
\item farmers
\end{enumerate}

The written records of an ancient trader would reveal that people of the time could write. Write two other things that the records might reveal.

Write three things that the ruins of an old building or settlement might tell us about life in the past.

(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on trade in the Arabian Peninsula)

(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on diseases)

A disease that is contagious is:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item passed on from one person to another
\item caused by eating bad food
\item caused by drinking dirty water
\item only a problem in childhood
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on bacteria)

Which is the true statement about bacteria?
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item All bacteria are bad for you.
\item There are no bacteria in frozen raw chicken.
\item Bacteria breed fastest in warm conditions.
\item Bacteria cannot survive in water.
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on non-communicable diseases)

Copy out the true statement.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Eating a high-fat diet can reduce the risk of developing a non-communicable disease.
\item Non-communicable diseases are only a problem for people who do not eat properly.
\item Regular exercise is a good way to reduce the risk of developing a non-communicable disease.
\item Non-communicable diseases are only a problem for elderly people.
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on hygiene practices)

You should dry your hands after washing them because:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item wet hands will get cold
\item wet hands will drip water on the floor
\item wet hands can't hold things properly
\item germs spread more easily on wet hands
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on wellbeing)

Wellbeing is about:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item having a lot of money
\item feeling that your life has purpose
\item being fit and healthy
\item being an important person
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on online safety)

Answer ‘Yes' or ‘No' to the following questions:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item I have met a person online and they say they would like to meet. Should I go?
\item A website wants my email address and phone number so that I can enter a competition. Should I enter these details?
\item A friend of mine wants me to send a digital photo of myself. Should I?
\item I get an email from a company that says I could win a prize if I enter the code word contained in an attachment. Should I open the attachment?
\end{enumerate}

(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on trade)

The important material that was traded from China was:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item wool
\item nylon
\item cotton
\item silk
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on early writing)

Examples of early writing are often found as:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item stories in printed books
\item shapes pressed into clay tablets
\item drawings on cave walls
\item calligraphy on special paper
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on trade)

Trade across the early Muslim Empire was made easier by:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item trading silk, shoes and wood
\item taking camels by boat across the Indian Ocean
\item using the same coins, weights and measures
\item building large cities
\end{enumerate}


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on trade, Exercise on resource distribution)

Explain why the different resources two groups of people had might lead them to trade with one another.


(Social Studies) (Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on trade, Activity on early trade items)

Identify two items that were the basis of early trade across the world and describe how they were transported.


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on trade, Exercise on early worldwide trade impact)

Explain how early worldwide trade would have had an impact on shipbuilding or on a craft such as pottery.


(Social Studies) (Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on trade)

Explain how the spread of the Arabic language across the early Muslim Empire would have made trade easier.


(Social Studies) (Question Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on role models)

How can a person be a role model?
