\begin{enumerate}
\item Du \_\_\_(sein) \_\_\_\_\_(schwimmen).
\item Maria\_\_\_\_\_(sein) \_\_\_\_\_(laufen).
\item Anna und Marcus\_\_\_\_\_(haben) \_\_\_\_\_(fragen).
\item Sie und ich \_\_\_\_\_(haben) \_\_\_\_\_(weinen).
\item Ihr \_\_\_\_\_(haben) auf dem Stuhl \_\_\_\_\_\_(sitzen).
\item Anna und Lena \_\_\_\_\_(sein) \_\_\_\_\_(reisen).
\end{enumerate}


(German) (Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D G (Exercise on the future 1 tense, Exercise on verb form)

\begin{enumerate}

\item Marcus spielt ein Spiel. – Marcus\_\_\_\_ ein Spiel\_\_\_\_\_.
\item Anna liest ein Buch. - Anna \_\_\_\_ein Buch \_\_\_\_\_.
\item Wir schreiben ein Test. - Wir \_\_\_\_ein Test\_\_\_\_\_.
\item Ihr redet zu viel. - Ihr \_\_\_\_ zu viel \_\_\_\_\_\_.
\end{enumerate}

(German) (Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D G (Exercise on modal verbs)

\begin{enumerate}

\item Wir \_\_\_\_ (sollen) das Essen heute vorbereiten.
\item Du \_\_\_\_(müssen) jetzt aufräumen.
\item Wir \_\_\_\_\_(mögen) diese Arbeit nicht.
\item Ihr \_\_\_\_\_(dürfen) im Wohnzimmer schlafen.
\item Wir \_\_\_\_\_(können) auch schon früher gehen.
\end{enumerate}


(German) (Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D G (Exercise on reflexive verbs)

Fill in the spaces with the correct form of reflexive verbs and reflexive pronouns.

\begin{enumerate}

\item Mario\_\_\_\_\_ über die hohe Telefonrechnung. (sich wundern)
\item Anna \_\_\_\_\_in jeder Stadt, auch mit Stadtplan\_\_\_\_\_\_\_. (sich verlaufen)
\item Du solltest \_\_\_\_\_, sonst kommst du nicht mehr rein. (sich beeilen)
\item Sie wollen \_\_\_\_\_\_alle für die gleiche Stelle \_\_\_\_\_\_. (sich bewerben)
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Die Häuser \_\_\_\_\_ neu\_\_\_\_\_. (werden, bauen)
\item Ich \_\_\_\_\_, ob ich eine Schwester habe\_\_\_\_\_. (werden, fragen)
\item Der Computer \_\_\_\_\_schon lange nicht mehr\_\_\_\_\_. (werden, benutzen)
\item Das Auto \_\_\_\_\_ von einem Mann\_\_\_\_\_\_. (werden, einparken)
\item Die Post \_\_\_\_\_ heute noch nicht \_\_\_\_\_\_. (werden, bringen)
\end{enumerate}

\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_   fragend
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_   trinkend

\end{enumerate}

\item trinken  \_\_\_\_\_\_\_

\item - er \_\_\_\_\_ (sein) gestern sehr spät nach Hause gekommen.

\end{enumerate}


(German) (Fill in the Blank Exercise) D G (Exercise on imperative form)

Fill the spaces with the correct imperative form. Pay attention to the use of uppercase and lowercase letters at the beginning of the sentence.

\begin{enumerate}
\item \_\_\_\_\_ (gehen) wir ersteinmal nach Hause!
\item \_\_\_\_\_ (sein) wir nett zueinander!
\item \_\_\_\_\_ (machen) bitte die Tür zu!
\item \_\_\_\_\_ (abschließen) dein Fahrrad bitte noch!
\item \_\_\_\_\_ (aufpassen) gut auf euch\_\_\_\_!
\item \_\_\_\_\_ (lassen) mich in Ruhe!
\item \_\_\_\_\_ (trinken) Sie nicht so viel Alkohol, das ist sehr schlecht für die Leber!
\end{enumerate}


(German) (Fill in the Blank Exercise) D G (Exercise on adjective conjunction, Exercise with adjectives)

Fill in the spaces with the correct form of the adjectives in parentheses.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Frankfurt ist eine sehr \_\_\_\_\_ (schön) Stadt.
    \item Meine \_\_\_\_\_(rot) Tasche ist mit heute geklaut worden. 
    \item Ist dein Auto \_\_\_\_\_(schnell)?
    \item Du hast einen \_\_\_\_\_ (klein) Hund.
    \item Meine Tochter ist schon richtig \_\_\_\_\_ (groß) geworden.
    \item Der Stift gehört dem \_\_\_\_\_\_ (klein) Mädchen.
\end{enumerate}


(German) (Fill in the Blank Exercise) D G (Exercise on choosing the correct word)

Choose the correct word to complete the sentence.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Ich habe mir heute frei genommen. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ muss ich nicht zur Arbeit gehen. (Deshalb, Ganz, Sehr, Anders)
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ möchte ich den ganzen Tag auf dem Sofa liegen und mich entspannen. (Ganz, Morgen, Rechts, Hinein)
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ ist die Prüfungsphase vorbei. (Sehr, Äußerst, Darum, Folglich, Bald)
\item Gefällt dir das neue Sofa? - Ja, \_\_\_\_\_\_\_. (darum, sehr, ganz, bald)
\item Wir warten \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ auf euch. (darum, bald, drinnen, ganz)
\end{enumerate}


(German) (Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D G (Exercise on prepositions)

Choose the correct preposition for each space below.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Das Essen steht \_\_\_\_\_\_ dem Tisch. – auf, unter, hinter
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_ Meer schwimmen viele Fische. - Auf, Zu, Im
\item Die Stadt ist \_\_\_\_ Wochenende besonders voll. - am, unter, neben
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_ der Woche muss ich immer arbeiten. - Am, Auf, Unter
\item Du kannst so \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ mit meinem Anruf rechnen. - gegen, zu, bei
\item Ich habe jeden Montag \_\_\_\_\_ Tanztraining. - um, bei, seit
\item Sie sind jetzt \_\_\_\_\_\_ Wochen ein Paar. - für, zwischen, seit
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Group Activity, Prediction Exercise) D 1 (Exercise involving movement predictions)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Plan with your group how you will explore the movement of three different things.
  \item Describe the movement of your objects.
  \item Think about how you will record what you see.
  \item Predict what the movements will be like.
  \item Show your plan to the teacher.
  \item Carry out your plan for each thing. Record it.
  \item Talk about the movements with your group. Compare them.
  \item Compare what you saw happen with what you predicted. Were you right?
  \item Share your results with the class.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Group Activity) D 1 (Exercise on senses)

\begin{itemize}
  \item In your group, you will explore how your senses help you.
  \item Collect five different objects. Choose things of different sizes, materials, feel, colour and smell.
  \item Put the things under a cloth on a tray or table.
  \item You will swap with another group so that you don’t know what the objects are.
  \item Then you will take turns to feel the objects under the cloth.
  \item Plan how you will tell the class what each animal uses its sense to help it.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Question, Observation Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on plants, Activity on seed growth)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Collect the things needed to explore how seeds grow into plants.
  \item Put a group name or number on the pot.
  \item When the seeds have been planted and have what they need, put the pot in a good place.
  \item Look at the pot each day.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Draw pictures of it. Record any changes you see.
    \item Put the day’s date on each drawing.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item How can you stop them from falling over as they get bigger?
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Try to keep your plants alive until the flowers open.
    \item Draw the plant with flowers. Put the day’s date on your drawing.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Look at the plants and drawings from other groups. Compare them with yours.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Are they different?
    \item How are they different?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Draw a plant that is different from yours.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Show it to the class.
    \item Tell the class what you can see.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Now you have finished, what have you found out about growing plants from seeds? Tell the class what you think.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity) D 2 (Exercise on sound, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Go outside and stand in a circle. Face outwards.
  \item Listen to the sound made by the teacher.
  \item Slowly move away from the teacher. Listen for the sound.
  \item Stop and listen. What do you notice? Try to explain it.
  \item Predict what will happen if you go further away from the source of the sound. Tell the class.
  \item Slowly move further away. Listen for the sound.
  \item Was your prediction correct?
  \item Try to explain what you have observed.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A group of students standing in a circle facing outward, with a teacher in the center making a sound. The students are depicted at various distances from the teacher, illustrating the concept of sound traveling and becoming fainter as they move away. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Group Activity, Matching Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on light sources, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Talk with your group about all the sources of light you can identify.
  \item Make a list of all the sources.
  \item Share the list with the class.
  \item Look at the light sources in the picture. Copy the letters (a) to (h).
  \item Match the names below to the light sources and write them down next to the letters.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item television
    \item torch
    \item street light
    \item candle
    \item fire
    \item oil lamp
    \item headlights
    \item desk lamp
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows various light sources labeled with letters (a) to (h). The sources include a torch, candle, fire, oil lamp, television, desk lamp, street light, and headlights. Each source is distinct and easily identifiable. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity) D 2 (Exercise on materials, Exercise with heating and cooling)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose two of the following materials for your exploration: wax, chocolate, butter, ice.
  \item Talk with your group about how you will explore the way these materials change:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item when they are heated
    \item when they are cooled.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Plan to make your exploration fair.
  \item Decide what equipment you need and collect it.
  \item Choose how you will record what you find out.
  \item Make predictions about both materials, and write down your predictions. Say:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item how they will change when heated
    \item how they will change when cooled.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Heat the first material.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Observe it closely. What can you smell, hear and see?
    \item Record any changes.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item When there are no more changes, let the material cool.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Observe it closely.
    \item Record any changes.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Use the second material. Do the heating and cooling as you did with the first one.
  \item Record what you found out.
  \item Compare your results with what you predicted might happen. Were your predictions right?
  \item Compare the way the two materials were changed by heating and cooling.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What was the same?
    \item What was different?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share with the class what you found out.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Observation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on dissolving materials, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Look at the pictures. What is the same about all of them?
  \item Make a list of three materials that do not behave this way when mixed with water.
  \item Tell the class what your three materials are.
  \item Some materials dissolve in water and others do not dissolve in water. When a material dissolves it disappears – it cannot be seen.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Is the material still there?
    \item How can you tell?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your answer with the class.
\end{enumerate}
[STRDGM] The image shows various materials being mixed with water, including sugar, salt, and jelly cubes, demonstrating which dissolve and which do not. There are also containers with clear water and the materials being added to them. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on Earth spinning, Exercise on Earth's illumination)

Discuss with your group why the Earth is half-lit and half-dark in many pictures. Share your group's ideas with the class.


(Science) (Activity, Experiment Exercise) D 2 (Exercise involving a cardboard box, Activity with light observation)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Find a small cardboard box. For example, a cereal packet or a shoe box.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Cut a small flap in the end of the box. This flap will act as a ‘window’ that can be opened and closed.
    \item Make a small hole in one side of the box for you to peep through.
    \item Put some small coloured objects in the box.
    \item Wrap the box in black paper or a cloth to keep out the light. Cut the same flap and hole in the wrapping.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Open the flap and then peep through the hole. What can you see?
  \item Record what you observe.
  \item Predict what will happen when you close the flap.
  \item Close the flap and peep through the small hole again. What can you see?
  \item Record what you observe.
  \item Talk with your group about what you found out.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Try to explain it.
    \item Share what you found out with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity) D 1 (Exercise on sound, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Go outside. Find a good place to sit still and be as quiet as you can.
\item Be very still. What can you hear?
\item Do you know what is making each sound?
\item When you have heard four different sounds, tell your teacher.
\item Back in class, identify the sounds you heard.
\end{enumerate}
[STRDGM] An outdoor setting with various sources of sound, such as birds chirping, a car passing by, trees rustling, and water flowing. The scene is peaceful, with a clear sky and greenery around, allowing for an immersive listening experience. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Question, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on plants, Exercise on plant growth requirements)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Talk to your group about how you can find an answer to the question: ‘What are two of the things plants need to grow?’
  \item Share your ideas with the class.
  \item Plan the part of the investigation that your group will do.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Plan how you will collect the evidence.
    \item Plan how to record what happens.
    \item What do you think will happen? Tell your prediction to your teacher.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Choose the things you need for the investigation and collect them.
  \item Share your group's plan with the teacher.
  \item Do your investigation and record what happens.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Are the results the same as your prediction? Was it right or wrong?
    \item Share the results with the class.
    \item Listen and look as other groups report their results.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item What is the answer to the question you investigated?
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Tell the class what you think.
    \item Try to explain why you think that.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sound)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Plan with your group to explore how you hear sounds.
  \item Choose the things you need. Collect them.
  \item Plan what you will do and how you will do it. Like this:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item First we \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
    \item Then we \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
    \item Next we \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
  \end{itemize}
  \item Tell your teacher what you plan to do. Predict. Tell your teacher what you think will happen.
  \item Do your exploration.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make observations.
    \item What did you find out? Record the results.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare your results with your prediction. Is this what you thought would happen?
  \item Tell the class what you found out.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on appearance)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Draw a picture of yourself.
  \item Now draw a picture of another child in your class.
  \item Display the two drawings side by side.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item How do you both look?
    \item What is different about you?
    \item What is the same about you?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Now do the same with drawings by another child in the class.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Talk about it with the class.
    \item Tell the class your ideas about the differences and similarities.
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on shadows)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Go outside in the morning.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Stand in an open place where you can see the Sun.
    \item Look for things that have shadows, such as trees or buildings.
    \item Show the things with their shadows.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Measure at least one of the shadows.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Write down its length.
    \item What time of the morning did you look at the shadows? Write down the time on your drawings.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Predict what you will see when you go outside at noon. Write down your prediction.
  \item Go outside as near to noon as you can and stand in the same place as before.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make a second drawing of the Sun and the same things on the skyline, with their shadows.
    \item Measure the same shadow and record its length.
    \item Write down the time on your drawing.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare what you recorded with your prediction.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What did you observe?
    \item Was it different from your prediction?
    \item Try to explain what you observed.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Predict what you will see when you go outside late in the day. Write down your prediction.
  \item Go outside as late in the day as you can and stand in the same place.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make a third drawing of the Sun and the same things on the skyline, with their shadows.
    \item Measure the same shadow and record its length.
    \item Write down the time on your drawing.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare what you recorded with your prediction.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What did you observe?
    \item Was it different from your prediction?
    \item Try to explain what you observed.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your drawings, your measurements, and your explanations with the class.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on the differences between materials found in the classroom, Exercise on changing shapes)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Find four different objects made of different materials. You will look at four different ways to change their shape: squashing, bending, twisting, and stretching.
  \item Record your tests. Complete one table each time you try to change an object's shape. Look at the example table shown to help you.
  \item Try to do the same things to each material. Remember to put the same weight on each material.
  \item Try four ways of changing the shape of the objects. Then record what you found out in the tables.
  \item In class, talk about what happened.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise involving musical instruments, Activity on changing pitch)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose an instrument and play with it, exploring how you can change the pitch of its sounds.
  \item Record the name of the instrument and the methods that you used successfully to change the pitch of its sounds.
  \item Choose a different type of instrument and carry out the same exploration.
  \item Record its name and methods as before.
  \item Take a third type of instrument and repeat the activity.
  \item Compare your results.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Come to a conclusion about how the pitch of notes from musical instruments can be changed.
    \item Can you see any patterns in your observations?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your results and conclusions with the class.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Observation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on shadows)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Go outside and look for three shadows. For each one you find, say what is making the shadow.
  \item Look at your own shadow.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Try to change it. Make at least four different shapes.
    \item Try to make your shadow disappear.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Show the class two of your shadow shapes and how you can lose 'your' shadow.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Group Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on shadows, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Talk with your group about how you can make shadows using a torch.
  \item Collect three objects that have different shapes.
  \item Play with the objects and the torch to explore what shadows you can make.
  \item Record the shadows as drawings.
  \item What do you notice about:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item where the light is?
    \item where the object is?
    \item where the shadow is?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Tell the class what you think.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A torch.
  \item Miscellaneous classroom objects.
\end{itemize}

Copy these sentences. Use these words to fill in the gaps: food, ears, speak, teeth, eyes.
\begin{enumerate}
  \item We use our mouth to \_\_\_ and to \_\_\_ and to breathe.
  \item We use our \_\_\_ to bite and chew our \_\_\_.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on body parts, Exercise with labeling)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Draw a picture of an arm. Can you name all the parts of the arm?
\item Touch each part on your body as you name it.
\item Write the name of each part on your drawing. Choose from this list: hand, finger, thumb, elbow, armpit, wrist.
\item Draw a line from each name to the right place on your drawing.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on body parts)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Draw a picture of a leg. Can you name all the parts of the leg?
\item Touch each part on your body as you name it.
\item Write the name of each part on your drawing. Choose from this list: ankle, foot, toe, knee, hip, thigh, shin, buttock.
\item Draw a line from each name to the right place on your drawing.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Question, Activity) D 1 (Exercise on body parts)

Do you know a song that can help us remember the names of our body parts?


(Science) (Activity, Investigation, Experiment) D 5 (With Material, Exercise on the melting point of ice)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Measure the temperature of the ice cube with the thermometer before you start warming it. Record your reading.
  \item Observe the process of melting.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Record the temperature when the melting begins.
    \item Repeat the temperature readings every minute and record them.
    \item When the cube has melted completely, stop the temperature measurements.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Write down what this investigation has shown you about the melting point of ice.
  \item Share the results of your investigation with the class.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Ice cubes.
  \item Thermometers.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on mixing solids with water, Exercise with predictions and observations)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Investigate what happens when you add a spoonful of one of the solids to water.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Predict what you think will happen.
    \item Write down your prediction.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Test the first solid.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Carefully observe the result of adding it to water and stirring them together.
    \item Record your observations in writing and drawings.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Repeat the same process with the second solid.
  \item Compare the results with your predictions and discuss them with your group.
  \item Share your findings with the class and try to explain the changes you observed.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on solutions)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Explore the process of making a solution of sugar and water.
  \item Record what you do and what happens.
  \item When you have made the solution, try answering the question:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Is the sugar still present, or has it changed into a new material?
  \end{itemize}
  \item When you have an answer to this question, write down how you came to your conclusion.
  \item Share your findings with the class and listen to those of other groups.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on acceleration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Plan your exploration of speeding up and slowing down objects to test.
\item Write down your plan and show it to your teacher, including questions like: "What happens if \_\_\_\_\_?" or "How can we make \_\_\_\_\_?"
\item Draw a table for recording your results with a column for predictions.
\item Explore each object one at a time until you have an answer to your question.
\item Record what happens as you use forces to speed up and slow down the objects.
\item Observe what happens when the object moves: off the board and onto the floor, or off the board onto the table or other surface.
\item Record your observations.
\item Look at your results and discuss them with your group.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Discussion Exercise, Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on movement)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Discuss with your group how you can explore changing the direction of moving objects.
\item Plan a fair test and show your plan to your teacher.
\item Make careful observations and record what you observe.
\item Look at your results and come to conclusions about how the direction of movement can be changed.
\item Share your results and conclusions with the group.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Group Task, Performance Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on the characteristics of living things)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Choose three characteristics of living things to perform in a mime or role play.
\item Prepare your performance with your group.
\item When it is ready, perform it for the class. Do not tell them which characteristics you are showing.
\item Ask the class to identify the characteristics you have shown.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Spelling Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on life processes, Exercise with unscrambling)

Unscramble the letters to find three life processes: tghow, tonniuir, temomev.


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on how objects change shape)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Plan your exploration of how objects change shape.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Choose at least two objects to explore.
    \item Decide which type of force to apply for each object – a pull or a push, or both.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Make a small drawing of each object to show its shape before you try to change its shape.
  \item Draw a table to record your predictions and the results of your exploration.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Object name and drawing before force is applied
    \item Force used
    \item Prediction
    \item Drawing of object after force is applied
    \item Was the prediction correct?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Try to change the shape of each object and record the result in a small drawing.
  \item When all objects have been tested, compare your predictions with your results and fill in the last column with ‘yes’ or ‘no’ for each one.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on insoluble solids and filtering, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Explore how filtering works, using the solids you have chosen.
\item Plan the steps you will follow, from making the mixture to using the filter papers and funnels to separate the parts of your mixture.
\item Observe what happens as you try to separate the materials of your mixture, and record your observations.
\item Repeat the process using a different insoluble solid.
\item Compare what happened with each of your solids and come to a conclusion about how filtering works.
\item Share your results and conclusions with the class.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Insoluble solids.
\item Water.
\item Filter papers.
\item Funnels.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on filtering, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose a solution to work with. Plan how to separate the solid from the solution:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item in a slow way
    \item in a faster way
  \end{itemize}
  \item Write down what your group will do. Plan your investigation in detail.
  \item When your plan is complete, show it to your teacher.
  \item Make a prediction of which method will be faster, and write it down.
  \item Collect the things you need to make a solution and make enough for repeating your methods three times each.
  \item Carry out your plan for the fast method and observe what happens. Record your observations in drawings and text as you go along.
  \item When you have a clear result, repeat the method another two times in exactly the same way. Observe and record what happens each time.
  \item Now carry out the slow method. It might be possible to do all three at the same time. Observe and record what happens each time, as you did for the first method.
  \item Look at your results:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss your results with your group.
    \item Write down your group’s conclusion and share it with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare your methods with the methods used by other groups:
  \begin{enumerate}
    \item Which one was the fastest?
    \item Why? Try to explain your answer.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
[STRDGM] The image shows two setups for evaporation: one with a shallow dish in sunlight and another with a heated crucible. The first setup has a dish with liquid and is exposed to sunlight, while the second has a heated container with liquid boiling. Arrows indicate the direction of vapor rising from both setups. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the solar system, Exercise on Earth's position)

Describe the solar system and the position of Earth in relation to the Sun and other planets.


(Science) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the solar system, Exercise on orbits)

Explain the concept of an orbit and what it means for a planet to revolve around the Sun.


(Science) (Discussion Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Earth's rotation, Exercise on day and night)

Discuss the Earth's rotation and how it relates to day and night.


(Science) (Calculation Exercise, Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Earth's rotation)

Calculate the number of rotations the Earth makes in a year.


(Science) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Earth's rotation, Exercise on Earth's axis tilt and seasons)

Explain the tilt of the Earth's axis and how it affects the seasons in different hemispheres.


(Science) (Comparison Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Earth's seasons, Exercise on hemispheres)

Compare the seasons in the northern and southern hemispheres, using examples from Australia and France.


(Science) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the importance of photosynthesis, Exercise on the process of photosynthesis)

Explain the process of photosynthesis and its importance for plants and animals.


(Science) (Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on photosynthesis, With Answer)

Identify the four essential components needed for photosynthesis.

\subsection*{Answer}
\begin{itemize}
\item Light, chlorophyll, water, and carbon dioxide.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Discussion Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on photosynthesis, Exercise on plant resources)

Discuss where plants get water, carbon dioxide, and light from.


(Science) (Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on plants, Exercise on energy storage)

Describe how plants store energy in the form of sugars and starch.


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (With Answer, Exercise on the nervous system)

Identify the main parts of the nervous system.

\subsection*{Answer}
\begin{itemize}
\item The brain, the spinal cord, and the nerves.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Unscramble Exercise, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on sense organs)

Unscramble the letters to find the names of the five sense organs: iksn, soen, yees, rase, guten.


(Science) (Activity, Discussion, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on soluble and insoluble substances, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Collect at least four different solid substances.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Choose two that you think are soluble in water.
    \item Choose two that you think are insoluble in water.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Discuss with your group how to make this a fair test. Write a plan of how you will do this investigation into solubility.
  \item Draw a table for your results, using column headings like this:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Substance
    \item Soluble
    \item Insoluble
  \end{itemize}
  \item Carry out the investigation on each of your chosen substances in the same way.
  \item Observe what happens and record the results in the table.
  \item Discuss the results with your group and come to a conclusion.
  \item Share your results and conclusion with the class.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A table with three columns labeled "Substance," "Soluble," and "Insoluble." The table is empty, ready for students to fill in their results after conducting the investigation. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on life processes, With Answer)

Identify and describe the seven life processes of living things.

\subsection*{Answer}
\begin{itemize}
\item Movement, respiration, sensitivity, growth, reproduction, excretion, and nutrition.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Comparison Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration, Exercise on the movement of living and non-living things)

Compare the movement of living things with that of non-living things, using examples such as plants and machines.

[STRDGM] An image showing a crystal growing in water on one side and various machines (like cars, planes, and ships) moving on the other side, with arrows indicating movement. The background should be simple to highlight the main subjects. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on how living and non-living things respond to stimuli)

Discuss how living things respond to stimuli and how non-living things do not.


(Science) (Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on the importance of respiration and nutrition)

Explain the importance of respiration and nutrition for living organisms.


(Science) (Activity, Comparison Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on life processes)

Illustrate the differences between living and non-living things in terms of their life processes.


(Science) (Activity, Research Exercise, Group Task) D 5 (Exercise on exercising and its advantages, Exercise involving a table, Activity on advantages and disadvantages of exercising)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Collect as many sources of information about exercise as people who are athletes and sports players as you can.
\item Use the materials to make notes about why people exercise.
\item Discuss with your group the advantages of taking exercise.
\item Draw a table like this one to record your group's ideas.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{table}[h!]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|m{6cm}|m{6cm}|}
\hline
\textbf{Advantages of Exercising} & \textbf{Disadvantages of Not Exercising} \\ \hline
& \\ \hline
& \\ \hline
& \\ \hline
& \\ \hline
& \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise, Group Task, Discussion Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on filtering substances, Exercise on separating mixtures)

Investigate how you would separate one substance from another.
\begin{itemize}
\item Choose one of the following mixtures: salt mixed with sand, sand mixed with iron fillings, or fine sand mixed with coarse sand.
\item Discuss with your group how you will do the separation. Make a plan of what you will do.
\item List any equipment you will need and show your list to the teacher.
\item Explain how your plan will work.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the circulatory system, Exercise on components)

Identify the main components of the circulatory system.


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the circulatory system, Exercise on the function of the heart)

Describe the function of the heart in the circulatory system.


(Science) (Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the circulatory system, Exercise on blood circulation)

Explain the role of arteries, veins, and capillaries in blood circulation.


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on blood cells, Exercise involving a list)

List the different types of blood cells and their functions.


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the circulatory system, Exercise on interaction with other body systems)

Discuss how the circulatory system interacts with other body systems (lungs, kidneys, digestive system).


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion Exercise, Investigation) D 4 (Exercise on the measurement of mass, Exercise involving a table, Exercise with comparison of mass)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Discuss with your group which objects you will use to explore the measurement of mass, and collect them.
  \item Choose a measuring device for finding the mass of your objects.
  \item Draw a table and record the names and the mass (in grams and/or kilograms) of your chosen objects.
  \item When you have 'weighed' them, list the results and sort the objects in order of mass, from the 'lightest' to the 'heaviest'.
  \item Share your results with the class and compare everyone’s figures.
  \item Look at the following statements and use the class results to choose the true statement:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Heavier objects are always larger than lighter objects.
    \item Lighter objects are sometimes larger than heavier objects.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Tell the class which statement you think is true and provide evidence to support your answer.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on conductivity, Exercise involving a table, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Collect at least 10 items made of different materials.
  \item Use a lamp in a holder and a cell in a holder and three wires to make a circuit with a gap.
  \item Think about the following questions:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item How will you use the circuit to test the items?
    \item How will you know if the material is a conductor or an insulator? Tell your group what you think.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Draw a table like this one in your exercise book (or Workbook). Record what you find for each item that you test. Put a tick in the conductor or insulator columns for each item.
  \item Discuss your results with your group.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What is common about all the conductors?
    \item Share your results with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A lamp
  \item A cell
  \item Three wires
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity) D 6 (Exercise on the effects of climate change, Activity on environmental factors)

\begin{itemize}
\item Predict what environmental factors could change the populations of plants and animals.
\item Share your predictions with the class.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Class Activity, Display Exercise, Creative Task) D 3 (With Illustration, Exercise on material properties)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Walk around the classroom and find five objects made of different materials.
  \item Take the objects to your desk and observe each one carefully.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Look at them, feel them, smell them.
    \item Think of words to describe the properties of the materials.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Record the names of the materials and the properties you have found.
  \item Display your materials and your record for the class to see. Look at what other learners have found.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] An image showing a classroom with various objects made of different materials, such as wood, metal, plastic, and fabric, placed on desks for observation. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity) D 3 (With Material, Exercise on the effects of force on the movement of an object)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Take a ball, a toy with wheels or some other object that can roll down a slope.
  \item Use a plank, desk or table top or other flat, smooth surface to make a slope.
  \item Plan how your group will investigate two of the effects of force on the movement of your rolling object: stopping and starting movements.
  \item Share your group’s plan with the teacher.
  \item Carry out your exploration of the effects of force on movement. Record the following three things each time:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item your prediction of what will happen
    \item what you did
    \item what happened.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item If you fail to have the effect you planned and predicted, try another way until you are successful. You can record results in a table.
  \item Share your results with the class. Show the class one way in which you started or stopped the movement of your rolling object.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A ball, a toy with wheels or some other object that can roll down a slope.
  \item A plank, a desk or tabletop or other flat, smooth surface to make a slope.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on push and pull forces, Activity with force measurement)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Collect some objects that your group wants to use for measuring force.
  \item Can you work out how a force meter works? Have a go.
  \item Draw a table with fields for object names, push object, pull object and force (N) to record your results.
  \item Measure the force you use to pull or push each object that you have chosen to investigate.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Record each time what force you used – a pull or a push.
    \item Record the force meter readings in your table of results.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your results with the class. Make a display of all the results.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Class Activity, Group Discussion, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on changes of state and temperature, Exercise on hardness)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose to investigate:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item either a change of state, or
    \item a change of temperature, or
    \item hardness.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Collect the items needed for your chosen activity.
  \item Discuss with your group:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item how you will investigate the change
    \item how you will record the results.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Write out the plan for the steps of your investigation and include your prediction of what you think will happen. Show your plan to your teacher.
  \item Carry out the activity, observing change and recording your observations in words and/or drawings.
  \item When the changes have ended, look at your results.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss them with your group.
    \item Come to a conclusion about what they tell you about the change you investigated: was it reversible or was it irreversible?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your results with the class and explain why you have come to your conclusion.
  \item Listen to the results and conclusions of other groups and ask questions if you do not understand or agree.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on conduction, Exercise on metals as conductors)

Explain why metals are used as conductors in electrical items.


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on conduction, Exercise on properties of copper and aluminium)

Describe the properties of copper and aluminium that make them good conductors.


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on tungsten, Exercise on the use of tungsten in lamps, Exercise on high-temperature suitability)

Discuss the use of tungsten in lamps and why it is suitable for high temperatures.


(Science) (Activity) D 6 (With Illustration, Exercise on the functions of electrical circuits, Exercise on components of electrical circuits)

Identify the different components shown in the image related to electrical circuits and their functions.

[STRDGM] The image shows a light bulb, a circuit board with various electronic components, and colored wires (red, yellow, green) used for electrical connections. The light bulb represents a source of light, the circuit board illustrates the complexity of electronic devices, and the wires indicate how electricity is transmitted. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Class Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Exercise on forces, Exercise with scenarios)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Look at the pictures, which show forces acting on different objects.
\item Try to work out the directions of the forces in each one. There may be more than one force acting at the same time.
\item Write the letters (a) to (g), and record your answers beside them.
\item Share your answers with the class and compare them with those from others.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows various scenarios: a parachutist descending with a parachute, a person snapping their fingers, a stick floating on water, a splash from a dropped object, a basketball being dribbled, two players shooting a basketball, and a person holding a water bottle. Each scenario illustrates different forces acting on the objects. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Question Exercise, Experiment) D 5 (With Illustration, With Material, Exercise on the movement of the Sun and the Earth)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Discuss these questions with your group:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Does the Sun travel around the Earth?
    \item What actually happens?
    \item What causes night and day?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Share your group’s answers with the class.
  \item Think of your activity with the ball and the light:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Which was moving: the torch (the Sun) or the ball (the Earth)?
    \item Did you still get ‘night’ and ‘day’ coming and going for your ‘home’ (the mark on the ball)?
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing the Earth with its axis tilted, labeled with "Earth's axis," "Day," "Night," and "Direction of rotation," along with a sun positioned above the Earth. The Earth is depicted in a way that illustrates its rotation and the concept of day and night. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A ball
  \item A torch
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation Exercise, Discussion Exercise) D 6 (Exercise involving data collection, With Illustration, With Material, Activity on circuits)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose to investigate:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What happens when you change the number of a particular component in the circuit, e.g. lamps or cells.
    \item What happens when you change the type of components in the circuit, e.g. changing from buzzers to motors.
    \item What happens when you change the size of components in the circuit, e.g. short wires to long wires, thin wires to thick wires.
    \item What happens when you try a combination of all three changes.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Discuss your choice with your group:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Plan a fair test to find out what effects the changes produce.
    \item Decide what observation you will make to assess the outcome (the effect) of the change each time.
    \item Prepare some form of record for your results.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item When the planning is complete, show it to your teacher and, when it has been agreed, collect the components you need for your investigation.
  \item Before each change, write down your prediction of what effect the change will have.
  \item Carry out the testing in a fair way:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Do everything the same each time, and making only ONE change at a time.
    \item Record the outcome each time, before making the next change in the circuit.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item When all the changes have been made, look at your results and do four things:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Compare the results with your predictions – were they supported by the evidence of your observations?
    \item Look for patterns in the results – was there any pattern and were there any results that seem ‘odd’?
    \item Use your results to draw conclusions.
    \item Use your scientific knowledge and understanding of circuits to explain what you observed.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your results, conclusions and explanations with the class.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a simple circuit with various components like lamps, cells, and wires of different lengths and thicknesses. The circuit should be labeled to indicate where changes can be made, such as adding or removing components, and changing wire types. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Lamps
  \item Cells
  \item Buzzers
  \item Motors
  \item Short wires
  \item Long wires
  \item Thin wires
  \item Thick wires
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise, Group Discussion Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on friction)

\begin{itemize}
  \item Rub your thumb and forefinger together.
  \item Write a sentence describing how it feels—smooth, slippery, sticky.
  \item Now rub some dry soil between your thumb and forefinger, writing a sentence describing your clean fingers.
  \item Wash and dry your hands, then dip your thumb and forefinger into oil.
  \item Rub them together as before.
  \item Write a sentence describing how it feels, compared to the other ways you did it.
  \item Discuss the results with your group and answer these questions:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item When did you feel least friction?
    \item When did you feel most friction?
    \item How has friction reduced?
    \item Is this useful in daily life?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Share the group’s answers with the class.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Class Activity, Group Discussion Exercise, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on friction, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Collect the items and materials you need to explore one of the methods for reducing friction:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item rollers—pencil or other rods, straws or branches; look to find smooth and rough materials.
    \item wheels—materials to make a vehicle, with and without wheels.
    \item surfaces—use a variety of items/materials to test them on.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Discuss with your group how you will show the effect of friction on your chosen method to reduce friction.
  \item Decide what you will measure—time, distance, or mass of the load.
  \item Keep a plan and record sheet in which you will write the measurements.
  \item When you have finished, record your results:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Carry out your measurements.
    \item Record them on the record sheet.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Introduce your method of reducing friction:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item e.g., structure your plane or boat, polish the load and the surface.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Repeat the same test as before and take at least three sets of measurements, recording them on the record sheet.
  \item Calculate and write down the mean.
  \item Compare the sets of measurements—what worked and with the friction-reducing method.
  \item Discuss with your group what the results tell you:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Come to a conclusion—was friction reduced or not?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Share your results and conclusion with the class.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Comparison Exercise, Group Discussion, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on plants, Exercise involving a list, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Look at the two plants in the pictures.
\item Compare them and make a list of the differences you can see.
\item Discuss your list with others in your group.
\item Try to explain the differences you have observed.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows two plants side by side: Plant A on the left is taller with broader leaves and a more extensive root system, while Plant B on the right is shorter with narrower leaves and a less developed root system. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Creative Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on metals, Activity with drawing)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Think of examples of how we use metals.
\item Write down some of the uses of metal.
\item Can you think of the names of the metals used in your examples? Write them down too.
\item Make drawings of three of the examples you see. Now have a look at what others have done.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise, Investigation) D 3 (Exercise involving data collection, Exercise on nutrition)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Collect packaging from a variety of foods.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Look at the nutrition information on the packaging.
    \item Use the information to sort the items into four groups:
    \begin{itemize}
      \item low in fat
      \item low in sugar
      \item high in fat
      \item high in sugar
    \end{itemize}
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Display your groups of packaging.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss your groups with the people you are working with.
    \item Record what you have found.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your findings with the class and look at what your other classmates have found.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Group Discussion Exercise, Role-Playing Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on the role of the senses)

Work with a partner.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Prepare a scene to involve one person reading the senses’ role and the other performing it.
\item Share your role play with the class.
\item Discuss with your group how you will use a part of the body the senses help to protect the body.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion Exercise, Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise involving data collection, Exercise on the effects of temperature on plant growth)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Discuss with your group how to test if temperature affects plant growth.
  \item Write down the question you will try to answer.
  \item Make a plan for a fair test:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Change only one factor and keep all the others unchanged.
    \item Show the plan to your teacher.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Write down your prediction of what you expect to happen.
  \item Collect the things you need. Decide what you will observe and how you will record your observations.
  \item Carry out the test until you have an answer to your question.
  \item What did you conclude from your results?
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Write down your conclusions.
    \item Compare the results with your prediction. What was the difference, if any?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Present your results and conclusions. Try to explain what you have found.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise, Group Discussion) D 6 (Exercise on surface testing)

\begin{itemize}
  \item Set up the slope in a place where the balls can roll down without causing damage.
  \item Draw a table to record the surfaces of the materials used for the slope.
  \item Write down your predictions for all the surfaces you are testing.
  \item Carry out your test.
  \item Look at the results and compare the times taken.
  \item Look for patterns in the results.
  \item Discuss the findings with your group and come to your conclusions.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on forces, Exercise on road safety)

\begin{itemize}
\item Discuss this question with your group: Why is it harder to stop a fast-moving car than a slow-moving car?
\item Explain your answer using what you know about the forces involved.
\item Write down your group’s ideas.
\item Discuss this question with your group: What can be done to improve road safety, using your knowledge of forces?
\item Write down your group’s ideas.
\item Explain how this will improve safety.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on insulators, With Illustration)

\begin{itemize}
\item Identify materials that are insulators and explain why they are used in electrical items.
\item Discuss the properties of plastics that make them suitable for electrical insulation.
\item Describe the role of plastics in household appliances and their advantages over other materials.
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] An image showing a kettle, a power socket with a plug, and a thermostat dial being adjusted by a hand. The kettle is blue and has a handle, the power socket is white with a black plug inserted, and the thermostat dial has numbers ranging from 1 to 5. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Group Activity, Long Answer Exercise, Creative Exercise, Discussion Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration, Exercise involving drawing, Activity on light and shadow)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Write a mark on a ball to represent your home.
  \item Make the room dark or go into the darkest corner of the room.
  \item Hold the ball at the top and bottom so that you can turn it slowly.
  \item Get another group member to shine the torch or lamp onto one side of the ball.
  \item Slowly spin the ball as the light shines on it from one side. Watch your mark on the ball as it goes into and out of the light.
  \item Discuss with your group what you have done and seen.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Try to explain what the ball and the light represent, as well as the movement of the mark into and out of the light.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Record what this activity shows.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make drawings of what you have done.
    \item Write an explanation of what this activity shows.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your drawings and your explanation with the class.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a village scene with three panels depicting different times of day: morning, noon, and evening, with the position of the sun changing in each panel. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Creative Activity, Drawing Exercise, Model Building Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on plants, Exercise involving building a model, Exercise involving drawing)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Go outside and find a small plant. Try to find one with flowers.
  \item Dig it up with care and take it to class.
  \item Draw a picture of the plant. Name each of the parts you can see. Write the names on the drawing.
  \item Observe the plant closely.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Look at how the parts are fitted together.
    \item Tell the class what you have observed.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Make a model of a plant. Choose what you will use to make it.
  \item Display your model. Now look at those made by others.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise, Long Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the parts and function of the eye, With Illustration, Exercise on light rays)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Identify the parts of the eye labeled in the diagram.
\item Explain how the iris controls the size of the pupil in response to light intensity.
\item Describe the process of how light enters the eye and reaches the retina.
\item Discuss the difference between rays of light from various sources (e.g., candle, moon, torch).
\item Illustrate how light rays travel from a light source to the pupil of the eye.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing an eye with labeled parts including the pupil, iris, cornea, lens, retina, and optic nerve. There is also a separate illustration of a light source, such as a candle, with arrows indicating the direction of light rays entering the eye. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Class Activity, Discussion, Creative Task) D 5 (Exercise on fruits and seeds, Exercise involving drawing, With Illustration, With Material, Exercise on seed dispersal)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Gather and collect seeds from fruits.
\item Use the hand lens to observe the fruits and seeds.
\item Discuss how the seeds are dispersed.
\item Illustrate how seeds can be dispersed, using different methods.
\item Match the pictures that show different ways of seed dispersal.
\item Draw a diagram showing the life cycle of a plant.
\item Explore the different types of fruits and how they help in seed dispersal.
\item Identify how seeds are adapted to their dispersal methods.
\item Create a chart showing the different methods of seed dispersal.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A chart with various methods of seed dispersal, including wind, water, and animals. Each method is illustrated with corresponding images of seeds or fruits that utilize that method. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A hand lens
\item A variety of fruits
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the roles of different organisms in a food chain)

Identify the roles of different organisms in a food chain (producers, consumers, predators, prey).


(Science) (Activity) D 6 (Exercise on food chains, Exercise with producers and consumers)

Create a food chain using examples of producers and consumers.


(Science) (Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on photosynthesis, Exercise on producers)

Explain the process of photosynthesis and its importance to producers.


(Science) (Activity, Classification Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on animal classification, Exercise on feeding habits)

Classify animals as herbivores, carnivores, or omnivores based on their feeding habits.


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the relationship between predators and prey)

Describe the relationship between predators and prey in an ecosystem.


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on magnetic materials, Exercise involving data collection)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Plan with your group how you will find magnetic materials in your classroom and outside.
  \item Write down your plan.
  \item Show your plan and predictions to your teacher.
  \item Collect the things you need for your test.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Test at least four different materials in the room and four others outside.
    \item Record the test results each time.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Look at your results. If you find any patterns, try to explain them.
  \item Share your results, conclusion and explanation with the class.
  \item Listen to the other groups and try to make a generalisation about the class results.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 3 (Exercise involving drawing, Exercise on plants, Exercise with labeling)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Draw a picture of the tomato plant.
\item Label it with the names of the plant parts. Here are the names with the letters mixed up: toro, fale, urtif, smet, wflore.
\item Show your drawing to the class.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Creative Activity, Observation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise involving drawing, Exercise on plants, Exercise involving a list, Exercise on similarities and differences)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Go outside and find two different plants. Try to find ones with flowers.
\item If you can dig them up, then do it carefully and take the plants back to class.
\item Observe them carefully.
\item Record your observations of all the parts you can see in drawings.
\item Label the parts you can see.
\item Compare the two plants and compare your two drawings.
\item Look for similarities and differences.
\item Make lists of the similarities and differences.
\item Display your drawings and lists for the class to see. Look at what others have done.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation, Discussion Exercise) D 6 (With Material, Exercise on habitats)

\begin{itemize}
\item Discuss with your group which two habitats you will investigate in your locality. Try to choose two that are very different.
\item Go outside with your paper, clipboard, pencil, and measuring devices. Collect information to be able to give a clear and full description of the habitats.
\item Return to class and discuss with your group the information you have collected. Present your descriptions and answer questions from others in the class.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Paper
\item Clipboards
\item Pencils
\item Measuring devices
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Group Activity) D 6 (Exercise on food chains, With Material)

\begin{itemize}
\item Look at all the food chains displayed in your class and find a common feature. Tell your group what you think it is.
\item Explain to your group what the arrows stand for.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\item stigma
\item petals
\item nectaries
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (With Answer, Exercise on insect pollination)

\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on transparent and opaque materials, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Plan an investigation with your group to explore transparent and opaque materials.
  \item Choose a variety of materials for your investigation.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Write down the names of the materials you have chosen.
    \item Write down your predictions about how the materials will behave when you try to pass light through them.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Plan what you will do. Make sure it is a fair test. Show your plan to your teacher.
  \item Test each material one by one.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Record your results in a table.
    \item Identify each material as transparent or opaque (or translucent).
    \item Write these words in your table and compare the results of your test with your predictions.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your results with the class.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on exploring local environments)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose where the environment will be:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item It can be in a field.
    \item It can be on the sunny side of a road, or on the shady side of the school.
    \item It can be in a pond or on a beach.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Make a plan with your group to explore a local environment.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item First we \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
    \item Then we \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
    \item Next we \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
  \end{itemize}
  \item If you need to collect plants and animals, you must choose what to use. It could be:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item a bag
    \item a bucket
    \item a glass jar
    \item your hands
  \end{itemize}
  \item Think of how to use all your senses:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item What can you smell?
    \item What can you feel?
    \item What can you hear?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Work as a group. Share out the tasks:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Collect all the evidence you can about the plants and animals in the environment you have chosen.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Decide how to show (display) what you have found out.
  \item Add the name of the environment that you explored to your display.
  \item What will you see when you look at what the other groups found?
  \item Move around the class. What has everyone else found? Is it what you predicted?
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion Exercise, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on seed germination, With predictions, Exercise involving fair test)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Discuss with your group what conditions you think are necessary for seeds to germinate.
  \item Choose which factors your group will investigate.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss how you can do a fair test to investigate the effect of the factors on seed germination.
    \item Predict what you think will happen, and write down your prediction.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Make a plan of how the investigation will be done. Show the plan to your teacher.
  \item Collect the equipment you need and set up the test carefully. Label any containers you use so that they do not get mixed up.
  \item Set up the test and put the containers with the seeds in a safe place where they will not be disturbed.
  \item Observe the seeds.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Keep a record of your observations each day for seven days.
    \item After seven days, share your results with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare what has happened to the seeds in each container.
  \item Continue with the test until no more seeds are germinating in your containers.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss with your group what you think this experiment has shown.
    \item Draw your conclusions based on the data you have collected.
    \item Compare the outcomes with your predictions.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your conclusions with the class.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Answer any questions that other learners want to ask.
    \item Listen to what other groups have found from their investigations. Ask them questions if their explanations are not clear.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Write down your own list of conclusions about the conditions essential for germination.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion Exercise, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the reflection of light, Activity with mirrors and foil)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Discuss the reflection of light with your group.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Try to name three other examples of natural reflection.
    \item Try to name three examples of artificial reflection.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your examples with the class.
  \item Play with the mirrors and explore how they reflect.
  \item Compare a mirror with a smooth sheet of foil.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Can you see images in both of them?
    \item Record what you observe.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Crumple the foil and look again. Make a note of what you observe.
  \item Put some water into a plate or bowl and let it stand still on the desk.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Look down into it.
    \item Make a note of what you see.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Gently shake the desk and look down into the water again. Record what you see this time.
\end{enumerate}

\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise, Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise involving data collection, Exercise involving writing a report, With Material, Exercise on plant roots)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Put water into the container and fill it to the top. Carefully dig up a small plant, taking care not to break off its roots.
  \item Lower the plant into the container and allow water to overflow.
  \item Wrap the plastic bag around the container.
  \item Use string to tie the bag tightly around the stem of the plant. This should hold the stem above the water level.
  \item Draw a table to record the water level each day, over at least a week.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Measure the height of the water in millimetres.
    \item Record the height in the table.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Repeat the measurement and recording each day.
  \item When the period of measuring is over, use the measurements you have recorded to make a bar chart showing what happened to the water level.
  \item Write a report of what you did in the investigation.
  \item Look at your bar chart. Discuss the function of the roots.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Write down your ideas.
    \item Share your conclusions with the class.
    \item Discuss the conclusions that different learners have made.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Try to answer these questions:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Why was the top of the container covered with a plastic bag and closed around the stem?
    \item Why did the level of the water change?
    \item What would have happened if the roots had been cut off before the plant was put in the container?
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A container
  \item A small plant
  \item A plastic bag
  \item String
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on planning and conducting a fair test)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Discuss ideas with your group to plan a fair test.
\item Write down the group’s plan and show it to your teacher.
\item Collect the things you will need.
\item Decide what evidence you will collect and how you will record it.
\item Write down your own predictions about what will happen.
\item Share your plan and predictions with the class, and listen to the other groups.
\item Set up your test, making sure to change only one thing (or factor) at a time.
\item Make a record of your observations at the time the test begins.
\item Record the time and date of your observations.
\item Make regular observations and record them until you see no more change.
\item Compare your results with your predictions.
\item Write down the group’s conclusions.
\item Present your results and conclusions in a display.
\item Explain your results and conclusions and ask other groups to explain theirs.
\item Write down the letters a to d to match the test results to the letters.
\item Identify what factor X and factor Y are in the test.
\end{enumerate}

Observe the effects of erosion on different landscapes.

(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Experiment) D 5 (Exercise on mirrors, With Material, Exercise on light redirection)

\begin{itemize}
\item Use the mirror to create as many different effects as you can.
\item Switch on the torch. Using a mirror, you can make the light from your torch beam shine on a wall.
\item When you have succeeded, draw a diagram of how you did it. Use arrows to show the direction and path of the light from its source to the mirror, and from the mirror to the wall.
\item Collect two shiny objects and take them outside into the sunlight.
\item Try using the shiny objects to re-direct the sunlight onto a wall or other shaded surface. How did you do it?
\item Back in class, draw a diagram of what you did with the shiny objects.
\item Discuss your results with your group.
\item Try to explain how the light was re-directed by the mirror and the shiny objects.
\item Compare the three surfaces. What is similar about all of them?
\item Share your results and explanations with the class.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A mirror
\item A torch
\item A variety of shiny objects
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (With Material, Exercise on mirrors, Activity on reflections)

\begin{itemize}
\item Write out the alphabet in capital letters on a sheet of paper. Make each one at least 2 cm tall.
\item Hold up the paper in front of the mirror. If the mirror is large enough, you will see all the letters at once. If it is small, look at each letter one at a time.
\item What do you notice about the letters when you look at their images in the mirror?
\item Write down what you see.
\item What do you notice about the images of these letters?
\item Write down what you see.
\item Try to make a word that looks exactly the same on the paper and in the mirror.
\item Look at yourself in the mirror and touch your left ear with your right hand. What do you see in the mirror?
\item Discuss the results of all these investigations with your group.
\item Try to come to a conclusion about how plane mirrors make reflections.
\item Share your words from question 3 and your conclusion with the class.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A sheet of paper
\item A mirror
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (With Material, Exercise on boiling water, Exercise involving data collection)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Set up a container of water above a heat source.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Put a thermometer into the water.
    \item Read the temperature and record it in a table with columns for time and temperature.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Read the thermometer regularly and record the time and the temperature each time in the table.
  \item When the water is boiling, read the thermometer VERY CAREFULLY and record the temperature.
  \item Write down what the investigation has shown you about the boiling point of water.
  \item Share your conclusion with the class.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A container
  \item A thermometer
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on light intensity, With Material, Exercise involving a table, Exercise involving data collection)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Handle the light meter and become familiar with how to use it and read it.
  \item Draw a table like this one to record your readings of light intensity in different places.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Place
    \item Prediction
    \item Meter readings
    \item Average readings
  \end{itemize}
  \item Write down the places in the first column of the table. Try to choose places where you predict the light intensity will be very different.
  \item Write down your predictions of where you expect the light intensity to be highest and lowest in the second column.
  \item Take the light readings. Take several in each place.
  \item Think about why you need to take several readings in the same place.
  \item Record the readings in your table.
  \item When you have finished taking the readings, work out the average for each place. Write the averages in your table.
  \item Compare your averages with your predictions.
  \item Come to a conclusion about the readings you made.
  \item Share your results and conclusions with the class.
  \item Discuss what you have all learned about light intensity.
  \item Try to make a generalized statement about light intensity and meter readings.
  \item Sort out this jumbled sentence: reading greater higher the the the the the light of on meter intensity.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A light meter
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Unscramble Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on the waste products of the human body, Exercise with organ names)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Think of the things that you have to do every day to stay alive and well. Share your ideas with your group.
  \item Sort out those that are to do with getting rid of waste products from the body.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss with your group which organs are used to get rid of each type of waste.
    \item Sort out the jumbled names of organs and waste products in the lists below.
    \item Match the organs and the wastes and write down the pairs.
   \end{enumerate}
   \begin{itemize}
    \item Organs: nksi, sykni, glnsu, vielr
    \item Wastes: elbi, awtse, niuer, baocrn dodiex
   \end{itemize}
  \item Share your answers with the class.
\end{enumerate}
