(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise, Group Discussion Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration, Exercise involving a table, Exercise on shadows)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Plan the investigation.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Write down your group’s ideas, including any measurements you will make and how you will record them.
    \item Think about how to make it a fair test. Think about what conditions of the test must be the same for each object.
    \item Show your plan to your teacher.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Collect the items you need and start the investigation as early in the day as you can.
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
     \item Take the first measurement and record it in a table. Use the table headings listed here:
     \begin{itemize}
       \item Time of day
       \item Object
       \item Shadow 1
       \item Shadow 2
     \end{itemize}
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Repeat the measurements throughout the day for as long as possible.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Remember to record the measurements as you collect them.
    \item What must you be careful to keep the same?
    \item What two features of the shadows should you be recording?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item When all the measurements are finished, look at the results.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss with your group what they tell you about changes in shadows over the day.
    \item Copy and complete these sentences:
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
      \item As the day goes by, the length of the shadow \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
      \item The other change is the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
    \end{enumerate}
    \item Share your answers with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Use the length measurements to draw a bar chart on graph paper, showing the changes over the time you made your observations.
  \item Display your chart and the record you made of the directions/positions of the shadows over the day.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a timeline with different times of the day marked (10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm, 2:30 pm, 3:30 pm) and corresponding shadow lengths for each time, illustrating how shadows change throughout the day. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Explanation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on condensation, With Illustration)

Look at the pictures. Each one shows what happens when water vapour – an invisible gas – is cooled down. In picture (a), the water vapour in the warm air touches the cold window. The water vapour is cooled and changes back into liquid water. It forms tiny drops of water on the glass as it condenses. In picture (b), the water vapour in the warm air touches the cold can. The water vapour is cooled and changes back into liquid water as it condenses.\\

Now try to explain the clouds in picture (c). Tell the class what you think.

[STRDGM] Picture (a) shows a warm glass with tiny droplets of water forming on its surface, indicating condensation. [STPDGM] [STRDGM] Picture (b) features a cold can with water droplets on the outside, demonstrating the same process. [STPDGM] [STRDGM] Picture (c) depicts a fluffy white cloud in the sky, representing condensed water vapour. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on flowers, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Collect some flowers from outside.
  \item In class, identify the petals and sepals of your flowers. What are the colours of the petals?
  \item Use the hand lens to observe the small parts inside each flower.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What parts can you see?
    \item Count the numbers of each one. Include the names of the plants if you know them.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Record your observations in a table like this one. Include the names of the plants if you know them.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Name of plant
    \item Number and colour of sepals
    \item Number and colour of petals
    \item Number of stamens (male parts)
    \item Number of carpels (female parts)
  \end{itemize}
  \item Choose one flower that has a large carpel or carpels.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Use a sharp blade to cut the flower in half lengthwise.
    \item Use the hand lens to identify the ova inside the ovary.
    \item Count the ova.
    \item Make a drawing of the flower that you have cut in half. Label the following parts on your drawing: petal, sepal, stigma, style, ovary, ovum, anther, filament.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your drawing and your observations with the class.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Compare the structure of the flowers that you looked at with the ones that other learners investigated. What is different? What is the same?
    \item Can you see any patterns in the observations?
    \item Share your ideas with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{enumerate}
 \item A hand lens
 \item A sharp blade
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on shadows, With Illustration, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Go outside on a sunny day and look at shadows. Notice their size and direction.
  \item Look at your own shadow and change it to create different shapes. Make at least three different shadow shapes.
  \item Share your shapes with the class and look at the shapes made by other learners.
  \item Try to lose your shadow – make it disappear somehow. Share your method with the class and observe the methods used by others.
  \item Back in class, discuss with your group what you have observed outside.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Try to answer the question: how are shadows formed?
    \item Share your group's ideas with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Plan how you can test your ideas of shadow formation using a torch and a number of objects.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make it a fair test. Think about what conditions must be the same for each object.
    \item Show your plan to your teacher.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Decide what observations you will make and how you will record them.
  \item Carry out your test and record what happens.
  \item Look at the results for the different objects. Compare them to find any patterns.
  \item Try to make a generalisation based on the evidence you collected.
  \item Share your results and conclusion with the class. Listen to others.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] An illustration showing a light source (like a lamp) casting a shadow of a spherical object on a surface. The light rays are depicted as arrows pointing from the light source to the object, and the shadow is shown on the opposite side of the object. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{enumerate}
  \item A torch
  \item A variety of objects
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity) D 5 (With Illustration, Exercise involving going outside, With Material, Exercise on evaporation)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Go outside into the sunshine. Do the following things:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Soak a small piece of fabric in water and hang it up in the Sun.
    \item Pour about a spoonful of water onto a plate, a plastic bag, or any other waterproof surface, and leave it out in the Sun.
    \item Wet your hands with water. Keep one hand under a fan. Open the other hand and spread your fingers. Stand in the Sun.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Observe what happens in the three situations. Note what you observe.
  \item When no changes are happening, go back to the classroom and share your results with the class.
  \item Compare the three situations. Try to explain what you have observed.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows three different scenarios: a piece of wet fabric hanging in the sun, a spoonful of water on a plate in the sun, and a person with one hand under a fan and the other in the sun. Each scenario illustrates the effects of sunlight and airflow on evaporation. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Fabric
  \item A plate
  \item A plastic bag
  \item A fan
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Matching Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Exercise on organs)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Look at the drawing of the body outline and find the numbers 1 to 6.
\item Look at the drawings of the six major organs and name each of them.
\item Write down the numbers 1 to 6, and match the names of the organs to the numbers. Write the names alongside the numbers.
\item Share your answers with the class.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a simple outline of a human body with numbered locations indicating where major organs are located. The organs depicted include the brain, lungs, stomach, heart, and kidneys, each represented with a simple illustration. The body outline is light blue, and the organs are colorful and clearly labeled with numbers. [STPDGM]

(Science) (Activity) D 2 (With Illustration, Exercise on condensation and evaporation)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Look carefully at the spout of the kettle and see if you can observe the ‘gap’ between the cloud and the spout.
  \item Now look at the cloud.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What do you think it is – gas or liquid?
    \item Tell the class what you think.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Watch carefully as your teacher holds the cold plate with the cloth and puts it into the invisible steam.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What do you observe on the plate?
    \item What do you observe in the bowl?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Try to explain your observations to the class.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing the processes of condensation and evaporation, with arrows indicating the flow from liquid water to water vapor (evaporation) and back to liquid water (condensation). The diagram includes labels for "Cooled," "Heated," "Liquid water," "Evaporation," and "Condensation." The layout is clear and visually organized to help understand the processes. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 5 (With Material, Exercise on shadows)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Using the torch, try to change the size of the shadow around one of the objects.
  \item As you make a different-sized shadow, draw around it to record its size. You can use sheets of A3 or A2 paper to do this and stick sheets together if you need to.
  \item Try to change the size at least three times: the biggest possible, the smallest possible and one in between.
  \item Share your drawings with the class. Discuss what you have observed and try to make a general statement about what controls shadow sizes.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Torch
  \item A3 or A2 paper
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation, Group Discussion Exercise) D 5 (With Material, Exercise on shadows, Activity with predictions)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Play with the torch and one object against a sheet of paper to act as a screen where you can observe the shadow.
  \item Predict what will happen to the shadow length as you change the distance of the object from the torch.
  \item Write down your predictions.
  \item Observe what happens to the shadow on the screen when the light source (torch) and the screen stay in the same position, but the object is moved further and further from the light source.
  \item Draw the shadows on the screen when the object is in at least five different positions (five different distances from the torch).
  \item Measure the distance each time.
  \item Record the measurements in a table like this one:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Observation
    \item Distance from source (cm)
    \item Length of shadow (cm)
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Discuss your results with your group. Compare your results with your predictions.
  \item Present your results as a line graph.
  \item Try to reach a conclusion and make a generalised statement about shadow length and distance from the light source.
  \item Share your group's ideas and graph with the class. Look at the graphs of other groups and listen to their ideas.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Torch
  \item A3 or A2 paper
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Activity) D 2 (Exercise involving a table, Exercise involving a survey, Exercise on switches)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Make a survey of switches in the classroom.
\item Record your findings in a table.
\item Move around the room. Look for at least four different switches.
\item Record each switch as a drawing.
\item In the table, write down where the switch is and what it is for.
\item Add up all the switches you can find in the room. Record this number.
\item Share your survey results with the class.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 3 (Exercise involving a circuit)

\begin{itemize}
\item Take the things you need to make a circuit.
\item Set it up so that the lamp lights up.
\item Take a switch and add it to your circuit.
\item Try to switch the lamp on and off.
\item If it does not work, connect the switch in a different way in the circuit.
\item Draw a picture of each circuit where the switch works.
\item Share your results with the class. Show them how your switch works.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Research Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on astronomy, Exercise involving exploration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Find out more about astronomy.
\item Choose a place that you want to explore.
\item Use books, CD-ROMs, or school library information on the internet to find information on the place and the discoveries made by people of your chosen time or place.
\item Make notes and drawings you find useful and interesting information.
\item Share your work with others in the class.
\item Prepare to answer questions about your research findings.
\item Look at what others have displayed and ask questions if anything is not clear, or if you want more details.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Question) D 4 (Exercise on sound)

What happens to sounds when they travel through a solid?


(Science) (Activity, Experiment, Discussion Exercise, Partner Activity) D 4 (Exercise on sound, With Material, With Illustration)

You will need: paper (or Workbooks) and a pen or pencil.
\begin{itemize}
\item Sit or stand opposite ends of the desk or table.
\item Cover one ear with your hand and put your other ear close to the desk or table.
\item Ask your partner to lightly scratch the desk top with a pencil or stick.
\item Now put your ear closer to the desk so that it is touching the desk.
\item Ask your partner to repeat the scratching.
\item Swap with your partner and repeat the activity.
\item Discuss what you both heard and come to a conclusion.
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a person sitting at a desk with one ear covered and the other ear close to the desk, while another person is scratching the desk with a pencil. The setup illustrates how sound travels through solids. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item paper
\item a pen or pencil
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Question) D 4 (Exercise on sound)

What happens to sounds when they travel through a liquid?


(Science) (Activity, Experiment, Discussion Exercise, Partner Activity) D 4 (With Material, With Illustration, Exercise on sound, Activity on sound traveling through liquids)

You will need: a balloon, a ticking watch, and a timer, paper (or Workbooks) and a pen or pencil.
\begin{itemize}
\item Fill the balloon with water and place it beside your head so that it touches your ear.
\item Ask your partner to hit the watch, clock or timer on the other side of the balloon, so that you can hear it.
\item Listen carefully and compare what you hear this time with the first time.
\item Swap with your partner and repeat the activity.
\item Discuss the observations you both made and come to a conclusion about sound travelling through water.
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting a person holding a water-filled balloon next to their ear while another person is hitting a watch on the opposite side of the balloon. This setup demonstrates how sound travels through liquids. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on sound, Exercise with sources of sounds)

\begin{itemize}
\item Discuss with your group where sounds come from.
\item Name as many sources of sounds as you can.
\item Write down each of the sounds you hear.
\item Share them with the class.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (With Material, Exercise on observation)

\begin{itemize}
\item Take a ruler or the edge of your desk.
\item Place the ruler on the edge so that more than half of it hangs off.
\item Flick the end of the desk. Repeat this.
\item Observe what happens to the ruler when flicking it.
\item Record your observations.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A ruler
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Group Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on sound)

\begin{itemize}
\item Choose an object that you can blow into to make a sound.
\item Try to make sounds with your chosen instrument.
\item In your group, discuss the sound-making - talk, listen.
\item Share a sound of what the group creates.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Group Activity, Activity on sound) D 4 (Exercise on sound)

\begin{itemize}
\item Choose the sound measuring device carefully.
\item Record the sound levels.
\item Compare the results made by the group.
\item Be sure to tell the class what you saw and heard.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on sound, With Material, Exercise involving a table, Exercise involving a chart, Exercise involving data collection)

\begin{itemize}
\item Handle the sound meter carefully.
\item Record the sound levels as instructed.
\item Try to see how the environment readings vary in different locations.
\item When you finish the first task, discuss how your group data comes to a conclusion.
\item Use the data to create a chart or a table.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A sound meter
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 2 (With Material, Exercise involving circuits, Activity on circuits)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Take a cell (battery), a lamp and two wires.
\item Explore what happens when you connect these things in different ways.
\item Draw a picture of each way you try.
\item Try to make the lamp light up. Record this on the drawings of the circuits you make.
\item Share your results with the class. Show them how you made the lamp light up.
\item Look at the four circuit drawings. Which ones will light the lamp? Tell the class what you think.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A cell (battery)
\item A lamp
\item Two wires
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Group Activity, Discussion Exercise, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on sound, Activity on sound transmission)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Discuss with your group which materials you think can reduce or prevent sound travelling from its source (its transmission).
  \item Plan an investigation of how sound transmission can be prevented or reduced.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make it a fair test, using at least three materials and a sound source.
    \item Predict what you think the results will show.
    \item Write down your prediction.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Decide how you will observe the reduction or prevention of the sound. What will you measure, and how?
  \item Decide how you will record your observations and prepare for the recording.
  \item Compare the effects of the three different materials on the transmission of the sound.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Carry out the test in a fair way so that you will be able to compare the effects.
    \item Record your measurements each time.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare your results.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Use them to make a conclusion about the three materials.
    \item Compare your results with your prediction.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your group’s results with the class and compare them with those from other groups.
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Activity) D 4 (Exercise on sound)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Take a ruler or flat strip of wood or plastic. Place it on the edge of a desk so that more than half of it is over the edge.
\item Hold it down firmly.
\item Flick the free end of the ruler. Repeat this several times and listen carefully.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Experiment, Group Discussion Exercise) D 4 (With Material, Exercise on pitch)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Hold a rubber band between your teeth and stretch it with one hand, holding it with your other hand.
\item Pluck the rubber band with the finger and listen to the sounds you have created.
\item Discuss with your group how you can change the pitch of the sound to make it higher or lower.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Rubber bands
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (With Material, Exercise on pitch, Exercise involving a table)

\begin{enumerate}
\item You will need a rubber band and a small container (e.g., a small matchbox).
\item Stretch a rubber band over a matchbox or other small container.
\item Discuss with your group how you can change the loudness and pitch of the sound made.
\item Record the results in a table.
\item Compare the results with your predictions and try to explain what you observed.
\item Share your results and conclusions with the class.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Rubber bands
\item A small container (e.g., a small matchbox)
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise involving a table, Exercise involving data collection, Exercise on magnets, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Draw a table to record the results of the activity, including columns for the name of the object, material, and whether it is attracted or not by the magnet.
  \item Take a bar magnet and test it on 10 different objects in the classroom and outside. Record the results in the table.
  \item Look at the results:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Come to a conclusion about the materials attracted by the magnet.
    \item Write down your conclusion.
    \item Share it with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Test your idea about magnetic materials on eight more objects in the room:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Write a sentence about the results.
    \item Compare it with your conclusion from the first test.
    \item Do your conclusions agree, or have you changed your mind about which materials are magnetic?
    \item Tell the class what you think.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Sort out the materials into two groups: a magnetic group and a non-magnetic group.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Bar magnets
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration, Exercise on observing steam and condensation)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Look carefully at the spout and see if you can observe the ‘gap’ between the cloud and the spout.
  \item Now look at the cloud.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What do you think it is – gas or liquid?
    \item Tell the class what you think.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Watch carefully as the teacher holds the cold plate with the cloth and puts it into the invisible steam.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What do you observe on the plate?
    \item What do you observe in the bowl?
    \item Try to explain your observations to the class.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Complete the sentences below:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item I saw \_\_\_\_\_\_ of \_\_\_\_\_\_ on the plate. It \_\_\_\_\_\_ down the plate and \_\_\_\_\_\_ off into the bowl.
    \item Water \_\_\_\_\_\_ in the air \_\_\_\_\_\_ down as the \_\_\_\_\_\_ goes higher up.
    \item As it cools, it \_\_\_\_\_\_ into tiny \_\_\_\_\_\_ of water.
    \item We can \_\_\_\_\_\_ the drops of \_\_\_\_\_\_ as \_\_\_\_\_\_ in the sky.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a kettle steaming, with a spout releasing steam into the air. Below the spout, there is a plate that is catching the steam, and a bowl positioned to collect any drips. The environment includes students observing the demonstration. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Partner Activity, Group Discussion, Investigation Exercise, Presentation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise involving data collection, Exercise on habitats)

\begin{itemize}
  \item Discuss with your group which two habitats you will investigate in your locality. Try to choose two that are very different.
  \item Plan what you will look for and how you will record what you observe.
  \item Go outside with your partner and investigate your chosen habitats. Collect information to be able to give a clear and full description of each habitat to the class.
  \item Take care to describe what each habitat is like. For example:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Is it wet?
    \item Is it sandy, rocky, or soil?
    \item Is it in a river or in water?
    \item Are there plants, and are they close together or spread out?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Return to the class.
  \item Present your observations to the class.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on drug types, Exercise involving a list)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Discuss the three groups of drug types. Share your ideas about why some drugs are in one group and not another.
\item Write down examples of each group of drugs.
\item Share your lists and ideas with the class. Add to your lists any extra examples given by your classmates.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Long Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on melting and freezing)

(Science) (Activity, Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on state change, Exercise with liquid wax)

(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration, Exercise on the cooling and freezing, Exercise on freezing methods)

[STRDGM] The image shows a freezer with three drawers. The top drawer contains wrapped items, the middle drawer has pink and white packages, and the bottom drawer is empty. The freezer is organized and clean, illustrating how food is stored at low temperatures. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity) D 1 (Exercise on materials, Activity with material identification)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose four of these materials: wood, metal, plastic, glass, fabric, rubber.
  \item Move around the room.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Find two examples of each material.
    \item Collect them or make a drawing of each one.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Show the class what you have found.
  \item Tell them the names of the materials each object is made of.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (With Material, Exercise involving data collection, Activity on magnetism)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Tie a thread to one of the bar magnets.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Hold the bar magnet on the thread, letting it swing freely.
    \item When it is settled, bring another bar magnet slowly towards it – aiming the north pole of one towards the north pole of the other.
    \item Write a note of what you observe.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Repeat the action using the south poles of both magnets. Write a note of what happens this time.
  \item Now bring the south pole of one magnet slowly towards the north pole of the other. Write a note of what you observe.
  \item Lastly, bring the north pole of one magnet towards the south pole of the other. Record what happens this time.
  \item Share your results with the class.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Bar magnets
  \item Thread
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity) D 2 (Exercise involving a drawing, Exercise involving a class display, Exercise on electrical switches)

\begin{enumerate}
\item If you have electrical items at home, look for the switches on them. Make a simple drawing of each kind of switch you find.
\item Continue this activity in school and add more examples to your collection of drawings.
\item Display your drawings for the class to see and look at the drawings of other pupils.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity) D 4 (Exercise involving a circuit, Exercise involving a drawing)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Rebuild a circuit that lights the lamp.
\item Explore how many ways you can break the circuit and make the lamp go out. Make a simple drawing of each broken circuit.
\item Share your results with the class and explain why each circuit is broken.
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Activity, Fill-in-the-Gaps Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on the three states of water)

Copy and complete the sentences below. Here are the words you will need: liquid, states, gas, water, solid. (You will need to use some words more than once.)
\begin{enumerate}
\item Water is found in three \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item They are called \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_, \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_, and \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item The \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ state is called ice.
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ is the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ state.
\item The \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ state is called water vapour.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Activity, Group Discussion, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on drying, With Material)

Experiment to test the speed of drying pieces of cloth.
\begin{itemize}
\item Discuss with your group how you will test the two pieces of cloth.
\item Predict which piece will dry faster and write down your prediction.
\item Decide how you will measure the dryness of the cloth.
\item Keep a record of what you do, especially the time taken for each drying method.
\item Investigate and discuss the results.
\item Compare the results with your prediction.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*s{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Two pieces of cloth
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Discussion Exercise, Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on change of state)

Investigating a material's changes of state.
\begin{itemize}
\item Choose which material you will investigate: wax, chocolate, butter, or margarine.
\item How will you change the state of your chosen material?
\item Decide what you are going to do.
\item Discuss how you will examine the changes.
\item Share your group's conclusion with the class.
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Data Collection Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the heights of trees, Exercise involving a table)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Look around where you live and guess how high the trees are. Are the trees growing on their own or are they close to other trees? If you do not have any trees close by, look at local plants growing.
  \item Compare the heights of the trees/plants growing on their own with those growing close to each other. Try to compare trees/plants of the same type (species). If the leaves are the same, then the tree/plant will be of the same type.
  \item Copy and complete the table with the sections below in your Investigation Notebook.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Height of trees/plants growing on their own
    \item Height of trees/plants growing close to other trees/plants
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, True-False Exercise, Activity) D 5 (Exercise involving tracking shadow, Exercise on shadows, Exercise involving data collection, With Material, Exercise involving a table, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Take your shadow puppet outside to make shadows or simply use yourself.
  \item Change position during your investigation. Move your arms or legs, try running on the spot or hopping.
  \item Observe how your shadow moves. Does it show exactly like you? Draw around your shadow and check what it looks like at different times throughout the day. Record the time.
  \item Keep a diary of your shadow. Check how long it is and what direction it is facing at different times of the day.
  \item In your Investigation Notebook, record your findings in the table illustrated below.
  \item Write a conclusion about your investigation.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item During the morning my shadow is ...
    \item At midday my shadow is ...
    \item During the afternoon my shadow is ...
  \end{itemize}
  \item Predict what will happen to the shadows.
  \item What do you notice about the length of the shadow?
  \item What do you notice about the direction of the shadow?
  \item You could represent this data over several months.
  \item Decide whether the following statements are true or false.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item The Sun is the only natural source of light. (True/False)
    \item My shadow did not change at all throughout the day. (True/False)
    \item My shadow was at its longest at midday. (True/False)
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A table with columns for "Date," "Time of day," and "Observations and length of shadow." [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A shadow puppet
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Creative Exercise, Group Activity) D 5 (Exercise on shadows, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Working in small groups, plan and write a short shadow puppet show to perform to the rest of the class.
\item In your group, decide who the main characters are in your puppet show.
\item Using the materials provided, make puppets for your main characters. Think back to all the investigations you have carried out. This will help you to decide what size the puppets should be.
\item Practise positioning the puppets in front of the light source.
\item In your group, perform your puppet show to the rest of the class.
\item You can make 3D glasses using a strip of card and blue and red cellophane. These make flat pictures look more real.
\item Mark the card where each eye will be.
\item Cut out a 3 centimetre by 2 centimetre square for each eye.
\item Cover one eye hole with blue cellophane and the other with red. Stick the cellophane in place.
\item When you look at special pictures with your 3D glasses the images will appear to be 3D.
\item Shine a light at the side of your face. Ask a friend to tape some paper to the wall where your shadow appears.
\item Ask them to draw around your shadow on the paper and cut it out. You now have a silhouette of your head.
\item Make this into a shadow puppet and you can be in your play.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows two shadow puppets being used in a performance, with a light source behind them creating distinct shadows on a screen. In another part of the image, a child is interacting with the shadows, showcasing the fun of shadow play. [STPDGM]

(Science) (Question, Investigation Exercise, Partner Activity) D 2 (Exercise on light and dark activities, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item What can you see in a dark room?
  \item Write down three artificial sources of light that might help you to see well.
  \item Investigation: Do we need light to move around safely?
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Tie a blindfold over your eyes and try to move around the room.
    \item Ask your partner to help you to stop bumping into things.
    \item Describe how this felt.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Investigation: Does seeing help us to hear better?
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Take it in turns to wear a blindfold. Then stay still and quiet.
    \item Think about all the sounds you can hear.
    \item Take off the blindfold. What can you hear now?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Investigation: Is all light the same?
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Try to read this page in the dark.
    \item Then use candlelight.
    \item Now try it with a torch.
    \item What did you find? When was it easier to read the page?
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A blindfold
  \item A candle
  \item A torch
\end{itemize}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Add some water to your beakers so they are all half full.
\item Predict whether the materials will dissolve or not.
\item Add a spoonful of the first material to your first beaker. Stir.
\item What happens? Was your prediction right?
\item Which substances dissolved? Which substances did not dissolve?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Water
\item A range of soluble and insoluble materials
\item Beakers
\item Spoons
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] The image shows four containers: the first has blue liquid with a blue powder at the bottom, the second has a clear liquid with a blue powder that has dissolved, the third has a brown powder that has not dissolved in a clear liquid, and the fourth has a clear liquid with a white powder that has dissolved. [STPDGM]


(Science) (True-False Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on dissolving materials in water)

Circle the correct answer.
\begin{enumerate}
\item When a material spreads out in water we say it has dissolved. True / False
\item Only some materials will dissolve in water. True / False
\item Sand dissolves in water. True / False
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question Exercise, Group Activity) D 5 (Exercise on growing and shrinking shadows, Exercise involving a table, Exercise involving data collection, With Material, With Illustration)

In groups, carry out an investigation to explore if your prediction is true.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Using a torch as your light source, place it 2 meters away from a screen or wall and fix it in place so it does not move.
\item Choose an opaque object that is easy to move. You will need to measure this object, so choose something that has a simple shape, such as a building block.
\item Place the object 10 centimetres in front of the light source and measure the length of its shadow.
\item Now measure the size of the shadow from the same object at 20 centimetres, 30 centimetres, 40 centimetres, and 50 centimetres away from the light source.
\item In your Investigation Notebook, record your results in a table.
\item What do you notice about your results? Can you see a pattern?
\item Was your prediction at the start of the investigation correct?
\item Which variables were kept the same in the investigation to make sure it was a fair test?
\item Why does the shadow of an object get bigger as the object is moved closer to the light?
\item How can you collect reliable data?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The diagram shows how light travels from a light source to create shadows. It illustrates a near object casting a larger shadow and a distant object casting a smaller shadow, with arrows indicating the path of light. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A torch
\item An opaque object
\item Measuring tape
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item Stamen
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Descriptive Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the life cycle of a flowering plant, Exercise on fertilisation)

Describe how fertilisation happens in the flowering plant.


(Science) (Question, Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the life cycle of a flowering plant, With Answer, Exercise on flower anatomy)

What is the female part of the flower called?

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item Carpel
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on the life cycle of a flowering plant)

Complete the paragraph.

The life of a flowering plant begins with \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ dispersal. It then \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ and grows into an adult plant. Later, it is then pollinated by \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_. After a new seed is produced.

\item Breathing

\end{itemize}


(Science) (True-False Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on muscles and skeletons, Exercise on joints)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Muscles are attached to bones.
\item Bones can move on their own.
\item Elbows and knees are examples of joints.
\item We use our jaw muscles for talking.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Look at the photograph. How is the man changing the shape of the clay?
\item Look at the photograph. How is the woman changing the shape of the steel?
\item Do you think it is easier to change the shape of the clay or the steel?
\item When have you changed the shape of something? Look at the pictures for clues.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a man shaping clay on a potter's wheel, with his hands actively molding the material. Another image features a woman working with steel, likely using tools to manipulate the metal. Both individuals are engaged in the process of changing the shape of their respective materials. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on plant growth, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item How do we know that seeds do not need light to germinate?
\item The four stages of a scientific investigation are prediction, question, investigation and observation. Put these stages in order from the beginning to the end of the scientific enquiry process.
\item If we are investigating the effect of light on plant growth, what variables do we need to keep the same in order to make the test fair?
\item In this unit we learned how to record our findings in the form of a graph. Graphs make it easier for us to interpret our findings and draw conclusions. What kind of graph shows us how things change over time?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a large tree on the right side, with a pine cone and scattered seeds at the bottom left. The background is light green, and there are sections with questions and statements about plant growth and scientific investigation. [STPDGM]

\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Investigation, Activity) D 2 (Exercise on changing the shapes of materials, With Material, Exercise in British English)

\paragraph{Investigation} Making a paper picture
\begin{itemize}
\item Draw a picture in pencil on a large piece of card.
\item Take some pieces of coloured tissue paper and scrunch them up into balls.
\item Stick the coloured balls to your picture.
\item How did you change the shape of the paper?
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Pencils
\item Card
\item Coloured tissue paper
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation, Activity) D 2 (Exercise on changing the shapes of materials, With Illustration)

\paragraph{Investigation} Stretching materials
\begin{itemize}
\item Measure your material.
\item Fix your material to the holder.
\item Hang the weights from it with a paper clip.
\item Measure how far the material has stretched.
\item In your Investigation Notebook, record how many centimetres your material stretched.
\item Which material stretched the most?
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] The image shows a ruler attached to a holder with weights hanging from a material being tested for stretching. The setup is designed to measure how far the material stretches when weights are applied. [STPDGM]

\end{itemize}

\paragraph{Investigation} Cooling water
\begin{itemize}
\item Fill your plastic containers with water.
\item Put the containers into a freezer.
\item Look at your containers carefully when you have them back.
\item What do you see and feel?
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on heating materials, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Heating ice
\begin{itemize}
\item Break some of your ice into big pieces. Break the rest up into small pieces.
\item Put half of your big pieces and half of your small pieces in a warm place. Put the rest in a cool place.
\item Look at your ice samples every ten minutes. What do you see?
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Ice
\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

What happens when an object blocks light?

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item A shadow is formed.
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on materials, Activity on opacity and transparency)

You are going to investigate some materials to find out if they are opaque, transparent or translucent.
\begin{itemize}
\item Choose different materials to test and compare.
\item Before looking at the objects, predict whether each type of material is opaque, transparent or translucent.
\item Predict what will happen each time you try to cast a shadow using a transparent, translucent and opaque material.
\item Set up your equipment.
\item Investigate which materials do as shadows.
\item Record your results in your Investigation Notebook.
\item Compare your predictions with your results.
\item How accurate were your predictions?
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Question Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on scientific enquiry, With Answer)

What do you keep the same in an investigation?

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item Control variables
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Question Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on scientific enquiry, With Answer)

What do you change in an investigation?

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item Independent variables
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Question Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on scientific enquiry, With Answer, Exercise on dependent variables)

What do you call the thing you are measuring?

\subsection*{Answer}
\begin{itemize}
\item Dependent variable
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question, Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on mirrors, With Illustration, Exercise involving diagrams, Exercise involving drawing, Activity on light reflection)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Set up the investigation so that you can draw a ray diagram of your ray of light reflecting off the mirror. This time, draw a line to show where the mirror is.
\item Draw three different ray diagrams by moving your ray box. Make sure you know which ray is which. Use a different colour for each one.
\item Take one ray diagram and draw a line at 90 degrees (a right angle) to the mirror. This is called the normal line.
\item Label the angle of incidence, angle of reflection, incident ray and reflected ray on one of your ray diagrams.
\item Measure the angle between the angle of incidence and the normal line. What is it?
\item Measure the angle between the angle of reflection and the normal line. What is it?
\item Measure the angle of incidence and the angle of reflection for your other two ray diagrams. What do your results show?
\item The ray from the torch to the mirror is called the …
\item The ray from the mirror to the wall is called the …
\item When light hits a mirror, what is the angle called?
\item When light bounces off a mirror, what is the angle called?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a diagram illustrating the angles involved in light reflection: the incident ray approaches the mirror, the normal line is perpendicular to the mirror surface, and the reflected ray exits at an angle equal to the angle of incidence. [STPDGM]

(Science) (Multiple Choice Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on magnetism)

Circle the correct word.
\begin{enumerate}
  \item North and facing South end
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item The magnets moved apart / together.
    \item Opposite ends of the magnets attract / repel each other.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item North and facing North end
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item The magnets moved apart / together.
    \item The North ends of the magnets attract / repel each other.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item South and facing South end
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item The South ends of the magnets attract / repel each other.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item North and above North end and South and above South end
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item The magnets pulled together / pushed apart.
    \item Opposite ends of the magnets attract / repel each other.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\item are there particles inside metals millions of.
\item and North has each particle.
\item North-South in a all the particles are aligned magnetic metal.
\item attract magnet of a poles opposite
\item poles of a magnet repel like.
\end{enumerate}

\item True
\item True
\item False
\item True
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Activity, Question Exercise, Creative Activity) D 5 (Exercise on colour, Exercise in British English, With Material, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Take a circular piece of card and divide it into eight sections. Colour each section a different colour.
\item Push a stick or pencil through the centre of the circle.
\item Spin the stick. What do you see?
\item Explain why a leaf appears green.
\item Why do some objects appear to be white?
\item Why do some objects appear to be black?
\item Earlier you talked about your favourite colour. Explain how you can see this colour.
\item What colours make white light?
\item Explain why a red T-shirt appears red.
\item Why does a blue top look blue in daylight but look grey when it is getting dark?
\end{enumerate}

There is a stick or pencil pushed through the centre of the circle, indicating it can be spun. The background features a shadow puppet theatre with silhouettes of animals, illustrating the concept of light and colour. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Card
\item Colour pencils
\item Stick or pencil
\end{itemize}

\paragraph{Investigation} Using forces to change the shape of modelling clay
\begin{enumerate}
\item Use a wooden or plastic hammer and gently see what shape you can make out of a lump of clay.
\item Use your hands to make a pot out of a lump of clay.
\item Use your hands to push and pull the clay to make a flat pizza shape.
\item Draw ‘before’ and ‘after’ pictures of each of your models in your Investigation notebook.
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Investigation, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on forces, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Using forces to make a toy change speed or stop
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Gently push a toy car along a smooth, flat surface such as the classroom floor.
  \item Measure how far the car travels before it stops.
  \item Record the distance in the space below.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item My car traveled \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ cm.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Did the car go quickly or slowly?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Toy car
  \item Measuring tape
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on forces, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Changing the speed and direction of a toy car
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Push the car as hard as you can along the classroom floor. Make sure nobody is in front of the car.
  \item Observe the car traveling.
  \item Measure how far the car goes.
  \item Tick the sentence that is correct.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item The more force there is, the faster the car goes.
    \item The less force there is, the faster the car goes.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Toy car
  \item Measuring tape
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on forces, With Material, With Illustration)

\paragraph{Investigation} How do things move on different surfaces?
\begin{enumerate}
\item Make a ramp out of cardboard, using furniture or a piece of wood.
\item Hold your car at the top of the ramp and let go.
\item Put the ramp on surfaces made of different materials, such as soil, concrete and carpet. Measure how far the car travels on each surface.
\item Draw and complete the table in your Investigation notebook. Include (i) type of surface, (ii) distance traveled (cm), and (iii) observations in your table.
\item Which surface made the car travel the fastest?
\item Which surface made the car travel the furthest?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a classroom setting with two children interacting with a toy car. One child is pushing the car while the other observes. The background includes a table and chairs, emphasizing a learning environment. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Toy car
\item Cardboard, furniture or a piece of wood for making a ramp
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Class Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on sound)

Predict what will happen to a sound when you get further away from it.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Go outside into a big open space.
\item One person stands in the center with their eyes closed. They are the Listener.
\item Stand in a circle around the Listener.
\item Tiptoe very quietly towards the Listener. The Listener listens very carefully.
\item If they hear a sound they turn around quickly. If they see you moving you are out. See who gets to the center first.
\item Measure how far away you are when the Listener hears you.
\item Were some of you quieter than others? Why?
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Investigation, Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise, Partner Activity) D 1 (Exercise on moving things, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Investigation: Make a paper windmill
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Work with a partner and help each other.
    \item Take each corner and overlap them at the center hole.
    \item Hold all the corners in place with the paper fastener.
    \item Wrap the ends of the paper fastener around the end.
    \item Put some tape over the ends. Blow your windmill.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Complete the sentences to describe how your windmill moves.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item When I blow hard, the windmill moves \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
    \item When I blow softly, the windmill moves \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
    \item The windmill \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ round and round, but it doesn’t move another \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Paper
  \item Paper fasteners
  \item Tape
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Question Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on shadows and light)

How are shadows formed?


(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on shadows and light)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Look around the room. Find five small objects.
  \item How would you investigate the five objects to find out if they make shadows? Plan an investigation to test your objects. Think about:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item what equipment you will need
    \item what you will use as a source of light
    \item how you will know which is a good shadow and which is not
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Write down what you find out about the size of the shadow as you move the light source nearer to the object.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (True-False Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on shadows and light, With Illustration)

Decide whether the following statements are true or false.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Light travels in straight lines.
\item When light hits a transparent material it passes through.
\item When light hits an opaque material it can pass through.
\item Shadows are formed when light passes through a transparent material.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a beach scene with palm tree shadows on the sand, illustrating how shadows are formed when light is blocked. [STPDGM]

[STRDGM] The image shows a steam turbine, a kettle boiling water, and pipes filled with steam. The steam turbine is a large machine with blades that spin, demonstrating the power of steam. The kettle is emitting steam, indicating that water is boiling. The pipes are full of steam, showing how it travels. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Activity, Question Exercise, Partner Activity) D 4 (Exercise on steam, Exercise involving the teacher)

Your teacher will demonstrate how to measure the temperature of steam. Your teacher will hold the thermometer in the steam. Water boils at 100°C.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Why do you think the temperature of the steam is not exactly 100°C?
\item Think about what you might think happens if steam is trapped in a container. Discuss your ideas with a partner.
\item Where do you think the steam goes? When water is warmed, it changes to water vapor. This is a change of state from liquid to gas.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Question, Short Answer Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on steam, Exercise on the state changes)

(Science) (Discussion Exercise, Question) D 4 (Exercise on steam)

(Science) (Partner Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on touch, Activity on feeling objects)

\paragraph{Investigation} feeling objects
\begin{enumerate}
\item Work in pairs. Blindfold your partner and have them feel different objects. Can they identify what they are?
\item Explore how your partner can identify, if the objects are warm, cold, rough, or smooth.
\item Put your hand in cold water while your partner puts their hand in warm water. Describe what you feel.
\end{enumerate}

\item I like to eat \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on reflection, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Use your torch to investigate objects around the room. Shine the light from the torch on different objects. Write down which objects bounce the light back.
  \item Look at the results from your torch investigation. Group the objects into good reflectors and poor reflectors. In your Investigation Notebook, complete a table containing the following:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Good reflectors
    \item Poor reflectors
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Choose the object that you think is the best reflector out of the ones you tested. What kind of material is it? Describe the properties of the material. Would you describe the material as shiny or dull?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Torch
  \item A variety of good and poor reflectors
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\item Work with a partner.
\item Make the toy car move towards you.
\item How will you move the toy car towards you?
\item How will you move the toy car away from you?
\item Do you need to push or pull the toy car to make it move?
\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

(Science) (Creative Activity, Activity) D 1 (Exercise on making things go faster or slower, With Material)

Make a balloon toy car.
\begin{itemize}
\item Fix a balloon to the toy car.
\item Put the straw in the balloon.
\item Hold the end of the straw between your fingers.
\item Carefully blow up the balloon.
\item When you let go the air from the balloon pushes the toy car forward.
\item Can you make the wheels move?
\item What force moves the toy car?
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question) D 3 (Exercise on sight, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Is seeing with two eyes better than one?
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hold a pencil in each hand and stretch your arms out.
\item Close your left eye and point to a word.
\item Now close your right eye and try to make the pencils meet.
\item What happens? Is it easier to make the pencils meet?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Pencils
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Partner Activity, Investigation, Question Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sight, With Illustration, With Material, Activity on depth perception)

\paragraph{Investigation} Is seeing with two eyes better than one?
\begin{enumerate}
\item Sit your partner at a desk with a paper cup on the desk about an arm's length away from them.
\item Ask your partner to close their left eye.
\item Hold a paperclip in your hand. Move the paperclip slowly over the cup and your partner's length above it.
\item Your partner should drop it when they think the paperclip will fall directly into the cup.
\item Repeat with both eyes open.
\item Swap roles and repeat the investigation.
\item Does using two eyes make it easier to get the paperclip into the cup? Did it make it easier for everyone?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows two children at a desk, one holding a pencil and the other with a paper cup, illustrating the activity of testing depth perception. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Paper cups
\item Paperclips
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sight)

\paragraph{Investigation} Reading with one eye closed
\begin{enumerate}
\item Close your left eye and point to a word.
\item Open your left eye and close your right eye.
\item Now look at the word with both eyes.
\item What have you discovered in your investigations? Is it better to have one eye or two?
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sight, With Illustration, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} The blind spot
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hold the card in front of you. Close your right eye.
\item Stare at the X with your left eye. Slowly move the card closer to your face.
\item Keep looking at the X with your left eye.
\item Repeat this test with the other eye. This time, move the card closer until the X disappears. You have found your blind spot.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image features a child holding a card with a cross and an X, demonstrating the blind spot test. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Card
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question) D 3 (Exercise on sight, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Brain tricks
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hold the card in front of you in a horizontal position.
\item Close your left eye.
\item Stare at the cross and move the card closer to your face.
\item What happens to the space in the middle of the lines?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Card
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on forces and motion, Exercise involving drawing)

\paragraph{Investigation} What slows things down?
\begin{enumerate}
\item Put your hands palm down on a surface and press down.
\item Move your hand across the desk. What do you feel?
\item Did you feel a dragging feeling?
\item How could you investigate this? Think of an investigation you could do to test which shoe has the best grip.
\item Draw or write a picture explaining what you would do in your Investigation notebook.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Question, Short Answer Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on forces and motion, With Illustration, With Answer)

Do you have brakes on your bike? What do they do?

[STRDGM] The image shows a child riding a bike. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item Brakes use friction to stop things quickly. When you press the brake lever on the bike, the brake blocks squeeze together, stopping the bike wheel from moving.
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] The image features children playing with balls and toy cars, illustrating the concept of forces in motion. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Partner Activity, Investigation, Question) D 3 (Exercise on forces, Exercise involving a table, With Material, Exercise involving data collection)

\paragraph{Investigation} What happens when a moving object hits another object?
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Sit on the floor in front of a wall or door. Carefully roll the ball towards the wall. What happens?
  \item With a partner, both roll balls towards each other so the balls hit. What happens?
  \item Try this with toy cars. What happens?
  \item Write what you found out in a table containing the following sections:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Ball rolled to a wall
    \item Two balls rolled towards each other
    \item Two toy cars pushed towards each other
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Balls
\item Toy cars
\end{itemize}

(Science) (True-False Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on forces, With Answer)

A pulling or pushing force makes things stop. True / False

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item True
\end{itemize}


(Science) (True-False Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on forces, With Answer)

Friction is a slowing down force. True / False

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item True
\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Answers}

\end{itemize}


(Science) (Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sound, Exercise involving a table, Exercise involving data collection)

\paragraph{Investigation} Guessing sounds
\begin{enumerate}
\item Collect some objects that make a sound.
\item Ask your partner to stand with their back to you.
\item Pick up one of the objects and make a sound with it.
\item Record whether your partner recognised the sound in a table.
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Class Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sound, With Illustration)

\paragraph{Investigation} Direction of sounds
\begin{enumerate}
\item One person sits on the floor with their eyes tightly closed.
\item The rest of the class sit in a circle around them.
\item One student in the circle says: “The person in the centre has to point to the voice they can find and say who said it.”
\item They try again. First they cover one ear. Then they cup their hands behind their ears.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a classroom setting where students are engaged in sound-related experiments. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Group Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on sound, With Illustration, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Hearing and ear size
\begin{enumerate}
\item In groups make a funnel with a piece of card or paper.
\item Make more funnels in different sizes.
\item Choose something that makes a sound. Use this sound for all your tests.
\item Stand at the same distance from the sound.
\item Test all the funnels by putting them against your ear. Listen carefully with your ears shut.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image illustrates a person using a funnel to amplify sound. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Pieces of card or paper
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question Exercise) D 1 (Exercise on movement)

\paragraph{Investigation} What happens when you swing your arms?
\begin{enumerate}
\item Try walking and swinging your arms at the same time.
\item Can you swing your arms faster?
\item Predict what happens to the speed you walk when your arms slow down.
\item What force makes your arms move forward?
\item What force makes your arms move backward?
\item Can you guess what will happen if you hold up a pencil?
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Question Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on predators and prey, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Look at the picture of the cheetah. Answer the questions about this predator.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Why do you think the cheetah has long legs and a flexible spine?
    \item Why do you think the cheetah has a long, flat tail?
    \item Why do you think the cheetah has ridges on its paws and its claws are always out?
    \item Why do you think the cheetah has a small, aerodynamic head and lightweight body?
    \item Why do you think the cheetah has spots on its coat?
    \item What senses do you think the cheetah uses when hunting for prey?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Look at the picture of the gazelle. The gazelle can be found in Africa and Asia. It can run fast. Gazelles mainly eat green plants. They are hunted by lions, leopards, cheetahs and hyenas. Answer the questions about this prey.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Why do you think the gazelle has horns?
    \item Why do you think the gazelle can run fast?
    \item Why do you think the eyes of the gazelle are on the side of its head?
    \item Why do you think the gazelle has a coat of browns and white?
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a cheetah with labeled body parts: coat, spine, tail, teeth, legs, and claws. The cheetah is depicted in a running position, showcasing its long legs and aerodynamic form. Below, an image shows a gazelle, labeled with parts: horns, eyes, and coat colors. The gazelle is shown in a standing position, emphasizing its agility.[STPDGM]

(Science) (Investigation, Group Activity, Drawing Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on the tongue, Exercise in British English, Exercise involving drawing, With Material, With Illustration)

\paragraph{Investigation} Which parts of the tongue have the most taste buds?
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Put a lollipop stick in the cup of flavoured water.
  \item Place it on different parts of your tongue:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item The tip
    \item The sides
    \item Under your tongue
  \end{itemize}
  \item Draw and colour the tongue to show where you tasted the flavour the most.
  \item Compare your tongue map with your group.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Does it look the same or does it look different?
    \item Which parts of your tongue tasted the flavour the most?
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A lollipop stick
\item Cup of flavoured water
\item Paper
\item Colouring pencils
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] The image shows a close-up of a human tongue with a lollipop stick placed on it, indicating the areas where taste is being tested. The background is light and colorful, emphasizing the focus on taste and the tongue's surface. [STPDGM]


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Partner Activity) D 3 (Exercise on food groups, Exercise involving the teacher, Exercise involving a table)

\paragraph{Investigation} Sorting food into groups.

Your teacher will give you some different foods. Work with a partner to sort the foods into the different food groups in a table.


(Science) (Investigation, Activity) D 3 (With Material, Exercise on the tongue)

\paragraph{Investigation} Does saliva help you taste?
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Stick out your tongue to dry it.
  \item Put a few grains of salt on your tongue. What can you taste?
  \item Rinse your mouth. Dry your tongue again and place some sugar granules on your tongue. What can you taste?
  \item Wait a few minutes until you have saliva. Now place salt on your tongue. Rinse your mouth and then place sugar on your tongue. What can you taste this time?
  \item Complete the sentence.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item With a dry tongue I could / could not taste the sugar and salt as well as I could with a wet tongue.
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Salt
  \item Sugar
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Class Activity) D 3 (Exercise on smell, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Recognising smells
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Make a smell box. Take a small clean container like a yogurt pot.
  \item Choose something that has a strong smell. Place it in the container.
  \item Complete a table in your Investigation notebook with the following sections:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Smelly object
    \item Name of student
    \item Did they recognise the smell correctly?
    \item How long did it take them?
  \end{itemize}
  \item How many students guessed the smell?
  \item How many students did not guess the smell?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item A small container like a yogurt box
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Partner Activity, Class Discussion) D 3 (Exercise on smell)

\paragraph{Investigation} How does smell travel?
\begin{itemize}
\item Sit very still. Someone will spray something in the room.
\item Put your hand up when you can smell the spray.
\item Work with a partner to investigate how far the spray can be smelled.
\item What is the furthest distance that you could smell the spray?
\item Compare and discuss your results with the rest of the class.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Partner Activity) D 3 (Exercise on smell)

\paragraph{Investigation} Do we smell when we taste things?
\begin{itemize}
\item Hold your nose or put a peg on it.
\item Now eat a slice of orange.
\item Then eat a slice of orange without holding your nose.
\item What did you notice? Compare what you found with your partner.
\item Did they notice the same thing?
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Matching Exercise, Activity) D 3 (Exercise on smell, Exercise with a word bank)

Match up the words in the word bank with their meanings below.
\begin{itemize}
\item a nice smell
\item part of the face which we use to smell
\item small cells in the nostrils
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Word Bank}
\begin{itemize}
\item Nostril
\item Receptors
\item Perfume
\end{itemize}

(Science) (True-False Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on identification keys)

True or false?
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item We can use identification keys to help us name unfamiliar creatures. True / False
\item Identification keys can be simple or complex. True / False
\item We can only use identification keys to identify plants. True / False
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on circuits, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Can you predict what will happen to a circuit if you add more bulbs?
\item What will happen if you increase the number of batteries?
\item What will happen if you increase the length of the wires?
\item Are you going to change the number of batteries in your circuit?
\item Are you going to change the length of the wire in your circuit?
\item What are you going to measure?
\item Are you going to change the number of bulbs?
\item What will you keep the same in your investigation to make it a fair test?
\item How many different ways can you investigate wiring three bulbs into a circuit?
\item How will you record your results?
\item Record the change you made. Write down what happened to your circuit.
\item Can you write a conclusion from your results?
\item How did you make sure you carried out a fair test? What did you do?
\item What will happen to the brightness of a bulb if the wire is thicker?
\item What will happen to the brightness of a bulb if the wire is shorter?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a child working on a circuit board with various components like wires and bulbs. The child is focused on connecting parts of the circuit, illustrating a hands-on approach to learning about electrical circuits. [STPDGM]

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question, Fill-in-the-Blanks Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on magnetism, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Use a bar magnet to test objects.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item If an object is attracted towards the magnet, the object is made of a magnetic material.
    \item If an object is not attracted towards the magnet, the object is made of a non-magnetic material.
  \end{itemize}
  \item Push the magnets together with the South seeking poles facing each other.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item What do you feel?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Push the magnets together with a south-seeking pole facing a north-seeking pole.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item What do you feel?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Slowly push two magnets together with the North seeking poles facing each other.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item What do you feel?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Fill in the missing words. One has been done for you.
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Some objects \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ other objects to them. They are called A \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ has two ends, one end of the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ is the North seeking pole and the other end is the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ seeking pole. The law of magnetism is: Like poles \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ and opposite poles attract.
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image shows a bar magnet with its North and South poles labeled, alongside various objects being tested for magnetism, such as a pencil, wood, and metal items. There are also images of a compass and a train, illustrating the use of magnets in different contexts. [STPDGM]

  \item What do you think happens to a tree when it doesn't have enough water?
  \item A tree has a very thick stem. What is it called?
  \item Measure the height of the tree and its roots with a ruler and write it in the box. Then measure the width of the roots and write it in the box. What do you notice?

(Science) (Investigation, Question Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on friction and air resistance, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Investigate air resistance with paper.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Drop a piece of flat paper and observe how quickly it travels to the ground.
\item What forces are acting on the paper?
\item Now crumple the paper into a ball. What do you observe when you drop the scrunched paper?
\item Answer these questions about your investigation:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What did you notice about the time it takes for both pieces of paper to fall?
    \item Do they take the same amount of time to fall?
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Paper
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Question Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on electrical conductors and insulators, With Answer, With Illustration)

Can you make electricity with your hair or your clothes?

[STRDGM] The image shows a dramatic night scene with lightning striking over a city skyline. The sky is dark with flashes of bright light illuminating the buildings below. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item When you comb your hair, or rub a piece of plastic on your clothes, a small amount of electricity is made. The electricity does not move anywhere. We call it static electricity.
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question) D 6 (Exercise on electrical conductors and insulators, With Material, Activity on static electricity)

\paragraph{Investigation} How can you investigate static electricity?
\begin{enumerate}
\item Try combing your hair, or rub a piece of plastic on your clothes. Then hold the comb or plastic near small pieces of paper. What happens to the pieces of paper?
\item Now move the comb or plastic over other small objects.
\item What can you see?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A comb or a piece of plastic
\item A piece of paper
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on circuits, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Making a switch
\begin{itemize}
\item You can make a switch. You will need a small piece of cardboard, two brass paper fasteners and a paperclip.
\item Construct a simple circuit with a battery, wires and a lamp.
\item Connect the wires to the lamp.
\item What do you notice about the lamp when the switch is closed?
\item We can make a switch from any material that allows electricity to flow. Try using a nail, a coin or other metals.
\item Which material worked the best?
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A small piece of cardboard
\item Two brass paper fasteners
\item A paperclip
\item A battery
\item Wires
\item A lamp
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\item When there is a break in the circuit the components will work / will not work.
\item When the switch is open, the electricity can / cannot flow.
\item When the switch is closed, the electricity can / cannot flow. This means the buzzer will work / will not work.
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Question Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on soil, Exercise on drainage)

\paragraph{Investigation} How well does your soil drain?
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Add a small amount of cotton wool to the bottom of a filter funnel.
  \item Put five spoonfuls of soil into the funnel.
  \item Place the funnel into the top of a jar.
  \item Slowly pour water into the soil.
  \item Answer the following questions:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Which soil will get muddy after heavy rain?
    \item Which soil will be too dry to grow crops?
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

Seeds that are dispersed by animals may have parts that \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ to the animal’s fur or may have fruits that the animals \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_. Seeds that are dispersed by explosions usually have the seed pod and are then carried by the wind.

(Science) (Question, Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Earth's movements)

(Science) (Question, Short Answer Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Earth's movements, Exercise on Earth's orbit)
