(Science) (Partner Activity) D 5 (Exercise on Earth's movements, With Material)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Working in pairs, ask your partner to stand very still in a space holding a lit torch. They are the Sun.
\item Stand opposite your partner and practice spinning on your axis in an anticlockwise direction. You are the Earth.
\item Now try to orbit the Sun in an anticlockwise direction at the same time as spinning anticlockwise on your axis. You are modeling how the Earth gives us a day as you spin and a year as you orbit.
\item Take turns to be the Sun and the Earth.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Torch
\end{itemize}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on building materials, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Making bricks
\begin{enumerate}
\item Take some clay and squash it in your hands until it feels nice and soft.
\item Press the clay with your hands until it is the shape of a brick.
\item Leave the clay to dry. It will make a hard brick.
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Partner Activity, Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on shadows and Sun movement)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Hold a torch very close to your partner’s hand.
\item Ask your partner to form a shadow with their hands.
\item Look carefully at the shadow. How long is it?
\item Now move the torch further away from your partner’s hand.
\item What happens to the length of the shadow?
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise, Partner Activity) D 2 (Exercise on shadows and Sun movement)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Choose somewhere to stand. Stand with your back to the Sun.
\item Ask your partner to measure the length of your shadow.
\item Look at your shadow. Is it long and thin or short and fat?
\item Measure your shadow again at midday, and later in the afternoon.
\item Is there a pattern in your results?
\item How does your investigation prove that the Sun is at its highest at midday?
\end{enumerate}


(Science) (True-False Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on shadows and Sun movement)

Circle the correct answer.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The Sun moves across the sky. True / False
\item At midday the Sun is low in the sky. True / False
\item When the Sun is high in the sky a shadow is short. True / False
\item Shadows change during the day. True / False
\end{enumerate}

(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on the weather and water in hot countries, With Material, Exercise on cleaning groundwater)

\paragraph{Investigation} Cleaning groundwater
\begin{enumerate}
\item Take a piece of cloth and muddy water.
\item Stretch a piece of cloth over a bowl.
\item Pour the muddy water through the cloth.
\item What has happened to the water?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A piece of cloth
\item Muddy water
\item A bowl
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on the weather and water in hot countries, With Material)

\paragraph{Investigation} Cleaning sea water
\begin{enumerate}
\item Fill a glass dish with salty water.
\item Put it in the Sun and wait for the water to disappear.
\item Look carefully at the dish. What do you see?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A glass dish
\item Salty water
\end{itemize}


(Science) (Investigation Exercise) D 2 (Exercise on the weather and water in hot countries, With Material)

\subsection{Investigation: Capturing drinking water from salt water}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Put some salt diluted in water in a bowl. Mark how high the water is.
\item Cover it with a piece of glass and put it in the Sun.
\item Has the water disappeared?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item Salt diluted in water
\item A bowl
\item A piece of glass
\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

(Mathematics) (Calculation Verification Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

Use diagrams or fraction strips to help you check each calculation. Tick the correct answers. If the calculation is incorrect, correct it.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \[ \frac{1}{4} + \frac{3}{4} = \frac{5}{4} \]
\item \[ \frac{2}{5} - \frac{2}{10} = \frac{1}{5} \]
\item \[ \frac{32}{4} + \frac{-12}{2} = 2\]
\item \[ \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{7}{2} = \frac{11}{4} \]
\item \[ \frac{2}{3} \frac{5}{6} = \frac{5}{9} \]
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \ding{55}, \( \frac{1}{4} + \frac{3}{4} = 1 \)
\item \checkmark
\item \checkmark
\item \ding{55}, \( \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{7}{2} = \frac{21}{8} \)
\item \checkmark
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Calculation Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 M

Emma and Astrid are trying to calculate \[ 9 \times 2 \]. Who chose the better method?  

\subsection*{Emma's method}
\begin{equation*}
   9 \times 2 = 18  
\end{equation*}

\subsection*{Astrid's method}
\begin{equation*}
   9 \times 2 = 5
\end{equation*}

\item \( \frac{2}{5} \) of \$32 or \( \frac{3}{4} \) of \$27?
\item \( \frac{1}{10} \) or \( \frac{2}{3} \) of a pizza?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Fraction Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on Completing Inequalities)

Use the fractions \( \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{1}{4} \) to help complete the inequalities.

\begin{gather*}
\_\_\_ > \_\_\_ \\
\_\_\_ > \frac{2}{5}
\end{gather*}


(Mathematics) (True or False Statements, Fraction Exercise) D 3 M

Each statement true or false? Draw a ring around the correct answer.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( \frac{3}{4} \) is less than \( \frac{5}{10} \).
\item \( \frac{2}{4} \) is equal to \( \frac{1}{2} \).
\item \( \frac{4}{10} \) is greater than \( \frac{2}{5} \).
\item \( \frac{1}{2} \) is equal to \( \frac{5}{10} \).
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Fractions Exercise) D 3 M

Which fraction lies between \( \frac{2}{3} \) and \( \frac{7}{10} \) on a number line?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( \frac{4}{7} \)
\item \( \frac{6}{8} \)
\item \( \frac{4}{6} \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Complete the Statement, Fraction Exercise) D 3 M

Use \(<\), \(>\), or \(=\) to complete each statement.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( \frac{2}{6} \) \_\_\_ \( \frac{1}{3} \) of 18
\item \( \frac{3}{4} \) \_\_\_ \( \frac{1}{2} \) of 32
\item \( \frac{3}{5} \) \_\_\_ \( \frac{2}{5} \) of 60
\item \( \frac{2}{3} \) \_\_\_ \( \frac{2}{6} \) of 30
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Fraction Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on finding equivalent fractions)

Find three fractions that are equivalent to \( \frac{1}{3} \).


(Mathematics) (Temporal Exercises) D 3 (Exercise that uses a timetable)

\begin{table}[]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Transport} & \textbf{Departure} & \textbf{Arrival} \\ \hline
Train              & 12:06 PM           & 4:23 AM          \\ \hline
Bus                & 7:39 AM            & 1:42 AM          \\ \hline
\end{tabular}

\end{table}

\begin{enumerate}
\item How long does the bus take?
\item What time does the bus leave?
\item How long does the train take?
\item What time does the train leave?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Temporal Exercise) D 3 M

\begin{table}[]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|ccc|}
\hline
\multicolumn{3}{|c|}{\textbf{Train Timetable}}                              \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{\textbf{Destination}} & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{\textbf{Departure}} & \multicolumn{1}{l|}{\textbf{Arrival}} \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Porto Santo} & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{12:34 AM} & 4:22 AM \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Madrid}      & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{7:39 AM}  & 2:50 PM \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{São Paulo}   & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{3:00 AM}  & 6:25PM  \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Vilnius}     & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{2:46 PM}  & 3:51 AM \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Ouagadougou} & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{1:47 PM}  & 1:45 PM \\ \hline
\end{tabular}

\end{table}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Which is the longer journey for the train service?
\item What time does the train arrive at the destination?
\item How long is the journey from Goldham to the destination?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Temporal Exercise) D 3 (Exercise that uses timetables but doesn't require calculation)

\begin{table}[]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|cccc|}
\hline
\multicolumn{4}{|c|}{\textbf{Train Timetable}}                                                            \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{\textbf{Transport}} & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{\textbf{Departure}} & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{\textbf{Arrival}} & \textbf{Duration} \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Train}    & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{12:50 PM} & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{1:50 PM} & 1h        \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Ferry}    & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{8:00 AM}  & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{3:00 PM} & 7h        \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Airplane} & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{3:00 AM}  & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{6:25 PM} & 15h 25min \\ \hline
\multicolumn{1}{|c|}{Bus}      & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{2:00 PM}  & \multicolumn{1}{c|}{1:00 AM} & 11h       \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\begin{enumerate}
\item How long does the bus take from the station?
\item What time does the bus leave the station?
\item How long does the train take from the station?
\end{enumerate}

\item \( \frac{9}{12} \)
\end{enumerate}

What fraction of the shape is shaded?  

[STRDGM] A grid with shaded and unshaded squares, showing a total of 15 squares with 9 shaded and 6 unshaded. [STPDGM]  

\subsection*{Answers}
\( \frac{3}{5} \)

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 M

A bottle costs €5. To make a bottle, we need plastic (€0.5), heat (€1), chemicals (€2) and paper (€0.25) How many bottles will it take to make 32 bottles?


(Mathematics) (Word problem) D 6 (Exercise that uses a recipe)

To make pancakes for one person, we need:

\begin{itemize}
\item 1 egg
\item 150g flour
\item 100ml of milk
\item 0.125 tsp salt
\item 1.5 tbsp butter
\item 0.75 tsp baking powder
\end{itemize}

What quantities should Mira use to make pancakes for 4 people?


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Here is the recipe of a serving of raspberry ice-cream for eight individuals:

\begin{itemize}
\item 800ml milk
\item 100g sugar
\item 400g frozen raspberries
\end{itemize}

How many grams of raspberries does Laura use to make herself ice-cream?

\subsection*{Answer}
Laura uses 50g of raspberries.


(Mathematics) (Word problem) D 6 (Exercise that uses a recipe)

Chocolate ice cream for four people uses vanilla extract (1 tsp), sugar (200g), milk (400ml), chocolate (70g) and cream (100ml). How much chocolate should be used for 12 people?


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 M

What proportion of each milk is in a milkshake that uses:
\begin{itemize}
\item 50ml almond milk
\item 100ml coconut milk
\item 75ml cow's milk
\end{itemize}

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Exercise) D 3 (Exercise that helps with algebraic thinking)

I am thinking of a number. I multiply it by 3 and add 2 to get the answer 8. What is my number? You can use the formula below to help you.

\begin{equation*}
\text{number} = \frac{8 - 2}{3}
\end{equation*}


(Mathematics) (Temperature Reading Exercise, Comparison Exercise) D 3 M

\begin{enumerate}
\item Which thermometer shows the coldest temperature?  
\item Which thermometer shows the warmest temperature?  
\item What is the temperature in degrees Celsius?  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Three thermometers are shown, each with different levels of liquid indicating temperature. The first thermometer has a lower liquid level, the second is in the middle, and the third has the highest liquid level. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Drawing Exercise, Temperature Reading Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on converting Celsius to Farenheit)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Draw a thermometer with a temperature of 5 degrees Celsius (°C). Draw another one that converts this temperature to degrees Fahrenheit (°F).
\item Draw a thermometer with a temperature of 205 degrees Farenheit (°F). Draw another one that converts this temperature to degrees Celsius (°C).
\end{enumerate}

For each reading, round up or down to the nearest number.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Short Answer) D 3 (Exercise on converting between Celsius and Farenheit)

What is the difference between a temperature in degrees Celsius and degrees Fahrenheit?

(Mathematics) (Probability Exercise, Group Activity) D 4 (Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Imagine you and your friends roll a die six times. Record the result of each roll in the table below. The “Number” column represents the outcome of the roll. The “Total” column is the sum of all the numbers rolled up to that point. The “Outcome” column should note if the number rolled is greater than 3 or not. Fill in the table to show the outcomes for you and your friends.

\begin{table}[h!]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Number} & \textbf{Total} & \textbf{Outcome} \\ \hline
1               &                &                  \\ \hline
2               &                &                  \\ \hline
3               &                &                  \\ \hline
4               &                &                  \\ \hline
5               &                &                  \\ \hline
6               &                &                  \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\item Complete the table to show the chance of rolling a number.
\begin{table}[h!]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Number} & \textbf{Chance} \\ \hline
1               &                 \\ \hline
2               &                 \\ \hline
3               &                 \\ \hline
4               &                 \\ \hline
5               &                 \\ \hline
6               &                 \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\item Write sentences about the likelihood of having different colored balls.
[STRDGM] Bags with different colored balls: one bag with 2 red and 3 blue, another with 4 green and 1 yellow. [STPDGM]

\item Draw some different colored balls in this bag. Then write sentences about the likelihood of having different colored balls.
[STRDGM] A blank space for drawing with a prompt to illustrate various colored balls. [STPDGM]

\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 3 (With Answer, Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Paul planned a holiday for two weeks. He left on the 1st of May. When did he come home?

\end{enumerate}

\item May 15th 
\item Paul will come back to school on the 31st of May
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on adding and subtracting decimals, Multi-part, With Answer)

Estimate the following:
\[
0.8 + 0.38 + 0.09 + 0.07 + 0.69 = \_\_\_
\]

Now calculate it: \_\_\_

\subsection*{Answers}
The exact sum is 2.03 and an estimate could be 2.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise presenting a shopping problem, With Answer)
A shop has these items for sale:
\begin{itemize}
    \item Coffee maker: \$29.95
    \item Toaster: \$30.75
    \item Can opener: \$14.25
    \item Ice cream maker: \$28.60
\end{itemize}
Raindriver buys an ice cream maker and a coffee maker. How much does he spend altogether? \_\_\_

\subsection*{Answers}
Raindriver spends \$58.55.


(Mathematics) (Measurement Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on cutting, Multi-part, With Answer)

A cuts a piece of wood measuring 1 meter into three pieces. If the first piece is 30 cm long and the second piece is 20 cm long, how long is the last piece?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Length of last piece} = 1 \text{ meter} - (\text{Length of first piece} + \text{Length of second piece})
\end{equation*}

\subsection*{Answers}
The length of the last piece is 50 cm.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)
My family eats \( \frac{2}{3} \) of a box of cereal each week. How much cereal do they eat in 4 weeks?

\subsection*{Answers}
They eat \( \frac{8}{3} \) boxes of cereal, which is \( 2 \frac{2}{3} \) boxes.

\subsection*{Answers}
Each piece of ribbon is \( \frac{3}{10} \) metres long.

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 6 (Exercise with number statements, Multi-part)

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with digit calculation, With Answer)
Use the digits 1, 2, 3, and 4 to complete this calculation.

\_\_\_ + \( \frac{6}{} \) = \_\_\_

\subsection*{Answers}
One possible solution is \( 12 + \frac{6}{3} = 14 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with calculations, Multi-part, With Answer)

A school chef has 75 kg of flour. She uses an average of 5.35 kg of flour each week. There are 13 weeks in the school term.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the total amount of flour used over the 13 weeks.
\item Determine if the chef has enough flour for the term based on your calculations.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The total amount of flour used over the 13 weeks is \( 5.35 \, \text{kg/week} \times 13 \, \text{weeks} = 69.55 \, \text{kg} \).
\item Yes, the chef has enough flour since \( 75 \, \text{kg} > 69.55 \, \text{kg} \).
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with table calculations)

Work out the answer to each calculation and write it in the correct part of the table.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
Answer less than 10 & Answer between 10 and 20 & Answer more than 20 \\
\hline
 &  &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on comparison, Multi-part, With Answer)

A chef needs lots of bags of rice. Deal A: Buy 4 bags for \$5.08. Deal B: Buy 5 bags for \$6.25.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the cost per bag for Deal A.
\item Calculate the cost per bag for Deal B.
\item Which deal is cheaper?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The cost per bag for Deal A is \$1.27.
\item The cost per bag for Deal B is \$1.25.
\item Deal B is cheaper.
\end{enumerate}

    &   & 3 & 5 & 7 & 8 & 9 \\
+   & 4 & 6 & 2 & 1 & 0 & 3 \\
\hline
    & 4 &\_& 7 & 8 & 9 & 2 \\
\end{array}
\]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 M

A juicer holds 2 liters. Ali needs 12 liters of apple juice for her party. How many jars of apple juice must Ali make?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Number of jars} = \frac{12 \text{ liters}}{2 \text{ liters/jar}} = 6 \text{ jars}
\end{equation*}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item \( 91 \div 7 \)

   \item \( 96 \div 8 \)
\end{enumerate}

\item There are 22 pencils in a pot. How many children can have 3 pencils each?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (With Answer)
Write the missing numbers:
\begin{itemize}
    \item \( 8 \div 2 = \_\_\_ \)
    \item \( 4 + 32 = \_\_\_ \)
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
    \item \( 8 \div 2 = 4 \)
    \item \( 4 + 32 = 36 \)
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Answers}
The pairs of numbers are 6 and 6, or 9 and 4, or 12 and 3, or 18 and 2, or 36 and 1.

(Mathematics) (Explanation, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer, Exercise on composite numbers)
Show that 15 is a composite number.

\subsection*{Answers}
15 is a composite number because it has divisors other than 1 and itself, specifically 3 and 5.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with number calculation, With Answer)
Salma is thinking of a number. She says, "If I divide my number by 16, the answer is 15.54." What number is Salma thinking of?

\subsection*{Answers}
The number is \( 15.54 \times 16 = 248.64 \).

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (Exercise with addition, Exercise with division, Multi-part, With Answer)

Complete the following calculations:

\begin{enumerate}
\item \( 45 + 5 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 60 \div 10 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 20 \div 2 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 40 + 5 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 50 + 10 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 18 \div 2 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 35 + 5 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 40 + 10 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 16 \div 2 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 15 \div 3 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 15 + 5 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 16 \div 3 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 16 + 5 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 17 \div 3 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 17 + 5 = \, \_\_\_ \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item 50
\item 6
\item 10
\item 45
\item 60
\item 9
\item 40
\item 50
\item 8
\item 5
\item 20
\item 5.33
\item 21
\item 5.67
\item 22
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Multi-part) D 2 (With Answer)

The children had 12 shells. They put 4 shells on each sandcastle.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many sandcastles are there?
\item The children had 13 flags. They put 4 flags on each sandcastle.
\item How many sandcastles are there?
\item How many flags are left over?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item There are 3 sandcastles.
\item There are 3 sandcastles.
\item There is 1 flag left over.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part, With Answer)

Solve the following problems.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Rosi picked 14 apples. Matias picked 10 more apples than Rosi. How many apples did Matias pick?
\begin{equation*}
14 + 10 = \_\_\_
\end{equation*}

\item Lola picked 10 apples less than Rosi. How many apples did Lola pick?
\begin{equation*}
\_\_\_
\end{equation*}

\item Rashid picked 17 apples. He ate 6. How many apples were left?
\begin{equation*}
17 - 1 = \_\_\_
\end{equation*}

\item Nina had 22 apples in her basket. She picked 12 more. How many apples did Nina have?
\begin{equation*}
22 + 1 = \_\_\_
\end{equation*}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Matias picked 24 apples.
\item Lola picked 4 apples.
\item Rashid had 11 apples left.
\item Nina had 34 apples.
\end{enumerate}

\item \( 6 + \_\_\_ = 20 \)
\item \( 3 + 17 = \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 20 - 18 = \_\_\_ \)
\item \( 20 - \_\_\_ = 7 \)
\item \( 20 - \_\_\_ = 11 \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item 20
\item 14
\item 20
\item 2
\item 13
\item 9
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with fraction calculations, Multi-part)

Calculate the following fractions:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( \frac{1}{4} + \frac{1}{5} \)
\item \( \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{3} \)
\item \( \frac{3}{4} + \frac{2}{5} \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with fractions, Multi-part)

Calculate:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( \frac{3}{8} - \frac{1}{2} \)
\item \( \frac{3}{2} + \frac{1}{2} \)
\item \( \frac{4}{5} - \frac{3}{10} \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Error Correction Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)
Chata solved this calculation: \( \frac{2}{3} + \frac{3}{8} = \frac{5}{13} \). What mistake has Chata made? Correct Chata's answer.

\subsection*{Answers}
Chata made a mistake in adding the fractions. The correct answer is \( \frac{2}{3} + \frac{3}{8} = \frac{25}{24} \).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on time calculation, With Answer)
Alana spends \( \frac{2}{5} \) hour preparing for an experiment and \( \frac{3}{10} \) hour doing the experiment. How long did Alana spend on the experiment altogether?

\subsection*{Answers}
Alana spent \( \frac{2}{5} + \frac{3}{10} = \frac{4}{10} + \frac{3}{10} = \frac{7}{10} \) hour on the experiment altogether.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise with fractions, With Answer)

Each student in a club chooses to play tennis, or rounders. \( \frac{2}{5} \) of the students play tennis. What fraction of the students play rounders?

\subsection*{Answers}
The fraction of students that play rounders is \( \frac{3}{5} \).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 6 (With Answer)
Write the missing number: \( 4 - \frac{1}{3} = \frac{}{3} \).

\subsection*{Answers}
The missing number is 11.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with fraction calculation, With Answer)
Find the value of \( \frac{1}{3} - \frac{2}{5} \).

\subsection*{Answers}
The value is \( \frac{-1}{15} \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on time calculation, With Answer)
Heidi drives for \( \frac{3}{5} \) hours, then takes a break. She drives another \( \frac{7}{10} \) hours to reach her destination. How long did Heidi spend driving in total?

\subsection*{Answers}
Heidi spent \( \frac{3}{5} + \frac{7}{10} = \frac{6}{10} + \frac{7}{10} = \frac{13}{10} \) hours driving, which is 1 hour and 18 minutes.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on number placement, Multi-part)

Write the missing numbers to make this calculation correct: \( \frac{?}{?} - \frac{2}{10} = 0 \). Can you find more than one answer?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is one possible value for the missing number?
\item Can you find another value for the missing number?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on conversion, Multi-part)

Convert these times into seconds.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 2 minutes = \_\_\_ seconds.
\item 2.5 minutes = \_\_\_ seconds.
\item 1.35 minutes = \_\_\_ seconds.
\item 3.75 minutes = \_\_\_ seconds.
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on age calculation, Multi-part, With Answer)

Take the current date as January 1st 2022.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Jack was born on 12th October 1972. He will be \_\_\_ years, \_\_\_ months and \_\_\_ days old.
\item Scott was born on 30th September 1986. He will be \_\_\_ years, \_\_\_ months and \_\_\_ days old.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Jack will be 49 years, 2 months and 20 days old.
\item Scott will be 35 years, 3 months and 2 days old.
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Short Answer) D 4 (With Answer)
Explain if the number fifteen thousand five hundred and fifty-three is divisible by 5.

\subsection*{Answers}
The number fifteen thousand five hundred and fifty-three is not divisible by 5 because it does not end in 0 or 5.

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on exponents, Multi-part, With Answer)

Calculate the following:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 1^2 = \)
\item \( 5^1 = \)
\item \( 3^3 = \)
\item \( 1^1 = \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 1^2 = 1 \)
\item \( 5^1 = 5 \)
\item \( 3^3 = 27 \)
\item \( 1^1 = 1 \)
\end{enumerate}

\item What is the difference between the tenth square number and the fourth square number?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The sum is \( 9 + 25 = 34 \).
\item The difference is \( 100 - 16 = 84\).
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem Exercise, Explanation Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)
Ingrid says, "I can multiply by 100 by adding two zeros." Explain why Ingrid is wrong.

\subsection*{Answers}
Ingrid's statement is incorrect because simply adding two zeros to a number does not accurately represent multiplication by 100. For example, if you take the number 5.6 and add two zeros, you get 5.600, which is not the same as multiplying 5.6 by 100, which equals 560. This method only works for whole numbers and does not apply to decimal numbers or fractions.

\item Anton's number is ten times smaller than Kasinda's number.
\item Anya's number is ten times bigger than Ben's number.
\end{enumerate}

Anton's number is \_\_\_\_\_

Ben's number is \_\_\_\_\_

Kasinda's number is \_\_\_\_\_

Anya's number is \_\_\_\_\_

(Mathematics) (Statistics Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on mean, Exercise on mode, Exercise on median, Multi-part, With Answer)

Make sets of six numbers from these cards that have the following mean, mode, and median values:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Mean 10, Mode 6, Median 8
\item Mean 12, Mode 7.5
\item Mean 15, Mode 15, Median 16
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item One possible set: 6, 6, 8, 10, 10, 14 (Mean = 10, Mode = 6, Median = 8)
\item One possible set: 7, 7, 7, 12, 12, 12 (Mean = 12, Mode = 7.5)
\item One possible set: 15, 15, 15, 16, 16, 16 (Mean = 15, Mode = 15, Median = 16)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise with missing numbers, Multi-part)

The mean has been calculated for each set of numbers below. One number is not included. Work out the missing number:

The sets are as follows:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, \_\_\_\_\_
\item 10, 15, 20, 25, \_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The mean is 6.
\item The mean is 15.
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on statistics, With Answer)

Find the mean time for each runner given the following times:

\begin{itemize}
\item Runner A: 12 minutes
\item Runner B: 15 minutes
\item Runner C: 10 minutes
\item Runner D: 14 minutes
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Answers}
The mean time for each runner is calculated as follows:

\[
\text{Mean} = \frac{\text{Total Time}}{\text{Number of Runners}} = \frac{12 + 15 + 10 + 14}{4} = \frac{51}{4} = 12.75 \text{ minutes}
\]

    \item \( \frac{2}{7} \) of 28
    \item \( \frac{4}{9} \) of 36
\end{enumerate}

What is the same about all the calculations? Explain your answer.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

Arun: Double 8 and double the answer & 32 \\

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer, Exercise with division)

Marcus has \( \frac{3}{4} \) of a bottle of fruit juice. He divides it equally between three glasses. What fraction of the bottle is in each glass?

\subsection*{Answers}
Each glass contains \( \frac{1}{4} \) of the bottle.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer, Exercise with division)

Sofia has \( \frac{3}{4} \) of a cake. She divides the cake into three pieces and eats one of the pieces. What fraction of Sofia's cake is left? Show your working.

\subsection*{Answers}
Sofia has \( \frac{3}{4} \) of a cake. After dividing it into three pieces, each piece is \( \frac{3}{4} \div 3 = \frac{3}{12} = \frac{1}{4} \). After eating one piece, she has \( \frac{3}{4} - \frac{1}{4} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{1}{2} \) of the cake left.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)
Jodi has 2 meters of string. She uses \( \frac{1}{4} \) of a meter to make a bracelet. How much string is left?

\subsection*{Answers}
Jodi has \( 1.75 \) meters of string left.

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on calculation correction, Multi-part, With Answer)

Safiyah is learning to use brackets. She writes down four calculations but one of her calculations is wrong.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\Alph*.]
\item A: \( 10 - 2 \times 3 = 4 \)
\item B: \( (10 - 2) \times 3 = 6 \)
\item C: \( (10 - 2) - 3 = 5 \)
\item D: \( 20 - 2 \times 8 = 4 \)
\end{enumerate}

Which calculation is wrong? What is the correct answer?

\subsection*{Answers}
The incorrect calculation is B: \( (10 - 2) \times 3 = 6 \). The correct answer is \( (10 - 2) \times 3 = 24 \).

\item \( (8 - 10) + 2 \)

\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (With Answer)

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on bead calculation, With Answer)

Nasreen has a packet of coloured beads. The packet contains 5 orange beads, 5 red beads, and 10 blue beads. Nasreen says, "Half the beads are blue." She is correct. Explain how you know.

\subsection*{Answers}
To determine if Nasreen is correct, we first calculate the total number of beads:
\[
5 \text{ (orange)} + 5 \text{ (red)} + 10 \text{ (blue)} = 20 \text{ beads}.
\]
Next, we find half of the total number of beads:
\[
\frac{20}{2} = 10 \text{ beads}.
\]
Since there are 10 blue beads, which is half of the total, Nasreen is correct.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Exercise on missing number calculation, With Answer)
What is the missing number?

\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{3} \text{ of } 30 = \_\_\_
\end{equation*}

\subsection*{Answers}
The missing number is 10.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Short Answer) D 4 (Exercise on fractions, With Answer)

Hassan says, "I would rather have \( \frac{3}{8} \) of \$36 than \( \frac{1}{4} \) of \$60 because \( \frac{3}{8} \) is bigger than \( \frac{1}{4} \)." Do you agree with Hassan? Explain your answer.

\subsection*{Answers}
To determine whether you agree with Hassan, calculate \( \frac{3}{8} \) of \$36 and \( \frac{1}{4} \) of \$60.
\begin{itemize}
    \item \( \frac{3}{8} \) of \$36 is \( \frac{3 \times 36}{8} = \$13.50 \)
    \item \( \frac{1}{4} \) of \$60 is \( \frac{1 \times 60}{4} = \$15.00 \)
\end{itemize}

Since \$13.50 is less than \$15.00, you may disagree with Hassan.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with division, With Answer)
Calculate \( 837 \div 9 \).

\subsection*{Answers}
The answer is 93.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with division, Multi-part)

Four friends have lunch each day at a café. The total cost for the week is \$152. They share the cost equally.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How much does each person pay for the week?
\item If they go to the café for 5 days, how much do they pay per day?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with division, With Answer)
Henryk pays \$9 each week to go to the gym. He has paid \$747 so far. How many weeks has he been to the gym?

\subsection*{Answers}
He has been to the gym for 83 weeks.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with division, With Answer)
A team of volunteers made a total of \$992 by selling T-shirts for charity. Each T-shirt costs \$8. How many T-shirts did the volunteers sell?

\subsection*{Answers}
The volunteers sold 124 T-shirts.

\subsection*{Answers}

\text{Leanne: } 720 \div 24 = 30
\end{equation*}
\begin{equation*}
\text{Carrie: } 720 \div 24 = 3
\end{equation*}

Who has the correct answer? What mistake has the other child made?

\hline
Yellow & 50 \\
Red & 20 \\
Blue & 20 \\
Pink & 10 \\
Orange & 10 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

What percentage of the flowers are pink?

\subsection*{Answers}
The percentage of the flowers that are pink is 10\%.

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (Exercise with estimation, With Answer)

Estimate and complete the answer grid.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Expression} & \text{Answer} \\
\hline
\( 122 + \_\_ \) & 222 \\
\( 430 + -57 \) & 373 \\
\( 134 + \_\_ \) & 290 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{itemize}
\item \( 122 + 100 = 222 \)
\item \( 430 - 57 = 373 \)
\item \( 134 + 156 = 290 \)
\end{itemize}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)
Emma spent \( \frac{1}{3} \) hour preparing an experiment and \( \frac{5}{6} \) hour doing the experiment.

How long did Emma spend on the experiment altogether?

\subsection*{Answers}
Emma spent \( \frac{1}{3} + \frac{5}{6} = \frac{2}{6} + \frac{5}{6} = \frac{7}{6} \) hours, which is 1 hour and \( \frac{1}{6} \) hour.

\subsection*{Answers}
The answer is \( \frac{2}{3} \).

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Problem-solving Exercise, Short Answer) D 5 (With Answer)

Chevi paid \$648 for a flight to London and \$81 for a night in a hotel. How much did he spend in total? Explain how you found your answer: \_\_.

\subsection*{Answers}
Chevi spent \$729 in total. He found this by adding the cost of the flight and the hotel: \( 648 + 81 = 729 \).

Amira had \$249. Her mother gave her another \$42. How much did she have in total? Explain how you found your answer: \_\_.

\subsection*{Answers}
Amira had \$291 in total.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part, With Answer)

Samir and Abimbola are making a list of food to buy for their party. This is their list so far with the prices for the amounts they need:

\begin{itemize}
    \item Bread: \$4.45
    \item Doughnuts: \$9.99
    \item Ice cream: \$15.25
    \item Pizza: \$42.80
    \item Samosa: \$4.50
    \item Aloo tikka: \$10.75
\end{itemize}

They have \$75. How much more money do they need to buy everything on their list? What is the total cost?

\subsection*{Answers}
The total cost of the food items is \$87.79. They need \$12.79 more to buy everything on their list.

(Mathematics) (Problem Solving Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (Exercise with 2-digit numbers)

\hline

\hline

\item \( \frac{5}{6} \) of 24

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Multi-part)

You have 23 friends. How many cakes do you need to buy so that everyone (as well as yourself) has \( \frac{1}{8} \) of a cake each?


(Mathematics) (True/False Exercise, Multi-part) D 2 (Exercise on fact families, Multi-part)
Look at these statements about fact families. Write true or false next to each statement and give at least three examples to show that your answer is correct.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item A fact family consists of a group of related addition and subtraction or multiplication and division facts.
\item In a fact family involving the numbers 2, 3, and 5, the equations are \( 2 + 3 = 5 \) and \( 5 - 3 = 2 \).
\item Every fact family has exactly four equations.
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise with division, With Answer)
Antonio buys 35 chocolate bars. He shares them between five people. How many chocolate bars does each person get? What is the fraction you found?

\subsection*{Answers}
Each person gets 7 chocolate bars, and the fraction is \(\frac{7}{35}\) or \(\frac{1}{5}\).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise with division, Multi-part, With Answer)
Shelly organizes 138 beads into six piles. How many beads are in each pile? What is the fraction of beads in each pile?

\subsection*{Answers}
Each pile contains 23 beads, and the fraction is \(\frac{23}{138}\).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 2 (Exercise with subtraction, Multi-part, With Answer)

For each 2-digit number, swap the digits round and subtract the larger number from the smaller number.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 73
\item 82
\item 45
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 73 - 37 = 36 \)
\item \( 82 - 28 = 54 \)
\item \( 45 - 54 = 9 \)
\end{enumerate}

\item What is the smallest possible total you can get from pulling numbers out of the bag?
\item Did you find any quick ways to add numbers together?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (With Answer, Multi-part)

\item The chickens laid 18 eggs on Monday and 23 eggs on Tuesday. How many eggs altogether?

\item There were 27 students in one class and 28 in another class. How many students altogether?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item The total number of eggs is 41
\item The total number of students is 55.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Problem-solving) D 5 (With Answer)

India has a bowl of fruit. \( \frac{1}{4} \) are apples, \( \frac{1}{3} \) are papayas, \( \frac{1}{6} \) are mangos, and the other fruit are bananas. Calculate the possible numbers of each fruit. Your answer should use a common denominator.

\subsection*{Answers}
Let the total number of fruits be \( x \). Then:
\begin{itemize}
\item Number of apples = \( \frac{1}{4}x \)
\item Number of papayas = \( \frac{1}{3}x \)
\item Number of mangos = \( \frac{1}{6}x \)
\item Number of bananas = \( x - \left(\frac{1}{4}x + \frac{1}{3}x + \frac{1}{6}x\right) \)
\end{itemize}

To find a common denominator, we can use 12:
\begin{itemize}
\item Number of apples = \( \frac{3}{12}x \)
\item Number of papayas = \( \frac{4}{12}x \)
\item Number of mangos = \( \frac{2}{12}x \)
\end{itemize}

Adding these fractions gives:
\[
\frac{3}{12}x + \frac{4}{12}x + \frac{2}{12}x = \frac{9}{12}x
\]
Thus, the number of bananas is:
\[
x - \frac{9}{12}x = \frac{3}{12}x = \frac{1}{4}x
\]

The total number of fruits must be a multiple of the least common multiple of the denominators (4, 3, and 6), which is 12. Therefore, possible values for \( x \) could be 12, 24, 36, etc.


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Matching Exercise) D 1 M

Write the correct day of the week.

The day after Wednesday is \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

The day after Friday is \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

The day before Tuesday is \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

The day before Monday is \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

Complete the table for days of the week.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
The Day Before & Today & The Day After \\
\hline
 & Sunday & Monday \\
\hline
Sunday & Monday &  \\
\hline
Monday & Tuesday &  \\
\hline
Tuesday &  & Thursday \\
\hline
 & Thursday & \\
\hline
Thursday &  &  \\
\hline
 &  & Sunday \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer, Exercise on calculation)

Calculate the protein content from 300g of uncooked lentils if 13\% of lentils are protein.

\subsection*{Answers}
The protein content in 300g of lentils is 39g.

\paragraph{Using the data}
Now construct a frequency table.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering

5 &  \\ \hline

11 &  \\ \hline
12 &  \\ \hline
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Short Answer, Fill in the Blank) D 4 (Exercise on writing time in words, Multi-part)

Here are some times. Write each time in words. For example, 7.45 a.m. becomes seven forty-five in the morning.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 9.15 a.m. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item 12.30 p.m. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item 3.45 p.m. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item 7.40 p.m. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

Manuel visited his grandmother on Monday. He stayed for three days. On which day of the week did Manuel return home?


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

It is a Saturday today. Lucia's birthday is in four days' time. On which day of the week is Lucia's birthday this year?


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

Carlos posted a parcel on Wednesday to a friend. The parcel took two days to arrive at his friend’s house.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item On which day of the week did the parcel arrive?
\item If the parcel had taken one more day to arrive, what day would it have arrived?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Short Answer) D 2 (Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many days are there in five weeks?
\item How many months are there in two years?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Number Exercise, Short Answer) D 3 (Exercise on number facts)

Make any two-digit number. Write it below. Write down 5 facts about this number.


(Mathematics) (Number Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on number facts)

Pick a three-digit number. Write it below and list 5 facts about this number.


(Mathematics) (Comparison Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

April had \$23.95. Faith had \$23.50. Who had the most money? Write the amounts in two number sentences using the \( < \) and \( > \) symbols:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item April's amount compared to Faith's amount: \( 23.95 \, \_\_ \, 23.50 \)
\item Faith's amount compared to April's amount: \( 23.50 \, \_\_ \, 23.95 \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item April's amount compared to Faith's amount: \( 23.95 > 23.50 \)
\item Faith's amount compared to April's amount: \( 23.50 < 23.95 \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Comparison Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

Greg had 124 shells. Hope had 142 shells.

Who had the most shells?

Write the amounts in two number sentences using the \( < \) and \( > \) symbols:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Greg's shells compared to Hope's shells: \( 124 \, \_\_ \, 142 \)
\item Hope's shells compared to Greg's shells: \( 142 \, \_\_ \, 124 \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
Greg's shells compared to Hope's shells: \( 124 < 142 \)
Hope's shells compared to Greg's shells: \( 142 > 124 \)


(Mathematics) (Sequence Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (Exercise on Fibonacci-type sequences, Multi-part)

In a Fibonacci-type sequence, each number is the sum of the two previous numbers.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Create two of your own Fibonacci-type sequences.
\item Extend the Fibonacci sequence for another ten numbers starting from 0 and 1.
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Sequence Exercise, Pattern Recognition Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on Fibonacci-type sequences, Multi-part)

Continue these Fibonacci-type sequences until you pass 100:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item 4, 7, 11, 18, \ldots
\item 12, 23, 35, \ldots
\item 1, 10, 11, \ldots
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Sequence Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Multi-part, Exercise on number sequences, Exercise with calculations)

Choose two numbers to start number sequences of your choice. For each number, write the first five terms and explain the rule for your sequences.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item For the first number, write the first five terms of the sequence and explain the rule.
\item For the second number, write the first five terms of the sequence and explain the rule.
\end{enumerate}

Write a calculation using each of the other four numbers. Use what you have learned in this Unit. For example: adding or subtracting units, tens, hundreds or thousands, or partitioning one of your numbers.

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Exercise with table filling, With Answer)

Fill in this table. The first three rows are done for you.

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Half the number} & \text{Number} & \text{Double the number} \\
\hline
12 & 24 & 48 \\
\hline
120 & 240 & 480 \\
\hline
1200 & 2400 & 4800 \\
\hline
46 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
460 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
4600 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
28 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
280 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
2800 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
34 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
340 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
3400 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

\subsection*{Answers}
\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Half the number} & \text{Number} & \text{Double the number} \\
\hline
12 & 24 & 48 \\
\hline
120 & 240 & 480 \\
\hline
1200 & 2400 & 4800 \\
\hline
46 & 92 & 92 \\
\hline
460 & 920 & 920 \\
\hline
4600 & 9200 & 9200 \\
\hline
28 & 56 & 56 \\
\hline
280 & 560 & 560 \\
\hline
2800 & 5600 & 5600 \\
\hline
34 & 68 & 68 \\
\hline
340 & 680 & 680 \\
\hline
3400 & 6800 & 6800 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (Exercise on conversion, With Answer)
Convert the following meters to kilometers:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 3000 m = \_\_\_ km
\item 650 m = \_\_\_ km
\item 7100 m = \_\_\_ km
\item 9280 m = \_\_\_ km
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 3000 m = 3 km
\item 650 m = 0.65 km
\item 7100 m = 7.1 km
\item 9280 m = 9.28 km
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (Exercise with division, With Answer)
96 children divided themselves into groups of 4. How many groups were there?

\subsection*{Answers}
There were 24 groups.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 3 (Exercise on cost calculation, With Answer)
A tailor bought 125 m of red cloth and 215 m of blue cloth. Each metre of cloth cost \$5. How much did he pay altogether?

\subsection*{Answers}
The tailor paid \$1,700 altogether.

\subsection*{Answers}
1 l = 1000 ml.

\subsection*{Answers}
The cost of 1 storybook is \$18.

\subsection*{Answers}
The smaller number is 70.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 4 \, \text{m} \, 65 \, \text{cm} + 2 \, \text{m} \, 80 \, \text{cm} = \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{m} \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{cm} \)
\item \( 6 \, \text{km} \, 30 \, \text{m} - 2 \, \text{km} \, 45 \, \text{m} = \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{km} \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{m} \)
\item \( 3 \, \text{kg} \, 95 \, \text{g} + 2 \, \text{kg} \, 75 \, \text{g} = \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{kg} \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{g} \)
\item \( 5 \, \text{L} \, 50 \, \text{ml} - 2 \, \text{L} \, 90 \, \text{ml} = \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{L} \, \_\_\_\_ \, \text{ml} \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with multiplication, Multi-part, With Answer)

Fill in the blanks:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 346 \times 7 = ( \_\_\_ \times 7) + (40 \times \_\_\_) + ( \_\_\_ \times 7) = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 54.92 \times 3 = (4 \times 3) + (0.9 \times \_\_\_) + ( \_\_\_ \times 3) = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 685 \times 6 = ( \_\_\_ \times 6) + (80 \times \_\_\_) + ( \_\_\_ \times 6) = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 4.56 \times 4 = ( \_\_\_ \times 4) + (0.5 \times \_\_\_) + ( \_\_\_ \times 4) = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 532 \times 8 = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 8.26 \times 5 = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 365 \times 47 = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 300 \times \_\_ = 12000 \)
\item \( 2820 \) is the product of \( 60 \times \_\_ \).
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 2422 \)
\item \( 164.76 \)
\item \( 4110 \)
\item \( 18.24 \)
\item \( 4256 \)
\item \( 41.3 \)
\item \( 365 \times 47 = 17155 \)
\item \( 300 \times 40 = 12000 \)
\item \( 2820 \) is the product of \( 60 \times 47 \).
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on time calculation, With Answer)
In a 4 x 100 m relay race, the four runners' times are 13.46s, 14.55s, 12.52s, and 19.01s. What is the total time for the race?

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Fill in the Blank, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise with multiplication)
Your friend does not understand how to carry out column multiplication. Complete the sentences below to explain it to them:

\[
\begin{array}{c}
352 \\
\times 63 \\
\hline
21120 \quad (352 \times \underline{\hspace{1cm}}) \\
1056 \quad (352 \times \underline{\hspace{1cm}}) \\
\hline
22176 \\
\end{array}
\]

21120 is the answer to \underline{\hspace{1cm}}.

1056 is the answer to \underline{\hspace{1cm}}.

I get 22176 by \underline{\hspace{1cm}}.


(Mathematics) (True or False Exercise, Short Answer) D 2 (Multi-part)

Tick the correct sentences and put a cross next to the incorrect ones.

\begin{enumerate}
\item All the sides of a square are the same length.
\item A pyramid has 5 vertices.
\item A pentagon has 6 straight sides and 6 vertices.
\item Cubes have six square faces.
\item All shapes with three straight sides are called triangles.
\item A sphere has no vertices.
\item All shapes with five straight sides are called hexagons.
\item Cylinders have 4 circular faces.
\item Cuboids have six rectangular faces.
\item All shapes with six straight sides are called pentagons.
\item Cones have one vertex.
\end{enumerate}

Choose two incorrect sentences. Re-write them to make them correct.

(Mathematics) (Group Activity, Estimation Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on weight estimation)
Work in a group of four. Choose four different-sized items from the classroom.
\begin{enumerate}
\item As a group, estimate how much you think each item weighs. You need to agree on an estimate!
\item As a group, decide the best unit to use. Write the item, unit, and your estimate in the table below. Use decimal notation.
\item Now weigh each item. Add this information to your table (again, use decimal notation).
\item Compare the mass of each item with your estimate. Write the difference between your estimate and the actual weight in the table. Did your estimating improve?
\end{enumerate}
Now order your masses from lightest to heaviest:

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Item} & \textbf{Unit} & \textbf{Estimate} & \textbf{Actual} & \textbf{Difference} \\
\hline
1. & & & & \\
\hline
2. & & & & \\
\hline
3. & & & & \\
\hline
4. & & & & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\item Cakes: \$8.12 for a box of 4 or \$12.84 for a box of 6
\item Washing Powder: \$18.92 for a 2 kg box or \$50.54 for a 7 kg box
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 4 (Exercise with multiplication, Multi-part)

Complete these multiplications:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 234 \times 10 = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \)
\item \( 171 \times 23 = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \)
\item \( 507 \times 13 = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \)
\item \( 963 \times 19 = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \)
\item \( 744 \times 6 = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \)
\item \( 608 \times 4 = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
2 halves make a whole.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Fill in the Blank) D 5 (Exercise on time calculation, With Answer, Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Levi went apple picking. He began at 14:20. He picked apples for 2 hours and 25 minutes. What time did he finish? Levi finished at \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

\item Kieron spent 2 hours and 5 minutes at the gym. He left the gym at 18:20. When did he arrive at the gym? Kieron got there at \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

\item The twins went to the park. They arrived at 15:50 and left at 17:35. How long were they at the park? The twins were at the park for \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

\item Carrie and Mona left home to go to school at 07:15. They spent the day working hard. They got home at 16:25. How long were they away from home? Carrie and Mona were away from home for \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.

\item Adam and Chris worked in the garden. They started at 14:25. Adam finished at 16:10. Chris continued working for another hour and 10 minutes. For how long was Chris working in the garden? Chris was working in the garden for \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Levi finished at 16:45.
\item Kieron got there at 16:15.
\item The twins were at the park for 1 hour and 45 minutes.
\item Carrie and Mona were away from home for 9 hours and 10 minutes.
\item Chris was working in the garden for 1 hour and 10 minutes.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on distance calculation, With Answer)
A platoon of soldiers marched at an average speed of 20 \(\text{m/min}\) for 16 minutes. What was the distance they marched?

\subsection*{Answers}
The distance marched is 320 meters.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on distance calculation, With Answer)
An aeroplane flew at an average speed of 255 \(\text{km/h}\) for 9 hours. What was the distance it travelled?

\subsection*{Answers}
The distance travelled is \( 255 \, \text{km/h} \times 9 \, \text{h} = 2295 \, \text{km}.\)


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on average speed calculation, With Answer)
Douglas ran 150 \text{ m} in 25 \text{ seconds}. Find his average speed in \text{ m/s}.

\subsection*{Answers}
His average speed is 6 \text{ m/s}.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise formulated as a distance and time problem With Answer)
Rose and Lucy set off from Town C to Town D at the same time. The two towns were 640 km apart. After 8 hours, Rose reached Town D, while Lucy was still 128 km away from Town D. If Lucy continued at the same average speed, how much longer did she take than Rose to reach Town D?

\subsection*{Answers}
Lucy took 1 hour longer than Rose to reach Town D.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on distance and speed calculation, With Answer)
A ship sailed 1050 km at an average speed of 75 km/h. How long did it sail?

\subsection*{Answers}
The time taken to sail is 14 hours.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on distance and speed calculation, With Answer)
Gary drove at an average speed of 84 km/h from Town A to Town B. If the two towns were 273 km apart, find the time he took.

\subsection*{Answers}
The time taken is \( \frac{273 \text{ km}}{84 \text{ km/h}} = 3.25 \text{ hours} \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on distance and speed calculation, With Answer)

Jack drove from City X to City Y at an average speed of 60 \text{ km/h}. The two cities were 570 \text{ km} apart. What was the time taken?

\subsection*{Answers}
The time taken is 9.5 hours.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)
There are \(\frac{3}{5}\) as many cows as sheep on a farm. If there are 240 cows and sheep altogether, how many more sheep than cows are there?

\subsection*{Answers}
There are 60 more sheep than cows.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Jason sold \(\frac{3}{10}\) as many pens as Mike. If Jason sold 210 fewer pens than Mike, how many pens did they sell altogether?

\subsection*{Answers}
Let \( x \) be the number of pens Mike sold. Then, Jason sold \(\frac{3}{10}x\) pens. According to the problem, we have the equation:

\[
\frac{3}{10}x = x - 210
\]

Solving for \( x \):

\[
\frac{3}{10}x + 210 = x
\]
\[
210 = x - \frac{3}{10}x
\]
\[
210 = \frac{7}{10}x
\]
\[
x = 210 \times \frac{10}{7} = 300
\]

So, Mike sold 300 pens, and Jason sold:

\[
\frac{3}{10} \times 300 = 90
\]

Altogether, they sold:

\[
300 + 90 = 390 \text{ pens.}
\]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)
Rachel bought \(\frac{5}{12}\) as many stamps as Michelle. Michelle bought 420 more stamps than Rachel. How many stamps did Michelle buy?

\subsection*{Answers}
Michelle bought 840 stamps.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise with ratios, With Answer)
A sum of money was divided among three pupils in the ratio \( 4 : 7 : 3 \). If the largest share was \$84, find the smallest share of money.

\subsection*{Answers}
The smallest share of money is \$48.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on measurement conversion, With Answer)
Find the equivalent measures.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.4 \) m = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ cm
\item \( 1.25 \) kg = \_\_\_\_\_\_ kg \_\_\_\_\_\_ g
\item \( 305 \) ml = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ L
\item \( 0.75 \) ft = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ in.
\item \( 6.25 \) lb = \_\_\_\_\_ lb \_\_\_\_\_ oz
\item \( 3.25 \) gal = \_\_\_\_\_\_ gal \_\_\_\_\_ c
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 40 \) cm
\item \( 1 \) kg \( 250 \) g
\item \( 0.305 \) L
\item \( 9 \) in.
\item \( 6 \) lb \( 4 \) oz
\item \( 3 \) gal \( 4 \) c
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on average weight calculation, With Answer)

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

\subsection*{Answers}
The taxi fare is \( \$7.40 \).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (Exercise on volume calculation, With Answer)
A rectangular container \( 8 \) cm long and \( 9 \) cm wide was filled with water to a depth of \( 6 \) cm. When \( 12 \) marbles of equal size were added to the container, the depth of the water became \( 7.5 \) cm. Find the volume of one marble.

\subsection*{Answers}
The volume of one marble is \( 9 \text{cm}^3 \).


(Mathematics) (Geometry Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on volume calculation, With Answer)

\subsection*{Answers}
The number of \( 4 \)-cm cubes that can fit into the box is \( 3750 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 5 (Exercise on money distribution, With Answer)

Sam had \( \$85 \) and John had \( \$220 \). They were each given an equal amount of money. After receiving the money, John had twice as much money as Sam. How much money did each boy receive?

\subsection*{Answers}
Each boy received \( \$50 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise with ratio calculation, With Answer)

\subsection*{Answers}
Alice has \( \$227.50 \).


(Mathematics) (Geometry Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on volume calculation, With Answer)

\subsection*{Answers}
The volume is \( 1728 \text{ in}^3 \).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on algebraic expressions, Multi-part, With Answer)

Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( x = 12 \).

\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( 21 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 1 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 35 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 3 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 43 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 6 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 56 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 9 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 70 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 12 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( 21 - 12 = 9 \)
\item \( 12 - 1 = 11 \)
\item \( 35 - 12 = 23 \)
\item \( 12 - 3 = 9 \)
\item \( 43 - 12 = 31 \)
\item \( 12 - 6 = 6 \)
\item \( 56 - 12 = 44 \)
\item \( 12 - 9 = 3 \)
\item \( 70 - 12 = 58 \)
\item \( 12 - 12 = 0 \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on direct proportion, With Answer)
For every \$50 earned, Mr. Edward spends \$35 and saves the rest. How much money does he save if he earns \$1000?

\subsection*{Answers}
Mr. Edward saves \$650.


(Mathematics) (Algebra Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on evaluating expressions, Multi-part, With Marks, With Answer)
Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( x = 8 \). (2 marks each)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( 3x = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( \frac{x}{4} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 5x + 5 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 21 - 2x = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 7 + \frac{x}{3} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( \frac{7x}{2} - 10 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( x + \frac{x}{2} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 4x - \frac{7x}{8} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 2x^2 - 14 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( \frac{3x}{16} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item 24
\item 2
\item 45
\item 5
\item 11
\item 18
\item 12
\item 25
\item 94
\item 1.5
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Algebra Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on simplification, Multi-part, With Marks, With Answer)

Simplify each of the following expressions. (2 marks each)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( 3a + 6a = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 7b - 4b = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 5c + c + 2c = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 10d - 3d - 7d = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 8e - 6e + 9e = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 4f + 5f + 2f = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 6g + 8 - g = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 9h + 4 - 3h - 5h = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( i + 8 + 12i - 2 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 16 + 14j - 5 - 9j = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( 9a \)
\item \( 3b \)
\item \( 8c \)
\item \( 0 \)
\item \( 11e \)
\item \( 11f \)
\item \( 5g + 8 \)
\item \( 0 + 4 = 4 \)
\item \( 13i + 6 \)
\item \( 7j + 11 \)
\end{enumerate}

\item \( 4h - h = \underline{\quad} \)
\item \( 9i - 2i = \underline{\quad} \)

\item \( 9t - t = \underline{\quad} \)
\item \( 12v - 6v - 3v = \underline{\quad} \)

\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on algebraic expressions, Multi-part, With Answer)

Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( k = 12 \).

\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( \frac{k}{3} + k = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( k - \frac{k}{2} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( k - \frac{k}{6} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 2k + \frac{k}{12} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 7k - \frac{k}{2} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 5k + \frac{2k}{3} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 6k - \frac{5k}{2} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( 12 + 12 = 24 \)
\item \( 12 - 6 = 6 \)
\item \( 12 - 2 = 10 \)
\item \( 24 + 1 = 25 \)
\item \( 84 - 6 = 78 \)
\item \( 60 + 8 = 68 \)
\item \( 72 - 30 = 42 \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Algebra Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on evaluating expressions, Multi-part, With Marks, With Answer)
Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( m = 3 \). (2 marks each)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( m^2 + 5 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 14 + m^3 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( m^2 - 19 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 16 - m^2 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 4m^3 + 3 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 5m^2 - 7 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 8 + 3m^3 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( 100 - 2m^2 = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( \frac{4m^2}{3} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \( \frac{5m^3}{9} = \) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Roman*.]
\item \( 3^2 + 5 = 14 \)
\item \( 14 + 3^3 = 41 \)
\item \( 3^2 - 19 = -10 \)
\item \( 16 - 3^2 = 7 \)
\item \( 4(3^3) + 3 = 111 \)
\item \( 5(3^2) - 7 = 38 \)
\item \( 8 + 3(3^3) = 83 \)
\item \( 100 - 2(3^2) = 82 \)
\item \( \frac{4(3^2)}{3} = 12 \)
\item \( \frac{5(3^3)}{9} = 15 \)
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 1 (Multi-part)

1 less than 91 is \_\_\_.

10 more than 87 is \_\_\_.

10 less than 84 is \_\_\_.

2 more than 90 is \_\_\_.

20 less than 97 is \_\_\_.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
72 & 75 & 76 & 80 \\
\hline
84 & 86 & 89 &   \\
\hline
91 & 93 & 95 & 98 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on percentage calculation, With Answer)
Express 600 ml as a percentage of 4 €.

\subsection*{Answers}
The percentage is 15000\%.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on percentage calculation, With Answer)

Express 350 ml as a percentage of 2.5 €.

\subsection*{Answers}
The percentage is \( \frac{350 \, \text{ml}}{2.5 \, \text{€}} \times 100\% = 14000\% \).

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on ratio and proportion, With Answer)
A piece of string was cut into two pieces in the ratio \( 4 : 11 \). If the longer piece of string was \( 44 \, \text{cm} \) long, find the original length of the piece of string.

\subsection*{Answers}
The original length of the piece of string is \( 88 \, \text{cm} \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on ratios, With Answer)
Andrew and Martin shared 48 balloons in the ratio 3 : 13. How many more balloons did Martin get than Andrew?

\subsection*{Answers}
Martin got 36 more balloons than Andrew.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on ratios, With Answer)

The ratio of the number of Cynthia's posters to the number of Laura's posters was \( 3 : 4 \). Cynthia had 24 fewer posters than Laura. Later, Laura gave 36 of her posters away to her brother. Find the new ratio of the number of Cynthia's posters to the number of Laura's posters.

\subsection*{Answers}
Let the number of Cynthia's posters be \( 3x \) and Laura's posters be \( 4x \). According to the problem, we have:
\[
3x = 4x - 24
\]
Solving for \( x \):
\[
x = 24
\]
Thus, Cynthia has \( 3 \times 24 = 72 \) posters and Laura has \( 4 \times 24 = 96 \) posters. After Laura gives away 36 posters, she has \( 96 - 36 = 60 \) posters. The new ratio of Cynthia's posters to Laura's posters is:
\[
\frac{72}{60} = \frac{12}{10} = \frac{6}{5}
\]
The new ratio is \( 6 : 5 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (Exercise involving comparison, With Answer)
Amelia spent \$27. Tyrone spent \$52. How much more money did Tyrone spend than Amelia?

Tyrone spent \$\_\_\_\_\_ more than Amelia.

\subsection*{Answers}
Tyrone spent \$25 more than Amelia.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on percentage calculation, With Answer)

\subsection*{Answers}
The discount percentage is 12.5\%.

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (Multi-part)

Calculate the following equations:
\begin{equation*}

\end{equation*}

    13 - 6 = \_\_\_
\end{equation*}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 1 (Exercise with addition, Exercise with subtraction)

Solve the following arithmetic problems:

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Addition Problems} & \textbf{Subtraction Problems} \\
\hline
\( 0 + 5 = \_\_\_ \) & \( 5 - 4 = \_\_\_ \) \\
\( 9 + 1 = \_\_\_ \) & \( 7 - 7 = \_\_\_ \) \\
\( 5 + 2 = \_\_\_ \) & \( 9 - 0 = \_\_\_ \) \\
\( 4 + 4 = \_\_\_ \) & \( 10 - 6 = \_\_\_ \) \\
\( 6 + 3 = \_\_\_ \) & \( 8 - 2 = \_\_\_ \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)
There were 1400 people in a village in 1998. The number of people increased by 12\% in 1999 and later decreased by 25\% in 2000. How many fewer people were there in 2000 than in 1998?

\subsection*{Answers}
There were 350 fewer people in 2000 than in 1998.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)
The usual selling prices of a handbag and a set of jewellery were \$990 and \$550 respectively. Jane bought them at a 10\% discount during a sale. How much did she pay altogether?

\subsection*{Answers}
Jane paid \$1,386 altogether.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer, Exercise on percentages)

Sally wanted to buy a cordless phone and a printer that cost \$160 and \$380 respectively. If the salesman gave her a 15\% discount, how much discount did she get altogether?

\subsection*{Answers}
The total discount is \$81.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer, Exercise on percentages)

In 1999, 150 children were enrolled in Primary 1 at a certain school. The number of children enrolled increased by 20\% in 2000. In 2001, the number of children enrolled decreased by 20\%. How many children were enrolled in 2001?

\subsection*{Answers}
The number of children enrolled in 2001 is 144.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on percentage conversion, Multi-part, With Answer)

\begin{enumerate}
\item Express \( \frac{17}{25} \) as a percentage.

\item Express \( \frac{5}{8} \) as a percentage.

\item Express 60% as a fraction in its simplest form.

\item Express 85% as a fraction in its simplest form.

\item Express 0.7 as a percentage.

\item Express 0.036 as a percentage.

\item Express 30% as a decimal.

\item Express 6% as a decimal.

\item Express 60 cents as a percentage of \$3.

\item Express 18 cm as a percentage of 5 m.

\item Express 4.2 kg as a percentage of 2 kg.

\item Express 2 as a percentage of 800 ml.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item 68\%
\item 62.5\%
\item \( \frac{3}{5} \)
\item \( \frac{17}{20} \)
\item 70\%
\item 3.6\%
\item 0.3
\item 0.06
\item 20\%
\item 360\%
\item 210\%
\item 0.25\%
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on percentages, With Answer)
Andy has \$200. He has 25\% more money than Peter. How much more money does Andy have than Peter?

\subsection*{Answers}
Andy has \$50 more than Peter.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer, Exercise on percentages)

Gordon's weight increases by 20\% this year. If the increase in his weight is 10 kg, how much does he weigh now?

\subsection*{Answers}
Gordon weighs 50 kg now.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)
Aihui worked in a factory for 9 days. She was paid \$45 each day. How much did she earn altogether?

\subsection*{Answers}
Aihui earned \$405 altogether.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 3 (With Answer)
A pail filled with sand weighs 5 kg. The empty pail weighs 200 g. Find the weight of the sand.

\subsection*{Answers}
The weight of the sand is 4.8 kg.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)
The sum of two numbers is 240. If one number is twice the other number, find the numbers.

\subsection*{Answers}
The smaller number is 80 and the larger number is 160.


(Mathematics) (Pattern Recognition Exercise, Drawing Exercise) D 1 (Exercise with coloring, Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Imagine a sequence is triangle, circle, triangle, circle. Draw and color the next shape in the sequence.
\item Imagine a sequence is rectangle, rectangle, rectangle. Draw and color the next shape in the sequence.
\item Imagine a sequence is square, square, square. Draw and color the next shape in the sequence.
\item Imagine a sequence is triangle, rectangle, triangle, rectangle. Draw and color the next shape in the sequence.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on ratios, With Answer)
Edwin has 36 compact discs and 10 cassettes. Find the ratio of the number of cassettes to the total number of compact discs and cassettes.

\subsection*{Answers}
The ratio of the number of cassettes to the total number of compact discs and cassettes is \( \frac{10}{46} \) or \( \frac{5}{23} \).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Exercise on ratios, With Answer)
There are 96 men and 72 women in a queue. Find the ratio of the number of men to the total number of men and women.

\subsection*{Answers}
The ratio of the number of men to the total number of men and women is \( \frac{96}{96 + 72} = \frac{96}{168} = \frac{4}{7} \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (Multi-part, With Answer)
Nicole bought 12 pastries. She put 4 of them on a plate. She put the rest in a box. How many pastries were there in the box?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many pastries did Nicole put in the box?
\item How many pastries did she buy in total?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
There were 8 pastries in the box.

(Mathematics) (Estimation Exercise, Measurement Exercise) D 1 M

Estimate and then weigh your ruler. My ruler weighs about \_\_\_\_\_\_ units.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Exercise on percentage calculation, With Answer)
John, Darren, and Paul shared 90 sweets. John got 24 sweets, Darren got 39 sweets, and Paul got the remaining sweets. What percentage of the sweets did Paul get?

\subsection*{Answers}
Paul got 37 sweets, which is \( \frac{37}{90} \times 100 \approx 41.11\% \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer, Exercise on percentages)
Bernard bought a painting for \$3600. Lucas bought a similar painting that cost 35\% more than Bernard's painting. How much money did Lucas pay for his painting?

\subsection*{Answers}
Lucas paid \$4860 for his painting.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 5 (Exercise on measurement conversion, With Answer)

Find the equivalent measures.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.4 \) m = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ cm
\item \( 1.25 \) kg = \_\_\_\_\_\_ kg \_\_\_\_\_\_ g
\item \( 305 \) ml = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ L
\item \( 0.75 \) ft = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ in.
\item \( 6.25 \) lb = \_\_\_\_\_ lb \_\_\_\_\_ oz
\item \( 3.25 \) gal = \_\_\_\_\_\_ gal \_\_\_\_\_ c
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 40 \) cm
\item \( 1 \) kg \( 250 \) g
\item \( 0.305 \) L
\item \( 9 \) in.
\item \( 6 \) lb \( 4 \) oz
\item \( 3 \) gal \( 4 \) c
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on percentage conversion, With Answer)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.47 \)
\item \( \frac{6}{15} \)
\item \( 215 \) out of \( 500 \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 47\% \)
\item \( 40\% \)
\item \( 43\% \)
\end{enumerate}

\item \( 16\% \)  Decimal: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  Fraction: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

What is \( 32\% \) of \( \$96 \)?

\subsection*{Answers}
The answer is \( \$30.72 \).

Find the average of \( 21.4 \), \( 18.2 \), and \( 65.7 \).

\subsection*{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on averages, With Answer)
Fill in the blank: The average of \( 42 \), \( 36 \), \_\_\_\_\_\_ , and \( 25 \) is \( 30 \).

\subsection*{Answers}
The missing value is \( 17 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on percentage calculation, With Answer)
John had \( \$75 \). He spent \( \$15 \) on a book. What percentage of his money does he have left?

\subsection*{Answers}
He has \( 80\% \) of his money left.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on discount calculation, With Answer)
The normal price of a camera was \( \$76 \). At a sale, it was sold at a discount of \( 15\% \). What was the selling price of the camera?

\subsection*{Answers}
The selling price of the camera is \( \$64.60 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on average weight calculation, With Answer)
The average weight of \( 3 \) packages is \( 2 \) kg \( 750 \) g. The average weight of \( 2 \) of them is \( 3 \) kg \( 200 \) g. Find the weight of the third package. Give your answer in kg and g.

\subsection*{Answers}
The weight of the third package is \( 1 \) kg \( 850 \) g.


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

In a city, the rate for taxi fare for the first kilometer is \( \$2.60 \) and for every additional kilometer it is \( \$0.80 \). Find the taxi fare for a journey of \( 6.5 \) km.

\subsection*{Answers}
The taxi fare is \( \$7.40 \).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (Exercise on volume calculation, With Answer)
A rectangular container \( 8 \) cm long and \( 9 \) cm wide was filled with water to a depth of \( 6 \) cm. When \( 12 \) marbles of equal size were added to the container, the depth of the water became \( 7.5 \) cm. Find the volume of one marble.

\subsection*{Answers}
The volume of one marble is \( 9 \text{cm}^3 \).


(Mathematics) (Geometry Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on volume calculation of cubes, With Answer)
How many \( 4 \)-cm cubes can fit into a rectangular box that is \( 1 \) m long, \( 0.4 \) m wide, and \( 0.6 \) m high?

\subsection*{Answers}
The number of \( 4 \)-cm cubes that can fit into the box is \( 3750 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 5 (Exercise on money distribution, With Answer)

Sam had \( \$85 \) and John had \( \$220 \). They were each given an equal amount of money. After receiving the money, John had twice as much money as Sam. How much money did each boy receive?

\subsection*{Answers}
Each boy received \( \$50 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise with ratio calculation, With Answer)
Alice has \( 50\% \) of the amount of money Betty has, and Carrie has \( \frac{2}{5} \) of what Alice has. If Betty has \( \$364 \) more than Carrie, how much money does Alice have?

\subsection*{Answers}
Alice has \( \$227.50 \).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on volume calculation, With Answer)
The length of one side of a cube is \( 1 \) \text{ft}. What is its volume in cubic inches?

\subsection*{Answers}
The volume is \( 1728 \text{ in}^3 \).

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Exercise on equivalent fractions, Multi-part)
